Separate applications must be made and separate licenses must be obtained for each location at which an activity requiring a license is conducted. 
(b)  For a retail consumption dealer, if the sale of alcoholic beverages within an establishment or business at a specific location is handled through a concession contract, the license for such location shall be obtained jointly in the name of the entity which operates the business or establishment within which such concession is located and the name of the entity operating the concession. A "concession contract," for purposes of this subsection, shall mean an agreement or arrangement where the person selling alcoholic beverages is doing so as a department or section of a larger business enterprise, for example, a beverage service operated within a hotel, food and beverage services operated within an indoor commercial recreational establishment or outdoor commercial recreational establishment, or a beverage service operated within an eating establishment. For purposes of determining whether a particular business enterprise qualifies as an eating establishment, hotel, indoor commercial recreational establishment or an outdoor commercial recreational establishment, the activities, facilities and sales of the business enterprise as a whole shall be aggregated, and the individual sales or facilities of any concession therein shall not be treated separately. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-48. - Application procedure. 
(a)  A person desiring to obtain a license under this article shall make application to the director of development services on the forms prescribed by the director. 
(b)  The application shall include, but not be limited to, confirmation that all criteria required under section 6-50 has been satisfied. 
(c)  All applicants shall furnish the account number of the current occupation tax for that location, certification from the county tax commissioner that all taxes due to the county by the applicant have been paid and other material as required by the director of development services. Failure to furnish such data as required by the director of development services shall be deemed to be a withdrawal of the application. 
(d)  Each application for an initial license shall have attached thereto a plat of the land on which the establishment is proposed to be located showing the location of the improvements thereon. Such plat must be prepared by a land surveyor registered under the laws of the state and the surveyor shall show on the plat and certify as to the accuracy thereof the distance from the main entrance door of the proposed establishment to any school building, church building, county park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility measured under the applicable provisions of section 6-52. 
(e)  All applications shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to administer oaths. 
(f)  An application shall be presented to the board of commissioners or a committee designated by the board of commissioners within 45 days after the date such application is deemed complete by the director. The director shall notify the applicant in writing of the date on which the application will be presented to the board of commissioners or its designated committee, which notice shall be given in sufficient time to enable the applicant to meet the public notice requirements as set forth in section 6-51. 
(g)  At the time the application is presented to the board of commissioners or its designated committee, the applicant may appear and present any matters in support of the application and any other person may appear and present matters in opposition to the application. Upon hearing all of the presentations, the board of commissioners or its designated committee shall take action denying or granting the application or deferring action for a period not to exceed 45 days in order to obtain further information. If the application is denied, the board of commissioners or its designated committee shall set forth the reasons for the denial. 
(h)  In all instances in which an application is denied under the provisions of this article, the applicant, or related person or entity, may not reapply for a similar license for the same location for at least one year from the date of such denial. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-49. - Withdrawal of application; refund of fees. 
Any application for a license made pursuant to this article may be withdrawn by the applicant at any time. If the application is withdrawn before the license is issued, any sums deposited as license fees will be refunded. After issuance of a license, no refunds will be made. No refunds shall be made under any circumstances for investigation and administrative fees required in this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-50. - Licensing qualifications. 
(a)  Citizenship; residency. A license will be issued only to a person who is a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States. Where an applicant is other than a natural person, it must be an entity organized and existing under the laws of the United States or one of its states, an agent of the entity must meet the qualifications set forth herein. 
(1)  Where the applicant for a license is an entity other than a natural person, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the entity and an officer having authority to bind the entity. Said entity shall be registered to do business in the State of Georgia. 
(2)  Licenses issued to entities must be issued jointly to the entity and all of the other persons required by this section to join in the application. All respective partners, officers, directors, or members, as applicable, shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. 
(b)  Operation of business. If none of the applicants required above have primary responsibility of the day to day operations of the business for which the license is sought, then the operating manager shall join in the application. All persons named on the application shall be deemed "applicants". 
(c)  Background check. The person who has the primary responsibilities of the day to day operations of the business for which the license is sought shall submit a personnel statement in the form prescribed by the director of development services, and submit to a background check. 
(d)  Moral character; criminal record. No person or entity shall be granted an alcoholic beverage license unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the commission that such persons or partners in the firms or officers and directors of the company shall be of good moral character. 
(e)  Age. An applicant must be 21 years of age or older. 
(f)  Interest in business; involvement in business. An applicant must have a bona-fide interest in the business for which the license is sought. 
(g)  Eligibility. The following individuals are not eligible for an alcoholic beverage license, even if they possess all of the qualifications listed herein. 
(1)  Any person convicted of a felony within the ten years immediately preceding the date of receipt of submission of the application. 
(2)  Any person who has been convicted of a crime of moral turpitude or gambling within ten years immediately preceding the date of receipt of submission of the application. 
(3)  Any person whose license to sell alcoholic beverages has been revoked for cause in any county, municipality, state or territory of the United States within the ten years preceding the filing of the application. 
(4)  Any person who has knowingly falsified information or made any material misrepresentation on the application for a license under this chapter or any application under the predecessor ordinance for Columbia County submitted within the ten years preceding the filing of the application. 
(5)  Any person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal, state or local law pertaining to the possession, manufacture, sale or use of alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, or imitation controlled substances within the ten years preceding the filing of the application. 
(6)  Should any such applicant, partner or officer or director of any applicant entity, after a license has been granted, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a crime involving moral turpitude, or to the violation of any laws of the State of Georgia regulating possession or the sale of controlled substances, imitation controlled substances, drugs, liquors, wine or beer or the lottery laws of this state, said license shall be subject after hearing to immediate suspension or revocation. Should the operating manager be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a crime involving moral turpitude, or to the violation of any laws of the State of Georgia regulating possession or the sale of narcotics, drugs, liquors, wine or beer or the lottery laws of this state, the licensee shall have seven days to report to the director of development services and any such violation 45 days from such conviction to revise its license to add a new operating manager. Failure to report a violation within the time prescribed shall automatically revoke applicant's license. 
(h)  Surrogates. The board of commissioners or its designated committee may decline to issue a license under this article when any person having any ownership interest in or any control over the land or building in which the establishment to be operated pursuant to the license will be located, or where any person who has control over the operation of the establishment, does not meet the same character requirements as set forth in this section for the licensee. 
(i)  Registered agent. Applicant must appoint and continuously maintain in the county a registered agent upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law or under this article may be served. The registered agent must be a resident of the county. The licensee shall file the name of such registered agent, along with the written consent to serve of such agent, with the director of development services. 
(j)  Extenuating circumstances. The board of commissioners or its designated committee, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, the application or the proposed location of the establishment. If, in the board of commissioners' or the committee's judgment, circumstances are such that issuing of a license under this article would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-51. - Public notice of application for new license. 
A person filing an application for a new license under this article as opposed to an application for the renewal of an existing license shall give public notice of the filing of the application as follows: 
(1)  By publishing a notice of the application in the newspaper in which sheriff's sales in the county are placed, in a form approved by the director of development services, three times in the 30 days preceding the consideration of the application by the board of commissioners; 
(2)  By posting a sign for at least 30 days preceding the consideration of the application by the board of commissioners in a prominent position on the property where it can be readily read from the road, which states: 
"Application has been made to the board of commissioners for a license to sell (beer) (wine) (distilled spirits) for consumption (on) (off) premises at this location." 
Date:________        ___________        Name of Applicant 
The applicant must provide the board of commissioners proof of the giving of such public notice at or prior to the board of commissioners' consideration of the application. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-52. - Distance requirements. 
(a)  No establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article shall be located in a building which is closer than 100 yards to a church building, or closer than 200 yards to a school building, county park or playground, or an alcoholic treatment facility. In applying this section, the director shall determine what property is included in a school building, church building, county park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, subject to the qualifications set forth in this subsection, distances shall be measured in a straight line from the main entrance door of the establishment for which the license under this article is being sought to the nearest point on the boundary line of the land making up the campus of the church building, school building, county park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility. 
(c)  No establishment which is being operated pursuant to a county license to sell alcohol on May 19, 2015, the effective date of this article, shall be denied continued operation under such existing license, nor denied any renewal of such license, nor shall any new owner of such establishment be denied a new license based upon the measurements set forth in this section. Upon cessation of the operation of the establishment as set forth in section 6-56 pursuant to such license, such exemption shall cease. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the cessation of the operation of the establishment is for one year or less, such exemption shall not cease. 
(d)  The holder of title to any property making up a church building, school building, county park or playground, or alcoholic treatment facility may waive the distance requirements of this section as they apply to such facility in any specific instance by recording in the real estate records in the office of the clerk of superior court of the county, a written instrument evidencing such waiver and setting out the terms thereof, which instrument shall be executed and witnessed with the same formalities as a deed filed for record in the clerk's office. 
(e)  This section shall not apply within the area of the county bounded on the west by Evans Town Center Blvd, on the north and east by North Belair Road, and on the south by Evans to Locks Road. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 18-03 , § 1(Exh. A), 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 6-53. - Administrative and investigative fees. 
(a)  Upon making application for a license under this article, the applicant shall pay a license fee for the license, an administrative and investigative fee and such other fees as may be established from time to time by the board of commissioners by resolution adopted in open meeting and kept on file in the office of the county clerk. All applicants shall be furnished a copy of the schedule of fees at the time of application for a license under this article. In addition, all fees and taxes due the state and/or county by the applicant, or upon the property on which the establishment is to be located, must be paid in full at or prior to the time of filing the application for the license. 
(b)  All licenses granted under this article shall be for a calendar year or the balance thereof and the full license fee shall be paid for a license if the license is issued on or after January 1 but prior to April 1 of such year. Three-fourths of the license fee shall be paid if the license is issued on or after April 1 but prior to July 1, one-half of the license fee shall be paid if the license is issued on or after July 1 but prior to October 1, and one-fourth of the license fee shall be paid if the license is issued on or after October 1 of the calendar year for which the license is issued. The license fee for temporary permits under section 6-105 shall not be adjusted in any case. 
(c)  Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by payment for the full amount of the license fee and applicable investigative and administrative fees. If the applicant is denied a state license, the deposit representing the license fee shall be refunded, but the investigative and administrative fees shall be retained. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-54. - Display at place of business. 
A license issued under this article shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to public view at the place of business for which the license was granted. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-55. - Transferability. 
(a)  No license under this article shall be transferable, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(b)  In case of the death of a licensee who is the sole licensee, the establishment for which the license was issued shall be allowed to continue to sell alcoholic beverages in accordance with the terms of the license for a period of 45 days from the date of death of the licensee or until approval of a new licensee, whichever shall first occur; provided, however, that no sale of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed after the seventh day after the date of death of the licensee until such time as a personal representative of the estate of the deceased licensee, appointed by a probate court of competent jurisdiction, shall have registered with the director of development services on forms prepared by the director. Such personal representative shall be subject to all of the requirements that applied to the deceased licensee, and shall agree in writing to operate the establishment during the interim period in accordance with the terms of the license and the laws of the state and county. 
(c)  In the case of licenses issued jointly to an entity, if there is a change in control or ownership of the licensee, partnership, corporation or other business entity, then an application for a new license must be filed within seven days. Upon issuance of a new license, the authorization to sell under the previous license shall be revoked by operation of law. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the only change in control of the licensee, partnership, corporation or other business entity is a change in the operating manager, a new license shall not be required. A licensee shall have 45 days to hire a new operating manager and the new operating manager shall, within seven days of being hired, submit a personnel statement in the form prescribed by the director of development services, and submit to a background check. 
(d)  If there is a change in control or ownership of licensee's entity, and if an application for a new license is filed with the director within seven days of such sale or transfer, the establishment may continue to be operated under the then existing license for a period of 45 days or until a new license is issued or denied, whichever shall occur first. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-56. - Automatic forfeiture for nonuse. 
A license shall automatically terminate without further action in the event any licensee, for a period of two consecutive months after the license under this article has been issued, ceases to operate the business of selling alcoholic beverages as authorized in the license. If the business operation of selling alcoholic beverages is interrupted as a result of damage to the premises which is being repaired or because the premises are being remodeled, then this section shall not apply to such cessation of operation. If a license is issued for the operation of an establishment in a building which has not yet been completed, the license will not be forfeited unless the licensee fails to begin operations within a period of the earlier of 60 days after a certificate of occupancy is awarded or 180 days from the date of issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-57. - Expiration; renewal. 
(a)  All licenses granted under this article shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file application with the director of development services on the form provided for renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed on or before October 31 of each year. If a renewal application is received after October 31, the county cannot assure the applicant that a renewal license will be issued by January 1 and the licensee will have to cease the sale of alcoholic beverages from January 1 until the renewal license is issued. If a license renewal application is received after December 31, such application shall be treated as an application for a new license and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules, regulations and fees for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been issued. 
(b)  Any person applying for renewal of a license must pay the license, administrative and investigative fees at the time of filing the application. Failure to pay such fees at that time shall result in the application for renewal being treated as not filed or withdrawn. Any person applying for a renewal license who meets the qualifications of section 6-50 shall be issued a renewed license. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-32 , § 1, 11-1-2016) 
Sec. 6-58. - Audits. 
The director of development services, in order to determine if the provisions of this chapter are being complied with or to determine the eligibility of an applicant, may require a licensee or an applicant for a license under this article to provide the director with audited financial statements of the licensee or applicant for such period as the director may determine. The director shall also have the authority to conduct an audit of the books and records of a licensee or an applicant. If the director deems it necessary to conduct such an audit, the director shall so notify the licensee or applicant of the date, time and place of the audit. The director shall designate the person to perform such audit. The licensee shall cooperate with such audit or forfeit all licenses issued under this article. If an applicant for a license fails to cooperate with an audit, the application shall be deemed withdrawn. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-59. - Collection of delinquent sums. 
If any person shall fail to pay any sum due under this chapter, the director of development services or his designee shall issue an execution against the delinquent person and his property for the amount of the delinquent fee or tax. No person or entity shall be granted an alcohol license, or have its license renewed, until all monies otherwise owed to the county, including, but not limited to, property taxes, occupation taxes and stormwater fees, shall be paid unless a proper appeal of the same is pending. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-60. - Licensee to maintain copies of regulations; responsibility for instruction; violations. 
Each licensee shall keep a copy of this chapter, the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code and any regulations issued under such code on the premises. The licensee shall instruct any employee or agent of the licensee working in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages as to the requirements of all laws and regulations applicable to such sales so that the licensee, his agents and employees selling alcoholic beverages shall at all times be familiar with the requirements of the laws and regulations applicable to such sales. The licensee shall be responsible for any acts of his agents or employees which are in violation of this chapter or of the laws of the state or the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner applicable to the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-61. - Suspension, revocation. 
(a)  A license under this article may be suspended or revoked by the board of commissioners when the licensee furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information on the application or any renewal application for a license, or for failure of the licensee to pay all fees, taxes or other charges imposed under the provisions of this chapter or other laws or ordinances of the county or state. 
(b)  Whenever the state shall revoke or suspend any permit or license to sell alcoholic beverages, the license issued under this article shall be automatically revoked or suspended, as the case may be. 
(c)  If the director of development services, the board of commissioners or its designated committee believes that probable cause exists to find that a violation of sections 6-6, 6-88 and/or 6-94 has occurred in an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article, the board of commissioners or its designated committee may temporarily suspend such license pending final determination and action on the matter by the board of commissioners or its designated committee. 
(d)  The director of development services shall revoke a license under this article where alcoholic beverages have been sold or distributed at the location covered by the license during a period of suspension of such license. 
(e)  The board of commissioners may suspend or revoke any license under this article when the licensee does not meet the licensing qualifications set forth in this article and such information becomes known to the director of development services or the board of commissioners. 
(f)  An act or omission of a licensee, its partners, officers, members which constitutes a violation of federal or state law or this chapter will subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of his license when the board of commissioners determines that the act or omission did occur, regardless of whether any criminal prosecution or conviction ensues. 
(g)  An act or omission of an employee of license on the licensed premises which constitutes a violation of federal or state law or this chapter will subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of his license when the board of commissioners determines that the act or omission did occur, regardless of whether any criminal prosecution or conviction ensues; provided the board of commissioners determines that the acts of the employee were known to or, under reasonable circumstances, should have been known to the licensee, or were condoned by the licensee, or that the licensee had not established reasonable practices or procedures to prevent such act or omission from occurring. 
(h)  A license under this article may be suspended or revoked whenever the board of commissioners determines that a licensee no longer maintains the responsibility upon which issuance of the license was based or whenever the licensee has defaulted in any obligation of any kind whatsoever lawfully owing to the county. 
(i)  A license under this article may be suspended or revoked whenever the board of commissioners determines that the establishment operated pursuant to the license has been the scene of repeated incidents of violence resulting in injury to a person or damage to property or a disturbance of the peace or requiring the intervention of law enforcement officers on the scene of a single incident of severe violence resulting in the death of a person or serious injury to a person requiring inpatient hospital care for the injured person. 
(j)  Upon completion of any period of suspension, a license under this article shall not be reinstated until the licensee has paid the county a reinstatement fee equal to the original license fee for that calendar year. In addition, the licensee shall pay the administrative and investigative fees and update all license application forms. 
(k)  A license under this article shall be immediately revoked upon a conviction of applicant or any other person required to be named on the application of a violation of any federal, state or local law pertaining to the possession, manufacture, sale or use of alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, or imitation controlled substances. 
(l)  A license under this article shall be revocable for a criminal charge of any violation of federal, state or local law pertaining to the possession, manufacture, sale or use of alcoholic beverages, controlled substances, or imitation controlled substances which took place at the business establishment for which the license is given. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-62. - Hearings. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, or unless waived by the licensee, no license under this article shall be suspended or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section. 
(b)  The director of development services shall provide written notice to the licensee of the initiation of an action to suspend or revoke a license. Such written notification shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for such action and shall notify the licensee of the right to a hearing under the provisions of this section. Any licensee against whom action for the suspension or revocation of a license is initiated may have a hearing concerning such action before the board of commissioners or a committee thereof designated by the board of commissioners. Such hearing shall be by written request, filed in the office of the director of development services within seven days after the date of the notice of the initiation of the action from the director of development services to the licensee. Such written request shall set forth the reasons why the licensee feels that the proposed action should not be taken and, in reasonable detail, the grounds and facts which the licensee contends support the licensee's position. The board of commissioners shall determine whether or not the license shall be temporarily suspended during the period prior to the hearing and until action is taken by the board of commissioners or its designated committee. Failure of the licensee to request a hearing within the time specified shall be deemed to be a waiver by the licensee of a right to a hearing, and the board of commissioners shall be authorized to proceed with final action on the matter without the holding of a hearing. 
(c)  The board of commissioners, by resolution, may assign the duties of conducting a hearing to a committee of the board of commissioners. The committee's action shall be final. 
(d)  A hearing, if requested, shall be held within 45 days of the date of filing the request for a hearing with the director of development services. At such hearing the licensee shall have the right to be represented by an attorney, at the expense of the licensee, and to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. 
(e)  The action of the board of commissioners or its committee shall be forwarded to the director of development services within seven days after the conclusion of the hearing, and the director of development services shall notify the licensee by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the action taken by the board of commissioners or its committee. 
(f)  The action of the board of commissioners or its committee shall be final when taken. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-63. - Notice. 
For the purpose of this chapter, notice shall be deemed to be delivered when such notice is personally served or, if mailed, it must be mailed to the licensee at the address given in the latest application for the license under this article by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall be deemed delivered on the third day after the date of deposit in the United States mail. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Secs. 6-64—6-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 

Sec. 6-86. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-87. - Sale of beverages by indoor and outdoor commercial recreational establishments. 
(a)  A retail consumption dealer which is an indoor commercial recreational establishment shall not sell alcoholic beverages at any time that such dealer is having a promotion or event for which it can reasonably be anticipated that in excess of 50 percent of those persons attending will be under 21 years of age. 
(b)  An indoor commercial recreational establishment which is a billiard parlor and is operated pursuant to a license shall not admit any customer to the premises who is under 21 years of age at any time that alcoholic beverages are being offered for sale on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-88. - Gambling prohibited on the premises of retail consumption dealers. 
There shall be no gambling, betting, lotteries, games of chance or the operation of any scheme for hazarding money or any other thing of value on any licensed premises. No retail consumption dealer shall permit in his establishment slot machines, pinball machines or similar machines which require a federal gambling stamp. Notwithstanding anything in this division to the contrary, this section shall not prohibit the sale on the premises of any retail consumption dealer of state lottery tickets, cards or games which are legally sold under the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-89. - Open area and patio sales. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverage sales can be made by a retail consumption dealer in a patio/open area type environment on the premises if the retail consumption dealer has been approved to do so by the director of development services. 
(b)  To obtain such approval, the patio/open area must be enclosed by a permanent structure providing for public ingress/egress only through the main structure on the premises covered by the license. 
(c)  The height of the enclosing structure shall be a minimum of four feet above ground level. Such enclosing structure does not have to be solid, nor does it have to restrict visibility into or out of the patio/open sales area. Such enclosing structure must be permitted and approved by development services. 
(d)  There must be an approved emergency fire exit (not for general public use unless an emergency exists) from the patio/open sales area which should be of the type that sounds an alarm so that the licensee will be alerted in the event of unauthorized use when no emergency exists. 
(e)  If a licensee desires a patio/open sales area inside an existing structure, plans will be reviewed and approved on an individual basis by the director of development services. Interior-type patio/open sales areas must also meet the requirements of the county's planning, zoning, engineering and fire codes, and any applicable codes of the state. 
(f)  Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, if the retail consumption dealer is an outdoor commercial recreational establishment, alcoholic beverage sales can be made outdoors in the open, provided that such alcoholic beverages must be consumed on the premises of the outdoor commercial recreational establishment and may not be carried off of such premises. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-90. - Outside consumption prohibited; exception. 
(a)  Except for the area and circumstances specified in subsection (c), below, and as specified in section 6-117, no person shall leave the building in which alcoholic beverages are sold with open alcoholic beverage containers unless such person is in a patio/open sales area which is approved in accordance with section 6-89 or on the premises of outdoor commercial recreational establishments with an existing license. It is the licensee's responsibility to ensure that no open alcoholic beverage containers are carried out of the building in violation of this section. 
(b)  People shall not gather outside any building in which alcoholic beverages are sold and consume alcoholic beverages or loiter. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee operating the business in such building to prevent such gatherings. 
(c)  Within the area of the county bounded on the west by Evans Town Center Blvd, on the north and east by North Belair Road, and on the south by Evans to Locks Road the following regulations apply: 
(1)  Any licensee may sell alcoholic beverages in a paper or plastic cup for removal from the premises; provided, however, that the alcoholic beverage is not placed in a can, bottle or other glass container and, further provided, that the licensee may sell no more than one alcoholic beverage per person, per transaction, and no person shall remove more than one alcoholic beverage from the premises at a time; and 
(2)  Any alcoholic beverage dispensed pursuant to this section shall not exceed 16 fluid ounces in size and no person shall possess an open container containing an alcoholic beverage in excess of 16 fluid ounces on the streets, sidewalks, parks, squares or other public places within the area described in this section. No person shall possess more than one alcoholic beverage at a time. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 18-03 , § 2(Exh. B), 2-6-2018) 
Sec. 6-91. - Solicitation. 
A retail consumption dealer shall not require, permit, suffer, encourage or induce any employee or person to solicit on the premises, for himself or for any person other than the patron and guest of the patron, the purchase by the patron of any drink, whether an alcoholic beverage or nonalcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-92. - Happy hours or similar promotions. 
(a)  No retail consumption dealer, his employees or agents, in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages, shall: 
(1)  Offer or deliver any free alcoholic beverage to any person, except as permitted under section 6-118; 
(2)  Deliver more than one alcoholic beverage to one person at a time; 
(3)  Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished to any person an unlimited number of alcoholic beverages during any set period of time for a fixed price, except at private functions not open to the public; 
(4)  Increase the volume of alcohol contained in a drink without proportionately increasing the price regularly charged for such alcoholic beverage; 
(5)  Encourage or permit on the premises any game or contest which involves the drinking of alcoholic beverages or the awarding of alcoholic beverages as a prize; and 
(6)  Sell, offer to sell, furnish or cause to be furnished any alcoholic beverages for a price less than the cost of the ingredients to the licensee, except as permitted under section 6-118. 
(b)  No retail consumption dealer shall advertise or promote in any way, whether within or without the premises, any of the practices prohibited under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit retail consumption dealers from offering free food or entertainment at any time, or to prohibit the retail consumption dealer from including an alcoholic beverage as part of a meal package, or to prohibit the sale or delivery of wine by the bottle or carafe, or pitchers or buckets of beer. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-93. - Report of changed condition. 
(a)  A licensee shall file with the director a written, sworn report of any of the following changes: 
(1)  Any change in any legal relationship between any parties named in the application for the license; 
(2)  Any change in the ownership of the licensed premises; 
(3)  Any loss or damage to goods or premises of the licensee which results in a claim against an insurance policy; 
(4)  Any change for any purpose in division of net or gross sales of the licensed business; and 
(5)  Any change in any material facts contained in the application for the license. 
(6)  Any licensee who has any disciplinary action taken against him or any of his employees who sell, take orders for, deliver, or handle alcoholic beverages by any governmental authority (municipal, county, state, or federal) shall notify the sheriff and the director of development services of such action within seven days of such action. The following shall be considered to be disciplinary action: any arrest; the issuance of any citation; any indictment, presentment, or accusation; any conviction, including the acceptance of a plea of nolo contendere; any penalty imposed by any regulatory agency; and any other written charge or reprimand against the licensee or any of his employees. The provisions of this section shall not apply with respect to citations for traffic offenses. 
(b)  Such report shall be filed within five days after the date the change or disciplinary action occurs. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-94. - Certain types of entertainment, attire and conduct prohibited. 
The sale of alcohol shall not be permitted at an adult bookstore, adult entertainment establishment or adult theater as defined in section 90-9 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-95. - Inspection of licensed establishments. 
Officers of the sheriff's department, health department, fire marshal, or code enforcement shall have the authority to inspect an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article during the hours in which the establishment is open for business. Such inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this chapter and state law. This section is not intended to limit the authority of any other county officer to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-96. - Closing establishment in case of emergency. 
The sheriff or the director of development services, or their designees, may immediately close an establishment operated pursuant to a license under this article in case of an emergency, for the safety of the public or to investigate a crime for a period of time not to exceed 24 hours, or for such longer period of time as law enforcement officials may reasonably require to complete a criminal investigation at the establishment. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-97. - Bringing alcoholic beverages into establishments. 
No person shall bring his own alcoholic beverages into any commercial establishment regardless of whether or not such establishment is operated pursuant to a license under this article. For the purposes of this section, the term commercial establishment shall not include a private hotel room or other similar guest room or a private club. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-98. - Consumption on-premises of distilled spirits; locations where permitted. 
A license for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises will be issued only for an eating establishment, a hotel, an indoor or outdoor commercial recreational establishment, a private club or a on commercial vessel operating or moored in waters located within the county. When eating establishments are located in hotels, shopping malls or high-rise office or apartment buildings, every public entrance to the eating establishment shall be from the outside or a public lobby, hallway, mall or other publicly used interior portion of the primary use structure. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 18-12, § 2, 9-18-2018 ) 
Sec. 6-99. - Hours and days of sale of alcohol. 
Alcohol may be sold at all times not otherwise prohibited by state law. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-100. - Consumption sales only of distilled spirits. 
Persons holding a license to sell distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall not be permitted to make any package sales of alcoholic beverages on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-101. - Drinks to be served by employees. 
Alcoholic beverages sold by the drink must be served by employees of the licensee within the premises covered by the license. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-102. - Storage of inventory. 
A retail consumption dealer must keep his inventory of alcoholic beverages only on the premises covered by his license. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-103. - Beer and wine consumption on-premises; locations where permitted. 
No license for the sale of beer or wine for consumption on the premises will be issued except for an eating establishment, a hotel, an indoor or outdoor commercial recreational establishment, or a private club. This section shall not apply with respect to: (1) tastings provided pursuant to a wine or beer tasting permit or (2) tastings provided pursuant to a growler beer tasting permit. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-104. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-105. - Temporary event permits. 
Functions held in the unincorporated area of Columbia County at which alcoholic beverages are sold or provided will require temporary permits except as set out in subsection (4) below. 
(1)  Temporary permit required. A temporary permit must be purchased for any function at which alcoholic beverages are sold to the guests directly or indirectly. The individuals, or an officer with authority to bind the entity, putting on the function must apply for the temporary permit. In the alternative, if a Columbia County properly licensed retail consumption dealer or a properly licensed retail consumption dealer in another Georgia County that borders on Columbia County is catering the alcoholic beverages being provided at the off-premises function, the temporary permit may be issued to such retail consumption dealer. 
(2)  Obtaining temporary permit. To obtain a temporary permit, the appropriate person must obtain from Columbia County the necessary application forms and then file with the county, at least 21 days prior to the date of the function, a completed application and pay to the county the required fees. A temporary permit will be good for a period of not more than two days. Prior to the issuance of a temporary permit, the application filed must be approved by the county administrator and the director of the county division that handles the issuance of alcohol licenses. No public notice of the application shall be required for any temporary permit. Alcoholic beverages may be included in the price of admission to the function and no excise taxes shall be paid or collected on such sales. If the temporary permit is being issued to a retail consumption dealer, the dealer must present a copy of its county retail consumption dealer license and any State of Georgia Alcohol Licenses that may be required. 
(3)  Functions held by licensed retail consumption dealer. Any properly licensed Columbia County retail consumption dealer may obtain a temporary permit for a function which is not held on the premises covered by such dealers license and which may be held outdoors and/or under a tent. To obtain such a temporary permit, the retail consumption dealer must meet all of the requirements in subsections (1) and (2) directly above. 
(4)  Functions not requiring temporary permit. A temporary permit shall not be required for serving alcoholic beverages when the function is by invitation only, there is no charge made or other consideration provided for the invitation to the function, for admission to the function or for any food or beverages served at the function and the alcoholic beverages have been legally purchased. Such functions include weddings, company banquets, retirement parties, and private church, club or organization events. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-106. - Retail package sales of distilled spirits for off-premises consumption; type of retail establishments. 
Retail sales of distilled spirits in packages for consumption off the premises shall be made only in establishments dedicated primarily to the retail sale of distilled spirits, beer and/or wine in packages, and located in zoning districts in which such establishments are permitted as a conforming use. Establishments operated pursuant to a license permitting the sale of distilled spirits in packages may sell alcoholic beverages in packages through a drive-up window allowing pass through to automobiles or pedestrians, provided that all such packages are sealed. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-107. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-108. - Use of tags or labels to indicate prices. 
A retail package dealer shall indicate plainly, by tags or labels on the packages or on the shelf immediately below where the packages are placed, the prices of distilled spirits exposed or offered for sale. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-109. - Sealed containers required for distilled spirit sales. 
No sales of distilled spirits in packages shall be made except in fully sealed containers. Single sealed cans or bottles or other containers or packages of distilled spirits may be sold. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-110. - Retail package sales of beer and wine for off-premises consumption. 
(a)  Retail sales of beer and/or wine in packages for consumption off the premises shall be made only in establishments maintaining 50 percent of the floor space and storage area in a manner which is devoted principally to the retail sale of other products such as grocery stores, convenience stores, delicatessens and similar type facilities, or in establishments dedicated primarily to the sale of beer and/or wine and/or distilled spirits in packages. Any such establishment must be located in a zoning district in which such establishment is permitted as a conforming use unless the establishment was previously existing establishment qualifying as a nonconforming use. 
(b)  Retail sales of growlers in compliance with this section shall be authorized for establishments defined in subsection 6-110(a) authorized to sell alcoholic beverages, excluding distilled spirits, by the package. Before making any such retail sales, the holder of the alcohol license for the premises must obtain from Columbia County a permit for the sale of growler's and for providing samples of tap beers pursuant to such regulations as are established by the board of commissioners of the county. The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package as contemplated by O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-26, and 3-4-25, or other provisions of this section. Growlers may only be filled from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler. Only professionally sanitized and sealed growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale. Each growler must be securely sealed with a tamperproof plastic cap and removed from the premises in its original sealed condition. Consumption on the premises is strictly prohibited. However, samples of tap beers may be made available, but shall not exceed more than one ounce nor shall any one individual be offered more than three samples within a 24-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-111. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-112. - Use of tags or labels to indicate prices. 
A retail package dealer shall indicate plainly, by tags or labels on the packages or on the shelf immediately below where the packages are placed, the prices of distilled spirits exposed or offered for sale. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-113. - Sealed containers required for sale of beer and wine in packages. 
No sales of beer or wine in packages shall be made, except in full sealed containers. Single cans or bottles or other containers or packages of beer or wine may be sold. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-114. - Wholesale purchase of distilled spirits, beer and wine. 
(a)  No retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer shall purchase any alcoholic beverage from any person other than a wholesaler. No wholesaler shall sell any alcoholic beverage to any person other than a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the purchase by one retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer of another retail consumption dealer's or retail package dealer's entire stock in a bona fide purchase of an ongoing business. 
(b)  No alcoholic beverage shall be delivered to any retail sales outlet in the county, except by a wholesaler. The name of the wholesaler shall be clearly marked on the delivery vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-115. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-116. - Hotel in-room service. 
(a)  Definition. As used in this section, "in-room service" means the delivery of alcoholic beverages as defined in O.C.G.A. § 3-9-10. 
(b)  License. A hotel, if it has a license to sell alcoholic beverages either by the package and/or by the drink, may be authorized by the board of commissioners to make similar sales through in-room service. A hotel, prior to providing in-room service, must obtain from the county a license permitting such hotel to provide in-room service of alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  Restrictions and limitations. The sale of alcoholic beverages by in-room service shall be subject to all restrictions and limitations of this chapter relative to the retail sale of alcoholic beverages, except as provided otherwise in this section, and shall be authorized only on such days and during such hours as the sale of the alcoholic beverages in question is otherwise authorized in the county. 
(d)  Package size. Distilled spirits sold through in-room service shall not be sold in packages containing less than 200 milliliters each. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-117. - Certain government facilities. 
Anything in this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, the board of commissioners may permit the consumption and sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink on the premises of facilities owned by Columbia County, including but not limited to Savannah Rapids Pavilion, Bessie Thomas Community Center, Eubanks-Blanchard Community Center, the Library/Performing Arts Center, Memorial Gardens Complex, Wildwood Park, Exhibition Center and Evans Towne Center Park shall be permitted under the conditions set out in section 6-105 temporary event permits of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 6-118. - Wine or beer tastings. 
Wine or beer tastings may be conducted at retail package outlets licensed to sell wine and beer, but not distilled spirits, subject to the following restrictions: 
The applicant for a wine or beer tasting permit must hold a valid package license for sale of wine and beer in the state. All wines used for tasting purposes must have been purchased from a licensed state wine wholesaler. Wine bottles or beer containers shall be opened only by the holder of the valid package license and the wine or beer tasting permit or an employee thereof, and samples shall only be poured by such licensee/permittee or an employee thereof. Wine or beer tastings shall be offered not more than once per day and shall not exceed more than two hours. Samples shall not exceed two ounces per glass, nor shall any individual be offered more than four samples within a 24-hour period. No open containers of wine shall be removed from the licensed premises. Holders of a wine or beer tasting permit shall not charge for samples or tastings, but may accept donations for a charitable organization located in Columbia County. Wine or beer sampling and tasting is only permitted within the enclosed portion of the premises. Wine or beer tastings must comply with all laws and regulations otherwise pertaining to the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages in the state. All licensees and permit holders must comply with all applicable state statutes and sections of this Code concerning alcoholic beverages, including but not limited to those dealing with hours of operation, zoning, and distance requirements. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Secs. 6-119—6-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAXES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to impose excise tax on sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-131; imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80. 

Sec. 6-151. - Retail sales of distilled spirits by the drink. 
Every purchaser at retail of distilled spirits by the drink in the county shall pay a tax thereon at the rate of three percent of the retail price or charge for such drink, or at such higher rate as may be permitted by the laws of the state. Such tax shall not apply in any portion of the county in which an excise tax on the sale of distilled spirits by the drink is being imposed, levied and collected by a municipality. Such tax shall be collected by the retail consumption dealer, who shall remit such tax to the director of development services on or before the twentieth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the retail consumption dealer's gross sales derived from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the director. Credit card sales shall be reported as part of gross sales, and taxes collected on such credit card sales shall be submitted to the county in the same manner as required for cash sales. Each retail consumption dealer shall be allowed a deduction equal to the rate authorized for deductions from state tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50, as amended from time to time, provided that such tax is not delinquent at the time of payment. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-32 , § 2, 11-1-2016) 
Sec. 6-152. - Wholesale sales of distilled spirits and wine. 
There is levied an excise tax computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter, including a proportionate amount calculated at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter, on all sales of distilled spirits and wine in the county by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers. Such tax shall be paid to the director of development services by the wholesaler selling such distilled spirits or wine to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the twentieth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of distilled spirits and wine in the county during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the director. Wine containing less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. It shall be a violation of this chapter for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver, in any manner, any distilled spirits or wine to a retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer without collecting such tax. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell any distilled spirits or wine on which such tax has not been paid. Each wholesaler shall be paid three percent of the amount of taxes collected as reimbursement for collection of the tax, provided that the tax is paid on or before its due date. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-32 , § 2, 11-1-2016) 
Sec. 6-153. - Wholesale sales of beer. 
There is levied an excise tax on all beer sold by wholesalers to retail consumption dealers and retail package dealers in the county at the highest rate allowed by the state, but not less than the following: 
(1)  Where beer is sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons, and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons; and 
(2)  Where beer is sold in bottles, cans or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $0.05 per 12 ounces, and a proportionate rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. 
Beer which contains less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume shall not be subject to such tax. Such tax shall be paid to the director of development services by the wholesaler selling the beer to any retail consumption dealer or retail package dealer on or before the twentieth day of the following calendar month, along with a report of the wholesaler's gross sales of beer in the county during the reporting period on forms prescribed by the director. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-32 , § 2, 11-1-2016) 
Sec. 6-154. - Deficiency determination. 
Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation . If the director of development services is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax to be paid to the county by any person, the director may cause an audit of the books and records of the licensee to be performed and may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within the director's possession or that may come into the director's possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. It shall be the duty of each licensee subject to the collection or payment of any of the excise taxes set forth in this article to keep and preserve his records relative to the collection and payment of such taxes for three years. 
(1)  Interest . The amount of the deficiency determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day after the close of the monthly period in which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment thereof. 
(2)  Offsetting of overpayments . In making a deficiency determination, the director may offset overpayments for a period against underpayments for another period, penalties and the interest on underpayments. 
(3)  Penalty for negligence or disregard of rules and regulations . If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty of 15 percent of the amount of such deficiency shall be added to the tax. 
(4)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade . If any part of the deficiency for which a deficiency determination is made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provision of sections 6-151—6-156, or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the deficiency shall be added to such tax. 
(5)  Notice of director's determination; service of . The director or his designated representative shall give to the licensee written notice of a deficiency determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If such service is made by mail, such service shall be made pursuant to section 6-63. 
(6)  Time within which notice is to be mailed . Except in the case of fraud, intent to evade the provisions of this article or authorized rules and regulations, or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the twentieth day of every month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-32 , § 2, 11-1-2016) 
Sec. 6-155. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  Estimate of gross receipts . If any licensee fails to make a return, the director of development services shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee or of the total sales in the county which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is in or may come into the possession of the director. Upon the basis of such estimate, the director shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the county, adding to such determined sum a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or more periods. 
(b)  Offsetting of overpayments . If making a determination, the director may offset overpayments for a period or penalties against the interest on the underpayments. 
(c)  Interest on amount found due . The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the twentieth day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount, or any portion thereof, should have been returned, until the date of payment. 
(d)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade . If the failure of any person to file a return is due to fraud or an intent to evade sections 6-151—6-156 or rules and regulations, a penalty of 25 percent of the amount required to be paid by the person, exclusive of penalties, shall be added thereto in addition to the 15 percent penalty provided in section 6-154(d). 
(e)  Giving of notice; manner of service . Promptly after making his determination, the director shall give to the person written notice, to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice in section 6-63. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-32 , § 2, 11-1-2016) 
Sec. 6-156. - Collection. 
(a)  Security. Whenever the director of development services deems it necessary to ensure compliance with sections 6-151—6-156, he may require any person subject to such sections to deposit with him such security as the director may determine. The amount of the security shall be fixed by the director, but shall not be greater than twice the person's estimated average liability for the period for which he files returns, determined in such a manner as the director deems proper, or $10,000.00, whichever amount is the lesser. The amount of the security may be increased by the director subject to the limitations provided in this section. The director may sell the security at public auction, with the approval of the board of commissioners, if it becomes necessary to do so in order to recover any tax or any amount required to be collected, interest or penalty due. Notice of the sale may be served upon the person who deposited the security personally or by mail. If service is by mail, it shall be made in the manner prescribed for service of a notice of determined deficiency and shall be addressed to the person at his address as it appears in the records of the director. Upon any sale, any surplus above the amounts due shall be returned to the person who deposited the security. 
(b)  Notice of delinquency to persons holding credits or property of delinquent; duty of persons so notified. If any person is delinquent in the payment of the amount required to be paid by him, or if a delinquency determination has been made against him which remains unpaid, the director may, not later than three years after the payment became delinquent, give notice thereof by registered mail to all persons in the county having in their possession or under their control any credits or other personal property belonging to the delinquent, or owing any debts to the delinquent. After receiving the notice, the persons so notified shall neither transfer nor make any other disposition of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession or under their control at the time they receive the notice until the director consents to a transfer or disposition, or until 20 days elapse after the receipt of the notice. All persons so notified shall, within five days after receipt of the notice, advise the director of all of the credits, other personal property or debts in their possession, under their control or owing by them. 
(c)  Action for tax collection. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article becomes due and payable, and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article, the director may bring an action in the courts of this state, any other state or of the United States in the name of county to collect the amount delinquent, together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(d)  Duty of successors or assignees of licensee to withhold tax from purchase money. If any licensee liable for any amount under sections 6-151—6-156 sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the director showing that he has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(e)  Liability for failure to withhold; certificate of notice of amount due; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold the purchase price as required, he becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price valued in money. Within 30 days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the director shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchaser at his address, as it appears on the records of the director, of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of the successor may be enforced shall begin at the time the licensee sells out his business or at the time that the determination against the licensee becomes final, whichever occurs later. 
(f)  Refund of tax, penalty or interest paid more than once or illegally collected. Whenever the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the county under sections 6-151—6-156, it may be offset as provided in subsection 6-154(c) or it may be refunded provided a verified claim in writing therefor, stating the specific grounds upon which the claim is founded, is filed with the director within three years from the date of payment. The claim shall be audited and shall be made on forms provided by the director. If the claim is approved by the director and the board of commissioners, the excess amount collected or paid may be refunded or may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person from whom it was collected or by whom paid, and the balance may be refunded to such person, his administrators or executors. 
(Ord. No. 15-13, § 1(Exh. A), 5-19-2015) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 46. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned animal means any animal which has been left unattended or uncared for on public or private property. 
Advisory board means the animal care and control advisory board created under this article. 
Animal means any member of the kingdom Animalia. 
Animal care and control division means the animal care and control division within the county department of general services. 
Animal control officer means any employee of the county or the county sheriff, duly commissioned under the legal authority of the county to enforce the rules and regulations of this chapter, including any individual authorized under the provisions of section 14-61 to aid in the administration and enforcement of this chapter and applicable state laws. 
Animal running at-large means any animal not under immediate control, which is not on a leash, not at heel, not beside a competent person, not in a vehicle or not confined within the property limits of his owner, but shall not include animals which are actively engaged in sporting activities, including, but not limited to, hunting, field trials, shows, competition or other exhibitions. 
Cat means any animal classified as Felis domestica. 
County kennel or shelter means any premises designated by the animal care and control division for the purpose of impounding and caring for dogs, cats and other animals found running at-large in violation of this chapter. 
Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of the animal care and control division, inflicts a severe injury on a human, without provocation, on public or private property, at any time after March 31, 1989; or aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans, without provocation, after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog, and after the owner of such dog has been notified of such classification; provided, however, that this definition shall not include a dog which inflicts an injury: 
(1)  Upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties, or is a guard/security or attack dog which is being used for guard and/or security purposes. 
(2)  Which was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
Dog means the animal classified as Canis domestica. 
Guard or watch dog means any dog trained by a recognized training facility for the purpose of protecting individuals from assault and/or preventing property loss or damage. 
Impoundment means taking physical possession and control of an animal and transporting such animal to the county kennel or shelter. 
Inoculation means the administration of an antirabies vaccine, approved by the county board of health, administered by a licensed veterinarian or other person approved and authorized by the board of health of the county to administer inoculations. 
Livestock means animals which include fowl, horses, cows, goats, sheep, pigs or any other four-legged animal used for pleasure or profit, excluding dogs and cats. 
Owner means any natural person or legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trust, who owns, harbors, keeps, feeds, maintains, has lawful possession of, or knowingly causes or permits an animal to be harbored or kept, or has an animal in his care, or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises; provided, however, this shall not include a person hired or acting as custodian of the animal for its owner. 
Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that, without provocation, on private or public property, bites a human being at any time after March 31, 1989; provided, however, that this definition shall be subject to the same exceptions as those set forth in the definition of " dangerous dog " in this section. 
Proper pen or kennel means a pen or kennel for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, which shall be a structure suitable to prevent the entry of unauthorized individuals and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or kennel must have secure sides and a secure top which is attached to all sides. The sides must be buried two feet into the ground, sunken into a concrete pad or securely attached to a wire bottom. The gate to the pen or kennel shall be of the inward opening type. Any such pen or kennel must also provide protection from the elements for the dog. 
Public nuisance animal means any animal as set forth in section 14-12. 
Recognized training facility means any person holding a state kennel license, and conducting a business of training dogs for purposes of protecting individuals from assault and/or preventing property loss or damage. 
Records of an appropriate authority means records of any: 
(1)  State, county or municipal law enforcement agency; 
(2)  County or municipal animal care and control agency; 
(3)  County board of health; federal, state or local court; or 
(4)  An animal control officer provided for in this chapter. 
Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery, or a physical injury that results in death. 
Vicious animal means any animal that has been known to attack, bite or injure human beings, pets, companion animals or livestock, or which, because of temperament, conditioning or training, has a known propensity to attack, bite or injure human beings, pets, companion animals or livestock. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-2; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-2. - Animal care and control division to carry out purposes of chapter. 
It shall be the duty of the animal care and control division to carry out the purposes of this chapter, and to provide for a suitable impoundment of all animals in violation of this chapter which are seized by the animal care and control division. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-3; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-3. - Duties of animal control officers. 
Animal control officers shall have the authority to issue citations for violations of this chapter, to impound animals as provided in this chapter, and to perform such other duties as are set forth in this chapter. An animal control officer shall wear a uniform, nameplate and a county identification badge identifying him as an animal control officer, unless such person is an employee of the sheriff, in which case, he shall comply with the sheriff's regulations in such regard. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-4) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-186 et seq. 
Sec. 14-4. - Animal care and control advisory board created. 
There is created an animal care and control advisory board which shall consist of seven members who shall be appointed as provided for in the bylaws promulgated by the board of commissioners for the operation of the animal care and control advisory board. The terms of all existing members of the animal care and control advisory board shall terminate as of December 31, 2007. The members of the animal care and control advisory board appointed for terms beginning on or after January 1, 2008 shall serve for the terms as specified in the bylaws of the animal care and control advisory board. Each member of the animal care and control advisory board shall serve without pay and shall carry out the duties set forth in section 14-5 of the Code of Ordinances. The manager of the animal care and control division shall serve as an advisor to the animal care and control advisory board and shall attend all meetings thereof. The board of commissioners may by resolution duly adopted promulgate bylaws to govern the operations of the animal care and control advisory board. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-5; Ord. No. 07-13, § 1, 11-6-2007) 
Cross reference— Boards and commissioners, § 2-31 et seq. 
Sec. 14-5. - Duties of the animal care and control advisory board. 
The animal care and control advisory board is authorized to propose, for adoption by the board of commissioners, rules and regulations covering the operation of the animal care and control division, including, but not limited to, the impounding and disposal of animals, the disposal of dead animals, the fees to be charged in connection therewith when not otherwise provided for in this chapter, and the manner and method to be employed for such actions. Such rules and regulations shall not become effective until approved by the board of commissioners. The animal care and control advisory board shall not be authorized to spend any monies of or create any debt in the name of the county. Any rules and regulations approved by the board of commissioners shall be typed and posted at the county kennel or shelter, shall be published once in the official gazette of the county, at the county's expense, and shall be available for distribution to individuals requesting a copy of such through the animal care and control division. The animal care and control advisory board shall hear and determine matters under article II of this chapter, and shall serve as the animal control board for the purpose of hearing and determining matters under O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-6; Ord. No. 07-13, §§ 2, 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-6. - Restraint of animals. 
(a)  Animals running at-large.
