It shall be unlawful for any owner or possessor of an animal to allow such animal to run at-large within the unincorporated areas of the county, whether or not such animal is wearing a collar and tag. Any animal found running at-large, whether wearing a collar and tag or not, may be impounded by an animal control officer or any police officer. The officer may pursue the animal onto private property in order to capture such animal. 
(b)  Duty of animal owners. It shall be the duty of every owner or custodian of an animal to exercise reasonable care to protect other people, property and animals from injuries or damage which might result from such person's animal's behavior. If the owner or custodian of any animal is a minor, the parent or guardian of such minor shall be responsible to see that such reasonable care is exercised. 
(c)  Duty to keep dogs under restraint while on owner's property. It shall be the duty of every owner, possessor or custodian of a dog to exercise reasonable care to prevent the dog from leaving the real property limits of its owner, possessor or custodian. At such times as a dog is unattended, such dog shall be securely and humanely enclosed within a house, building, fence, pen or other enclosure from which it cannot climb, dig, jump or otherwise escape on its own volition. 
(1)  Additional requirements for dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs. The following additional precautions shall be taken by the owners, possessors or custodians of dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs: 
a.  The owners of dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs who maintain their dogs out-of-doors shall fence a portion of their property with a perimeter or area fence. Such fence shall be sufficient to prevent the dog's escape, with all points of ingress or egress securely locked at all times. Within such perimeter or area fence, the animal must be humanely confined inside a proper pen or kennel of adequate size. The proper pen or kennel may not share common fencing with the area or perimeter fence. The gate to the proper pen or kennel shall be kept locked, except when tending to the animal's needs, such as cleaning the kennel or providing food and water; 
b.  Whenever the dog is outside of its proper pen or kennel, but on the owner's property, such dog must be attended by the owner and restrained by a secure collar, wear a muzzle at all times, and a leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape of the dog. The leash shall be no longer than ten feet, and the animal must be kept at least 15 feet within the perimeter boundaries of the property, unless such perimeter boundary is securely fenced; 
c.  No vicious or dangerous dog shall be chained, tethered or otherwise tied to any inanimate object such as a tree, post or building, outside of its proper pen or kennel; 
d.  A minimum of two "Beware of Dog" signs shall be conspicuously displayed on each side of the proper pen or kennel for each 50 feet of enclosure, as well as a sign on each ingress or egress point to the proper pen or kennel. Such signs shall be a minimum of ten inches high and 14 inches long. The point of premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located shall be posted with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property, and containing a symbol designed to inform children of the presence of a dangerous dog. Such sign shall be four feet by four feet, and shall be posted on the property limits of the owner of such dog and on the proper pen or kennel for such animal; 
e.  Any animal control officer or any county enforcement officer shall have the authority to enter onto private property for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the provisions of this subsection (c)(1); and 
f.  Dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs are also subject to the additional regulations set forth in article II of this chapter. If there are conflicting requirements in such article, the stricter requirement shall take precedence. 
(2)  Additional requirements for guard or watch dogs. Owners or custodians of any guard or watch dog must confine all such dogs within a perimeter fence and meet the following conditions: 
a.  The perimeter fence shall be sufficient to prevent the dog's escape, with all points of ingress and egress securely locked at all times. 
b.  A minimum of two "Beware of Dog" signs shall be conspicuously displayed on each side of the enclosure for each 50 feet of enclosure, as well as a sign on each ingress or egress point to the enclosure. Such signs shall be a minimum of ten inches high and 14 inches long. 
c.  The owner or custodian of such dog shall, prior to placing such dog on the property of others in the county, obtain from the animal care and control division a registration number and distinctive identification collar for each dog. There shall be a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk for the first year's registration and identification collar and yearly renewals. Such renewal fee shall be paid by January 30 of each year. The registration number shall be tattooed, at the owner's expense, on the inside of the right hind leg or inside of the upper lip of the dog. The collar provided shall be worn at all times. 
d.  The owner or custodian of such dog shall report to the animal care and control division within 24 hours of any of the following: 
1.  Escape of the dog. 
2.  An attack on a human or animal by the dog. 
3.  Transfer of ownership of the dog. 
4.  Death of the dog. 
e.  Any animal control officer or enforcement officer of the county shall have the authority to enter onto private property for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the provisions of this subsection (c)(2). 
(d)  Duty to keep dog under restraint while off property. It shall be the duty of the owner or custodian of any dog to keep such dog under restraint and control at all times while the dog is off the real property limits of the owner, possessor or custodian. 
(1)  For the purpose of this subsection (d), a dog is deemed under control when it is: 
a.  Securely and humanely confined within a vehicle; 
b.  Properly confined within a secure enclosure with the permission of the owner of the property where the enclosure is located; 
c.  Securely restrained by a leash or other device held by a competent person; 
d.  Under voice command of a competent person who is in the immediate proximity of the dog. 
(2)  A guard or watch dog shall be deemed under control only when such dog is restrained by a collar and a secure leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape. 
(3)  Except when being transported to a licensed veterinary facility, dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs shall not be allowed off of the property of the owner of such dog. Should such transport to veterinary care be needed, the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be securely and humanely confined within a vehicle. Movement of such animal from the residence of the owner to and from the transporting vehicle and the veterinary facility shall be conducted with the animal securely leashed by a leash which is no longer than six feet in length, and muzzled by a muzzle or device constructed so as to prevent the animal from biting. 
(4)  This subsection (d) shall not apply to dogs which are actively engaged in sporting activities, including, but not limited to, hunting, field trials, shows, competitions or other exhibitions. 
(e)  Failure to restrain unlawful. Failure to keep any animal under restraint or control as provided for in this section shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in section 14-26. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-7) 
Sec. 14-7. - Wildlife. 
All complaints and matters concerning wild animals, not of a domestic nature, and complaints involving game animals or protected species and/or hunting, shall be forwarded to the game and fish division of the state department of natural resources or the United States Department of Agriculture, Law Enforcement Division. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-8) 
Sec. 14-8. - Impoundment of animals; disposition. 
(a)  All animals found running at-large in violation of this chapter may be seized or impounded by an animal control officer or any officer empowered to act by law, and detained at the county kennel or shelter. In the alternative, in his discretion, the animal control officer may return the animal to its owner. If the animal is impounded, the animal care and control division shall notify the owner, if the owner is known or can be reasonably ascertained, that the animal has been impounded. The owner of any animal impounded may, within five days after such impoundment, reclaim the animal by the payment of an impoundment fee, plus boarding fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the county clerk's office, for each day the animal was impounded. If a dog or cat which is impounded has not been inoculated for rabies as required by this article, the owner, upon reclaiming the dog or cat, must agree to promptly take the dog or cat to a veterinarian, have such animal properly inoculated, and pay the cost for such inoculation. Failure to comply with such agreement shall cause the owner of such animal to be in violation of this chapter and subject the owner to penalties as set forth in section 14-26. 
(b)  If any animal impounded by the animal care and control division evidences symptoms of contagious, infectious or fatal diseases, is seriously ill or severely injured, the animal care and control division shall determine whether to treat the animal or euthanize the animal. Such action may be taken to control the spread of disease or to eliminate any further pain and suffering of the animal. If the owner is known or can be reasonably ascertained and the circumstances of the situation permit, reasonable attempts should be made to stabilize the animal and to afford the owner the opportunity to pick up the animal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-9; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-9. - Reclamation of impounded animals. 
Any animal impounded pursuant to the provisions of this article may be reclaimed, except as provided in this chapter for dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs, by its owner by payment of a fee, and boarding fee for each day such animal was impounded, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. If a reclaimed animal has been treated according to section 14-10(c), such person reclaiming such animal shall reimburse the county for the cost of treatment. The animal care and control division shall cause the owner of such animal to have such animal vaccinated or inoculated as required by this article, at the expense of the person reclaiming such animal. Even if the owner of such animal fails to reclaim the animal, the owner shall be liable to pay the county the impoundment fee, boarding fee and all costs of treatment provided to the animal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-10; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-10. - Humane disposition. 
(a)  If an animal is not claimed by its owner within five days of impoundment, then it shall be the duty of the animal care and control division to euthanize the animal by an injection of sodium pentobarbital in as humane and painless a manner as possible by a person approved by the state to euthanize animals. At the discretion of the manager of the animal care and control division or his designee, an animal deemed to be desirable for adoption may be kept beyond the five-day limitation, provided that the animal does not evidence any apparent signs of illness, injury, contagious or infectious diseases and space is available to house the animal. Animals shall not be provided to any public or private institution, animal dealer or other individual who may use or supply the animal for research purposes. 
(b)  Any animal which is suffering excessively or which represents a danger to persons or other animals may be euthanized in the manner set forth in subsection (a) of this section, at the discretion of the manager of the animal care and control division or his designee, without regard to the five-day holding period. 
(c)  When, in the opinion of a supervisor in the animal care and control division, a diseased or injured animal which has been taken into custody is in need of immediate treatment so as to lessen the animal's suffering or to prevent the spread of a communicable disease to other animals, he may immediately obtain the services of, or place the animal with, a licensed veterinarian for the purpose of administering necessary treatment. The owner of the animal shall be liable to reimburse the county for all costs of such treatment. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-11; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-11. - Vicious animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious animal on the streets or public places of the county, or to allow the animal to run on the premises of another at any time, unless, and in addition to, the other requirements of this article, such animal shall be securely muzzled to effectively prevent such animal from biting any person or animal. Upon impounding a vicious animal for any reason, if the owner of such vicious animal seeks to reclaim such animal, the animal care and control division may, for reasons of public safety, retain such animal until disposition of all matters relating to the animal and the violations of this chapter by a court of appropriate jurisdiction. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-12; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-12. - Public nuisance animal. 
(a)  A "public nuisance animal" means and includes any animal that meets any of the following criteria: 
(1)  Is repeatedly found running at-large. 
(2)  Is found on the property or damages the property of any person other than its owner or keeper without the express consent of such other owner or the occupant of said other property. 
(3)  Attacks a person or another animal without provocation or acts in a vicious manner so as to menace any person or other animal. 
(4)  Excessively makes disturbing noises, including, but not limited to, continued and repeated howling, barking, whining or other utterances causing unreasonable annoyance, disturbance or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept. 
(5)  Creates unsanitary conditions or offensive and objectionable odors in enclosures or surroundings, and thereby creates unreasonable annoyances or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept. 
(6)  Is being kept in violation of the county zoning ordinance, chapter 90 of this Code. 
(b)  No person shall be charged with violating subsection (c) of this section on the basis of the animal being a public nuisance animal pursuant to subsection (a)(4) of this section unless written warning has previously been issued by an officer authorized to enforce provisions of the Code within 90 days of the charged violation and there are at least two complaining witnesses who shall have signed a written statement stating the address of the animal owner, a description of the animal, the circumstances causing the violation and the date, time and location of the violation. An animal shall not be deemed a public nuisance animal pursuant to subsection (a)(4) of this section, if at the time a person is trespassing upon the property upon which the animal is kept or any person is on the land adjacent to that on which the animal is kept and is intentionally trying to incite the animal and cause it to make noise or a disturbance. 
(c)  It is a violation of this section for any person to maintain or keep an animal in such a manner or in such conditions that it is a public nuisance animal or otherwise allow an animal owned or maintained by it to be a public nuisance animal. 
(d)  A public nuisance animal may be impounded and the owner or keeper of such animal may be charged with a violation of this section and shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9 of the Code. Each day that a violation of this section continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-13; Ord. No. 03-13, § 1, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 04-10, § 1, 12-7-2004) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 34-31 et seq. 
Sec. 14-13. - Dead animals. 
An employee of the animal care and control division or any other county employee may remove dead animals from public property. Carcasses of animals on private property must be disposed of by the animal or property owner or possessor in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq. Any dog, cat or small animal carcass to be picked up for disposal by the animal care and control division from a private residence must first be contained in a plastic bag and delivered to the right-of-way of the road or street for disposal. A pickup fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk will be charged. All dead livestock, including horses, cattle and any other large animal, must be disposed of by the animal owner, property owner or possessor thereof in accordance with state and local regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-14; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 70. 
Sec. 14-14. - Livestock; tying of animals. 
(a)  All livestock shall be properly housed with an adequate food and water supply, and confined within a fenced enclosure. 
(b)  No person shall tie, stake or fasten any animal within any street, highway, road, alley, sidewalk, right-of-way or other public place. Without the express permission of the property owner, no person shall tie, stake or fasten any animal so that the animal could cross any property limits or boundaries. 
(c)  No person shall walk or ride any livestock within any public street, highway, road, alley, sidewalk, right-of-way or other public place within the Evans Town Center Overlay District as part of a parade or other permitted event in which said right-of-way is closed to vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-15; Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 14-15. - Impoundment of biting animals. 
(a)  In accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the county board of health, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, an animal known to have bitten a person shall be confined in the county kennel or shelter for a period of ten days. All expenses incurred for boarding of such animal for such ten-day period, including reclamation fees as set forth in section 14-9, shall be paid by the owner or possessor of such biting animal. 
(b)  In accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the state department of health, all pets or wild animals known to have bitten a person, which cannot reasonably be held for a rabies observation period, shall be euthanized and a lab specimen of brain tissue sent to the state department of epidemiology for testing and control of rabies. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-16) 
Sec. 14-16. - Adoption. 
(a)  The animal care and control division or its designee may offer any animal for adoption that has not been reclaimed by its owner within five days after the impoundment of such animal, or shall immediately offer such animal for adoption if the animal is voluntarily surrendered to the animal care and control division by its owner. All persons adopting animals shall be over 18 years of age, and shall provide proper and humane care, feeding, shelter and protection from the weather, and veterinary treatment as required. It will be strongly recommended by the animal care and control division staff that all persons adopting a fertile dog or cat shall cause to have a female spayed or a male neutered within 30 days after the date of adoption, or by the maximum age of six months for a female and nine months for a male, whichever is longer. Such action will assist in reducing the animal population in the county. Any person adopting an animal shall not use the animal for breeding, exhibition or profit, and shall not engage in any research involving the use of the animal or supply the animal to any individual or institution which may use the animal in research. The frequency with which animals may be adopted and placed in any household may be restricted in the discretion of the animal care and control division manager. 
(b)  Adoptions fees may be set by the board of commissioners from time to time and shall be set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. In addition, the board of commissioners may require that all or part of the costs of examination, rabies inoculation, neutering or spaying be paid by the adopting party. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-17; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-17. - Vaccinations. 
(a)  All dogs and cats owned, possessed, harbored or residing within the county shall be inoculated for the prevention of rabies by a veterinarian licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the state, using only those vaccines prescribed and/or approved by the state department of human resources. 
(b)  All dogs and cats shall be vaccinated against rabies at three months of age. All dogs and cats shall be revaccinated within 12, 24 or 36 months as specified by the type of vaccine used. Any dog or cat found not to be vaccinated by three months of age must have consent of a licensed veterinarian stating the reason why such dog or cat should not be vaccinated. 
(c)  Any person keeping, owning, harboring or having any other type of animal, excluding dogs and cats, is not required to have the animal vaccinated against rabies unless required by the laws of this state, but such failure to have such animal vaccinated is at the risk of such person. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-18) 
Sec. 14-18. - Vaccination to be done only by licensed veterinarian. 
No person shall vaccinate a dog or cat against rabies who is not licensed to practice veterinary medicine in the state. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-19) 
Sec. 14-19. - Collar and vaccination tag. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each dog and cat owner, possessor or custodian to provide a collar and valid vaccination and identification tag, label or impression showing the name and address of the owner of such dog or cat. The collar and tag shall be worn by the animal at all times when such animal is not under the immediate control of the owner or possessor of the animal. In addition, any other animal required by the laws of the state to be inoculated or vaccinated shall have attached to the collar a valid vaccination tag. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attach a vaccination or owner's license tag to the collar of any animal for which such tag was not issued, or to remove such tag from any animal without the consent of such animal's owner, possessor or custodian. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-20) 
Sec. 14-20. - Certificate of vaccination. 
Upon administering an antirabies vaccine, a certificate of vaccination shall be issued and signed by the veterinarian administering such vaccine, to provide evidence of vaccination. One copy of the certificate shall be delivered to the animal's owner and a copy of the certificate shall be retained by the veterinarian administering such vaccine. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-21) 
Sec. 14-21. - Transient dogs and cats. 
Any dog or cat shipped or transported through the county or entering the county only for the purpose of a temporary stay, when such stay shall not exceed 30 days, shall be exempt from the collar and tag requirements of this article. However, all other provisions of this article are applicable to such transient animal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-22) 
Sec. 14-22. - Interpretation of rules and regulations. 
All rules and regulations concerning the inoculation of animals shall be interpreted by the county board of health. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-23) 
Sec. 14-23. - Summons. 
(a)  An animal control officer, at his discretion, upon finding what he reasonably believes to be a violation of this chapter, is authorized to issue a summons directing the owner, possessor or custodian of the animal in violation of this article to appear before the magistrate court of the county on a certain day to stand trial for such violation. 
(b)  If a violation of this chapter has not been personally witnessed by an animal control officer or an authorized representative or other employee of the county, a subpoena may be issued to the person complaining to be and appear on the day and time set for trial to testify on behalf of the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-24) 
Sec. 14-24. - Liability. 
The county and the animal care and control division and its commissioners, officers and employees shall not be responsible or liable for any accident, disease, injury or death to any animal while such animal is being impounded or boarded at the county kennel or shelter. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-25; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-25. - Interference with animal control officers/animal traps. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to interfere with any animal control officer or other officer empowered to act by law, or to take or attempt to take any animal from the county vehicle used to transport such animal, or to take or attempt to take any animal from the county kennel or shelter or impounding area. 
(b)  A citizen of Columbia County, Georgia, may borrow an animal trap from animal services provided such citizen abides with all relevant rules and regulations, including but not limited to those regulations related to times to set the trap, duration of the use of the trap, and the provision of adequate care for the animal until it is collected by an Columbia County Animal Services officer. Any citizen borrowing an animal trap is responsible for the cost to replace the same if it is stolen, damaged, or lost, regardless of fault by the citizen. The clerk of the county commission's office shall maintain a schedule of costs for the replacement of animal traps. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-26; Ord. No. 15-02, § 1, 3-17-2015) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 15-02, adopted March 17, 2015, changed the title of § 14-25 from "Interference with animal control officers" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 14-26. - Violation; penalty. 
Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. Each day that a violation of this article continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-27; Ord. No. 00-10, § 4(a), 10-3-2000) 
Sec. 14-27. - Adoption of ordinance by municipalities within the county. 
Any municipality in the county may adopt this chapter. If adopted by a municipality, all people owning animals in such incorporated areas may buy permits from the animal care and control division, and will receive the same services as those who live in the unincorporated areas. However, for the incorporated areas, the municipal ordinances must provide that the license fees shall be retained by the county to defray the cost of operation of the animal care and control division and further authorize the enforcement of the municipal ordinances by the animal care and control division. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-28; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Secs. 14-28—14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOG CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 

Sec. 14-61. - Designation of animal control officers. 
The manager of the animal care and control division and his designees shall be designated as animal control officers as provided in section 14-1. With the consent of the county sheriff, a deputy may be designated as an animal control officer. A person carrying out the duties of an animal control officer shall not be authorized to make arrests unless the person is a law enforcement officer having the powers of arrest. The manager of the animal care and control division shall be designated as the individual to carry out the duties of a dog control officer as provided by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22, with all of the power and authority set out therefor. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-29; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-62. - Hearings. 
The animal care and control advisory board shall hear and determine all matters provided for in section 14-64 or O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24. No member of the advisory board may participate in a hearing on any matter in which such member previously participated in the classification of the dog at issue. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-30; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-63. - Investigations by animal control officer; notice of classification. 
(a)  Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the county, an animal control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(b)  When an animal control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or reclassifies a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, the animal control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification, in writing, by certified mail, as specified in section 14-64, mailed to the owner's last known address. Such notice shall be complete upon its mailing. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-31) 
Sec. 14-64. - Procedures for classification; notice; hearing. 
(a)  As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this article against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  When a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, the animal control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification, which notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address; 
(2)  Include a summary of the animal control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; 
(3)  State that the dog has been classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog pursuant to this article and/or O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; 
(4)  Be dated and state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the animal control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; 
(5)  State that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the advisory board; 
(6)  State that if a hearing is not requested, the animal control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this article on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and 
(7)  Include a form to request a hearing before the advisory board, and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the advisory board. 
(c)  When the advisory board receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The advisory board shall notify the dog owner in writing, by certified mail, of the date, time and place of the hearing, and such notice shall be mailed to the dog's owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence, and in addition thereto, the advisory board shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the advisory board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify or overrule the animal control officer's classification of the dog as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. 
(d)  Within ten days after the holding of the hearing, the advisory board shall notify the dog owner in writing, by certified mail, of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which such determination is effective. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-32) 
Sec. 14-65. - Requirements for possession. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the county a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration. 
(b)  Subject to the additional requirements of subsection (c) of this section for dangerous dogs, the animal care and control division shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents the animal care and control division with evidence of, or the animal care and control division otherwise finds sufficient evidence that, the dog is being kept in facilities and according to the procedures set forth in section 14-6(c)(1) and O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25(b). 
(c)  In addition to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the animal care and control division, within three business days after the advisory board's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog becomes effective, evidence of a: 
(1)  Policy of insurance in the amount of at least $50,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by such dog, which insurance shall be kept in force at all times that the owner is maintaining the dangerous dog in the county; or 
(2)  Surety bond in the amount of at least $50,000.00 issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in the state, payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog, which surety bond shall remain in effect at all times that the dangerous dog is maintained in the county. 
(d)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the animal care and control division immediately upon discovery that the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the animal care and control division with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. 
(e)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the animal care and control division if the dog is removed from the county. The owner of a dog which has been declared a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in another jurisdiction which is brought into this county shall register the dog as required in this section within 30 days after the dog is brought into the county. 
(f)  Issuance or renewal of a certificate of registration by the county does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance if the initial certificate of registration or following the date of the annual renewal of such certificate. 
(g)  The animal care and control division is authorized to make any inquiry it deems necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. The county sheriff shall cooperate with the animal care and control division in enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(h)  The animal care and control division shall charge a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk, per year, for registration of dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs. Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of the annual renewal of a certificate of registration, an animal control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper pen or kennel, and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-33; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-66. - Restrictions on permitting dogs to be outside of proper pen or kennel. 
It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog to permit such dog to be outside a proper pen or kennel unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash which is no longer than six feet, and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. In addition, a dangerous dog shall be muzzled with a muzzle made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with the dog's vision or respiration, but will prevent the dog from biting any person. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-34) 
Sec. 14-67. - Impoundment; grounds; disposition. 
(a)  A dangerous dog may be impounded by an animal control officer, law enforcement officer or any other authorized person, if the: 
(1)  Owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by section 14-65(c); 
(2)  Dog is not validly registered as required by section 14-65; 
(3)  Dog is not maintained in a proper pen or kennel; or 
(4)  Dog is outside a proper pen or kennel in violation of section 14-66. 
(b)  A potentially dangerous dog may be impounded in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the potentially dangerous dog is: 
(1)  Not validly registered as required by section 14-65; 
(2)  Not maintained in a proper pen or kennel; or 
(3)  Outside a proper pen or kennel in violation of section 14-66. 
(c)  Any dog that has been impounded under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section may be reclaimed by the owner of such dog as provided in section 14-9, and upon providing evidence satisfactory to the manager of the animal care and control division or his designee that the dog will be maintained and handled in accordance with the requirements of this article. If the owner has not reclaimed the dog within five days after the dog was impounded, the dog may be disposed of in accordance with section 14-10. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-35) 
Sec. 14-68. - Violation; penalties; exception. 
(a)  The owner of a dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-65, 14-66 or 14-67 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature, and shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(b)  The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-65, 14-66 or 14-67 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(c)  If an owner who has a previous conviction for a violation of this article knowingly and willfully fails to comply with the provisions of this article, and the owner's dangerous dog attacks or bites a human being under circumstances constituting a violation of this article, the owner shall be subject penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(d)  In addition to the penalties for violations under subsection (c) of this section, the dangerous dog involved in such violation shall be immediately confiscated by the animal control officer, law enforcement officers or any person authorized by law, and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health. Thereafter, the dangerous dog shall be disposed of in an expeditious and humane manner. 
(e)  No owner of a dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this article for injuries inflicted by such owner's dog to any human being while on the owner's property, provided that the owner was complying, at the time, with all of the requirements of this article relating to the keeping of the dangerous dog on the owner's property. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-36) 
Secs. 14-69—14-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CRUELTY TO ANIMALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4. 

Sec. 14-101. - Abandonment. 
(a)  No person shall release any domesticated animal on any public or private property with the intention of abandoning the animal. 
(b)  No person shall intentionally abandon a dead animal on any private property belonging to another unless the person so doing shall have first obtained permission from the owner of the property on which the animal is being left. 
(c)  No person shall abandon a dead animal on any public property or public right-of-way unless the place on which the animal is being left is an approved sanitary landfill or other facility designed for receiving such animal, and has been designated by the board of commissioners as a public facility for receiving dead animals of the type being placed therein. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-37) 
Sec. 14-102. - Prohibited; exceptions. 
No person shall, by his act, omission or neglect, cause unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death to any living animal. This section shall not apply to the slaughter of animals for the purpose of providing food, nor shall it apply to any person who hunts wild animals in compliance with the game and fish laws of this state, nor shall it apply to killing or injuring an animal for humane purposes or in the furtherance of medical or scientific research. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-38(a)) 
Sec. 14-103. - Permitted acts. 
No person shall perform a cruel act on, harm, maim or kill any animal, or attempt to do so, except a person may: 
(1)  Defend his person or property or the person or property of another from injury or damage being caused by an animal; or 
(2)  Kill any animal causing injury or damage to livestock or poultry, unless prohibited by local, state or federal law. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-38(b)) 
Sec. 14-104. - Physical abuse. 
It is unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously kill; maim; disfigure; torture; beat with a stick, chain, club or other object; mutilate; burn or scald with any substance; drive over or otherwise cruelly set upon any animal, except that reasonable force may be employed to drive off vicious or trespassing animals, and a whip or stick may be reasonably, properly and humanely used in the legitimate training and using of an animal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-38(c)) 
Sec. 14-105. - Failure to care for and maintain. 
It is unlawful for any person to fail, refuse or neglect to provide an animal in his charge or custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink, shade, care or shelter, or to carry an animal in or upon any vehicle in a cruel or inhumane manner. Any animal habitually kept outside shall be provided with a structurally sound, weatherproof enclosure, large enough to accommodate the animal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-38(d)) 
Sec. 14-106. - Keeping diseased or crippled animal. 
It is unlawful for any person to have, keep or harbor an animal which is infected with any infectious disease that threatens the life or health of other animals or humans, or any incurable painfully crippling condition. The animal care and control division may impound such diseased or painfully crippled animal, and all such animals impounded may be disposed of as soon thereafter as conveniently possible in accordance with section 14-10. The animal care and control division shall not be required to give any notice of the disposition of such an animal. This section shall not be construed to include veterinary hospitals or animals under active veterinary care if such animals are properly quarantined. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-38(e); Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-107. - Authority of animal care and control division in case of animal neglect. 
Whenever the animal care and control division finds that any animal is or will be without proper care because of injury, illness, incarceration or other voluntary or involuntary absence of the owner or person responsible for the care of such animal, or because of the failure, refusal or neglect of the owner or person responsible for the care of such animal to provide proper care, the animal care and control division may impound such animal and handle the animal as any other impounded animal; and in the event of sickness or injury, the animal care and control division may take such action as called for to prevent undue pain and suffering of the animal, including immediate humane disposal of the animal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-38(f); Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-108. - Liability of county. 
In the enactment, operation and enforcement of this article, the county assumes no liability or responsibility for the enforcement or nonenforcement of this article, Neither the county, the advisory board or any commissioners, members, officers, agents or employees thereof shall be liable for injury or damage to any animal impounded as provided for in this article. By owning or maintaining animals in the county, the owner or possessor of each animal consents to the operation of an enforcement of this article. By operation and enforcement of this article, the county makes no representation upon which members of the public may rely for safety. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-40; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-109. - Violation; penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article or fails to comply with any requirements of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-39) 
Secs. 14-110—14-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STERILIZATION 

Sec. 14-136. - Policy. 
The breeding of dogs and cats acquired from public or private animal shelters, animal control agencies operated by the county, humane societies or public or private animal refuges in the county results in the birth of numerous animals who become strays, suffer privation and death, constitute a public nuisance and health hazard, and, ultimately, are impounded and destroyed at great public expense. It is therefor declared to be the public policy of the county that preventing the breeding of dogs and cats acquired from such shelters, agencies, societies or refuges be encouraged. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-41; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-137. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal shelter means any facility operated by or under contract for the county for the purpose of impounding or harboring seized, stray, homeless, abandoned or unwanted dogs, cats and other animals; any veterinarian which operates for such purpose in addition to his customary purposes; and any facility operated, owned or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society or other nonprofit organization for the purpose of providing for and promoting the welfare, protection and humane treatment of animals. 
Humane society means any unincorporated nonprofit organization existing for the purpose of prevention of cruelty to animals. 
Public or private animal refuge means harborers of unwanted animals of any breed, including crossbreeds, who provide food, shelter and confinement for a group of dogs, cats or a combination thereof. 
Sexually mature animal means any dog or cat that has reached the age of 180 days or six months, or more. 
Sterilization means the surgical removal of the reproductive organs of a dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-42) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-138. - Provisions required; responsibility for costs; proof. 
(a)  Any public or private animal shelter, animal care and control agency operated by a political subdivision of the county, humane society or public or private animal refuge shall make provisions for the sterilization of all dogs or cats acquired from such shelter, agency, society or refuge by: 
(1)  Providing sterilization by a licensed veterinarian before relinquishing custody of the animal; or 
(2)  Entering into a written agreement with the person acquiring such animal guaranteeing that sterilization will be performed by a licensed veterinarian within 30 days after acquisition of such animal in the case of an adult animal, or within 30 days of the sexual maturity of the animal in the case of an immature animal; provided, however, that the requirements of this section shall not apply to any privately owned animal which any such shelter, agency, society or refuge may have in its possession for any reason if the owner of such animal claims or presents evidence that such animal is the property of such person. 
(b)  All costs of sterilization pursuant to this section shall be the responsibility of the person acquiring such animal, and, if performed prior to acquisition, may be included in any fees charged by the shelter, agency, society or refuge for such animal. 
(c)  Any person acquiring an animal from a public or private animal shelter, animal care and control agency operated by a political subdivision of this county, humane society or public or private animal refuge, which animal is not sterile at the time of acquisition, shall submit to the such shelter, agency, society or refuge a signed statement from the licensed veterinarian performing the sterilization required by subsection (a)(2) of this section within seven days after such sterilization attesting that such sterilization has been performed. 
(d)  Every public or private animal shelter, animal care and control agency operated by a political subdivision of this county, humane society or public or private animal refuge selling or offering for sale or exchange any dog or cat, shall maintain and furnish to any person acquiring an animal from such shelter, agency, society or refuge a current list of veterinarians licensed in the state with offices in the county who have notified the shelter, agency, society or refuge that they are willing to perform sterilizations and the cost for such procedure. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-43; Ord. No. 07-13, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 14-139. - Violation; penalty. 
It shall be a misdemeanor to fail or refuse to comply with the requirements of this article, and any person convicted of such misdemeanor shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. Officials from the animal shelter shall have the authority to issue citations for failure to comply with this article and to impound animals who have failed to be sterilized in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-44; Ord. No. 00-10, § 4(b), 10-3-2000) 
Sec. 14-140. - Conflict with other ordinances. 
All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are repealed. 
(Code 1979, § 2-4-45)

(Code 1979, § 2-5-9)

Such officer or employee shall not engage in any work which is inconsistent with his duties or with the interests of the department. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-10)

Sec. 18-49. - Liability. 
Any officer, employee or member of a board charged with the enforcement of this chapter, acting for such board in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself liable personally, and he is relieved from all personal liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any officer or employee because of such act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of this chapter shall be defended by the county attorney until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-18) 
Sec. 18-50. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with the requirements thereof shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. The owner or tenant of any building, structure, premises or part thereof, and any architect, builder, contractor, agent or other person who commits, participates in, assists in or maintains such violation, may each be found guilty of a separate offense and suffer penalties provided in this subsection. 
(b)  In addition to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, it shall be the duty of the director to enforce the provisions of this chapter, including, but not being limited to, the right to refuse to issue, approve, sanction or certify any permit, license or certificate. In addition thereto, if any building, structure or other construction and improvements or work, subject to the provisions of this chapter, is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, converted, maintained or done, or any building, structure or work is or is proposed to be done or used in violation of this chapter, the director, board of commissioners or county attorney, or any adjacent or neighboring property owner who would be specially damaged by such violation, in addition to other remedies, may institute injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use, or to correct or abate such violation, or to prevent the occupancy of such building, structure or other construction and improvements. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-26) 
Sec. 18-51. - Conflict with other chapters. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall abrogate, modify, alter or change the requirements of any other chapter of this Code; provided, however, that if a conflict should exist between such other provisions and the provisions of this chapter, the more restrictive provision shall apply and be controlling. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-27)

ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 

Sec. 18-86. - Reserved.

Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-07, § 1, adopted June 21, 2005, repealed § 18-87 in its entirety. Former § 18-87 pertained to form and derived from Code 1979, § 2-5-19(b). 
Sec. 18-88. - Drawings and specifications. 
(a)  When required by the director, two or more copies of specifications and drawings drawn to scale, with sufficient clarity and detail to indicate the nature and character of the work, shall accompany each permit application under this article. Such drawings and specifications shall contain information, in the form of notes or otherwise, as to the quality of materials when quality is essential to conformity with this chapter. Such information shall be specific, and this chapter shall not be cited as a whole, or in part. The term "illegal," or its equivalent, shall not be used as a substitute for specific information on a permit application. 
(b)  The director may require details, computations, stress diagrams and other data necessary to describe the construction and basis of calculations, and such data shall bear the signature of the person responsible for the design thereof. 
(c)  All drawings, specifications and accompanying data shall bear the name and address of the designer. In the case of buildings or structures of group E-educational, group I-institutional and group A-assembly occupancy, and all buildings or structures three stories or more in height, or 5,000 square feet in area, except one-family and two-family dwellings, the designer shall be an architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of this state regulating the practice of architecture or engineering, and shall affix his official seal to such drawings, specifications and accompanying data. 
(d)  Plans for buildings and structures that require approval of the state fire marshal, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 92A-710, must bear the name and address of the designer, and the designer shall affix his official seal to such plans. 
(e)  Plans for all buildings shall indicate how required structural and fire-resistive integrity will be maintained where a penetration for electrical, mechanical, plumbing and communication conduits, pipes and systems shall be made; and shall also indicate, in sufficient detail, how the fire integrity will be maintained where required fire-resistive floors intersect the exterior walls. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-19(c)) 
Sec. 18-89. - Plat diagram. 
Upon application for a permit under this article, the director shall require drawings showing the location of proposed buildings or structures, and of every existing building or structure on the site or lot. He may also require a boundary line survey, if necessary, prepared by a professional engineer or registered land surveyor. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-19(d))

Sec. 18-93. - Contractor's tax, bond and liability insurance. 
It shall be the duty of every contractor, builder, electrician, plumber or mechanical contractor who shall make contracts for the erection, construction or repair of buildings, or any portion thereof, for which a permit is required under this article, and every contractor or builder making such contracts and subletting such contracts, or any part thereof, to do the following: 
(1)  Pay an occupation tax as provided in chapter 78, article V. 
(2)  Execute and deposit in the license and inspection department office a bond in the sum of $1,000.00, to be conditioned that all work performed by the contractor or under his supervision shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and other pertinent laws and ordinances. The contractor will pay all fees and penalties properly imposed upon him for violations of the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Place on file in the license and inspection department office a certificate of insurance for public liability and property damage for an amount not less than $50,000.00 for each person, and $100,000.00 for each occurrence. It shall be the responsibility of the contractor to notify the license and inspection office immediately upon cancellation of or change in public liability and property damage insurance. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-19(h))

(b)  Accurate records. The director shall keep a permanent and accurate accounting of all permit fees and other monies collected, the name of all persons upon whose account such fees or monies were paid, and the date and amounts thereof. 
(c)  Schedule of permit fees. On all buildings, structures, signs or alterations requiring a permit under this chapter, a fee for each permit shall be paid as required at the time of filing an application in an amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. 
(d)  Enactment of schedule of permit fees. The board of commissioners shall, from time to time, fix the fees to be charged for the permits set forth in this article. Such fees shall be enacted by resolution of the board of commissioners in open session and spread upon the minutes of the commission. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5-20)

ARTICLE VI. - NAMING AND RENAMING OF ROADS, STRUCTURES, AND FACILITIES, AND ALLOWING PLACEMENT OF MEMORIALS, MONUMENTS, SCULPTURES, PARK BENCHES AND WORKS OF ART ON COUNTY OWNED DESIGNATED PROPERTY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-07, § 1, adopted June 21, 2005, repealed Art. VI, §§ 18-202—18-241, in its entirety. Former Art. VI, §§ 18-202—18-241, pertained to flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures and derived from Code 1979, §§ 2-5-3.1—2-5-3.7.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 14-01, adopted July 1, 2014, enacted new provisions as herein set out. 

Sec. 18-236. - Purpose and administration. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to provide a uniform policy for naming and renaming roads, structures, and facilities within Columbia County, Georgia as well as ensuring ease of identification for law enforcement, fire, rescue, and emergency medical service personnel in Columbia County, Georgia. Secondarily, this article serves to establish standardization of identification to enhance county records of utility service, construction, permitting, licensing, and valuation. Finally, this article shall also provide a uniform policy for the establishment of memorials, monuments, sculptures, works of art, and park benches on county owned designated property. 
(b)  This article will be administered by the individual/individuals, who will be designated by the deputy county administrator, referred to herein as "agency." The agency will administer the naming and renaming of roads, structures, and facilities and the establishment of memorials, sculptures, works of art, and park benches on county owned designated property in accordance with the policies set forth herewith. The agency will also be responsible for maintaining an official record of this article. 
(c)  (1)  All roads that serve three or more structures or lots will be named regardless of whether the ownership is public or private. 
(2)  As used herein, a "road" refers to any highway, bridge, road, street, avenue, lane, private way, or similar paved, gravel, or dirt thoroughfare, and "property" refers to any property on which a structure has been erected or placed or may be lawfully erected or placed. 
(3)  A road name assigned by Columbia County will not constitute or imply acceptance of the road as a public way. 
(4)  Agency may solicit the involvement of those residents of affected neighborhoods in determining new or modified street names. 
(5)  No two roads will be given the same name or similar sounding name. 
(6)  Each road will have the same name throughout its entire length, when feasible, as determined by the agency. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-237. - Naming and procedures. 
(a)  Naming . 
(1)  New roads . 
a.  New road names submitted by a developer will be reviewed and approved during the plan review process. New road names being initiated by Columbia County will be considered at a scheduled committee meeting with final approval being considered by the board of commissioners. 
b.  New road names submitted by individual property owners or groups for naming a private easement, private road, private street, private avenue, private lane, private way, or similar private paved, gravel, or dirt thoroughfare will be considered by making application to the agency. Once the application is received, it will be scheduled for the next available committee meeting with final approval considered by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  Honorary road names . 
a.  Honorary road names submitted by an individual or group will be considered by making application to the agency. Once the application is received, it will be scheduled for the next available committee meeting with final approval considered by the board of commissioners. 
(3)  County owned buildings and facilities . 
a.  The naming of county owned buildings and facilities will be designated by the Columbia County Board of Commissioners by resolution adopted by majority vote. 
b.  County buildings or facilities being named or given a title will include but not be limited to buildings, areas in buildings, and recreational facilities. 
c.  Official names belonging to Columbia County, Georgia will remain the same unless changed by the board of commissioners upon relocation or change in function of the building or facility. 
d.  The naming of county owned buildings and facilities after individuals is discouraged with the following exception: 
1.  Deceased person(s) who brought honor to Columbia County, Georgia or made a significant monetary or other significant contribution to the development of the county, a county building, or a county facility will be considered. Such monetary gift shall at a minimum have represented 25 percent of the total county commitment of costs as established by the engineering services division. 
e.  The naming of a building or facility will be effective for the useful life of the building or facility so long as it is used for the purpose for which it was used at the time of the gift. At the end of the useful life of the building or facility and/or the cessation of the use in effect at the time of the gift, Columbia County, Georgia may rename the building or facility. 
(b)  Procedures . 
(1)  Roads . 
a.  The developer shall submit to the agency during the plan review process, the proposed road names to be utilized within the subdivision or commercial development. 
b.  Agency will notify the developer of the proposed names that are acceptable once the agency has reviewed the proposed names and cross checked them against the current county road index. 
c.  Agency will only allow the process to be re-initiated twice. If the resubmitted names by the developer are not approvable, agency reserves the right to select from a list of approvable names. The agency will provide a digital file of the official county road index to the developer upon request. 
(2)  Honorary road names . 
a.  Applicant shall consult with agency prior to submission of an application for a honorary road name for a road that is county or privately owned. 
b.  Applicant shall then submit a formal application for the honorary road name. Said application shall include the requested honorary road name and two alternate names accompanied by a petition signed by 100 percent of the affected property owners. 
c.  The applicant shall pay a non-refundable honorary road naming fee of $250.00 to the agency. Payment of this fee does not in any way guarantee that the honorary road name request will be approved. 
d.  Once the application is received, it will be scheduled for the next available committee meeting with final approval considered by the board of commissioners. 
e.  The committee will consider the honorary road name at its next regularly scheduled meeting and submit its recommendation to the board of commissioners for final decision. 
f.  After final decision of the board of commissioners, if approved, the agency will notify the affected property owners of the status of the honorary road name application. No addresses will be used utilizing the honorary road name. If disapproved, no further action will be taken by the agency. 
(3)  County owned buildings and facilities . 
a.  The naming of county owned buildings and facilities will be administered through the office of the county administrator. 
b.  Proposed name(s) may be submitted on a form provided by the agency. Said form shall provide a detailed background on the proposed name(s) and worthiness of the proposed change. 
c.  Suggested names will be presented in the form of a resolution to the next committee for consideration at its next available meeting. 
d.  The resolution will then be forwarded to the full board of commissioners for consideration. Said resolution will require two readings by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-238. - Renaming and procedures. 
(a)  Renaming —Is strongly discouraged due to safety and consistency issues and is seldom considered appropriate. However, renaming can be initiated by the county, private individuals, or groups. Road names shall be evaluated for historical significance and preservation of historical persons, places, and events prior to being considered for renaming. 
(1)  Roads (public or private) . 
a.  No county owned road or privately owned road shall be renamed except by action of the board of commissioners. 
b.  Renaming of county roads or private roads will only be considered if a determination is made that the change will result in a clear benefit to the property owners or the community. If it is determined that the change would result in a clear benefit to the property owners or the community, the applicant shall make formal application to the agency for consideration. This application shall require that 100 percent of the property owners possessing property that borders the public or private roadway must concur with the submission of the application and suggested road names (one primary and two alternates) via petition. Said application will be scheduled for the next available committee meeting with final approval being considered by the board of commissioners. If disapproved, the proposed change may not be reconsidered for one year. 
(2)  County owned buildings and facilities . 
a.  The renaming of county owned buildings and facilities will be designated by the Columbia County Board of Commissioners by resolution adopted by majority vote. 
b.  County buildings or facilities being renamed will include but not be limited to buildings, areas in buildings, and recreational facilities. 
c.  Officially named buildings and facilities belonging to Columbia County, Georgia will remain the same unless changed by the board of commissioners upon relocation or change in function of the building or facility. 
d.  The renaming of county owned buildings and facilities after individuals is discouraged with the following exception: 
1.  Deceased person(s) who brought honor to Columbia County, Georgia or made a significant monetary or other significant contribution to the development of the county, a county building, or a county facility will be considered. Such monetary gift shall at a minimum have represented 25 percent of the total county commitment of costs as established by the engineering services division. 
f.  The renaming of a building or facility will be effective for the useful life of the building or facility so long as it is used for the purpose for which it was used at the time of the gift. At the end of the useful life of the building or facility and/or the cessation of the use in effect at the time of the gift, Columbia County, Georgia may rename the building or facility. 
(b)  Procedures . 
(1)  Roads (initiated by individuals or groups) . 
a.  Applicant shall consult with agency prior to submission of an application to rename a road that is county or privately owned. 
b.  Applicant shall then submit a formal application for the road to be renamed. Said application shall include the requested road name and two alternate road names accompanied by a petition signed by 100 percent of the affected property owners. 
c.  The applicant shall pay a non-refundable road renaming fee of $250.00 to the agency. Payment of this fee does not in any way guarantee that the road renaming request will be approved. 
d.  Once the application is received, it will be scheduled for the next available committee meeting with final approval considered by the board of commissioners. 
e.  The committee will consider the road renaming at its next regularly scheduled meeting and submit its recommendation to the board of commissioners for final decision. 
f.  After final decision of the board of commissioners, if approved, the agency will notify the affected property owners of the name change and provide them with their new property address. If disapproved, no further action will be taken by the agency. 
(2)  County owned buildings and facilities . 
a.  The renaming of county owned buildings and facilities will be administered through the office of the county administrator. 
b.  Proposed names may be submitted on a form provided by the agency. Said form shall provide a detailed background on the proposed name(s) and worthiness of the proposed change. 
c.  Once the application is received, it will be scheduled for the next available committee meeting with final approval considered by the board of commissioners. 
d.  Suggested name will be presented in the form of a resolution to the committee for consideration at its next available meeting. 
e.  The resolution will then be forwarded to the full board of commissioners for consideration. Said resolution will require two readings by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-239. - Memorials, monuments, sculptures, park benches, and works of art ("collectively works of art"). 
(a)  Establishment . 
(1)  Memorials, monuments, sculptures, works of art (collectively "works of art"), and park benches . 
a.  Columbia County ("county") has made available county owned designated properties for the limited display of approved memorials, monuments, sculptures, works of art (collectively "works of art"), and park benches. 
(b)  Application . 
(1)  Applications for memorials, monuments, sculptures, works of art (collectively "works of art") shall be submitted to the monument and public arts committee through the community and leisure services division. 
(2)  Applications for park benches shall be submitted to the community events committee through the community and leisure services division. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-240. - Penalties for violations. 
Violations of this article shall be subject to penalties as outlined in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 14-01, 7-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-241. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PROPERTY NUMBERING[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-06, adopted Dec. 3, 2013, repealed the former Art. VII, §§ 18-242—18-244, and enacted a new Art. VII as set out herein. The former Art. VII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 2-5-51—2-5-53, adopted Dec. 19, 2000. Ord. No. 13-06 states "Violations of this article shall be subject to penalties as outlined in section 1-9 of this Code. 

Sec. 18-242. - Purpose and administration. 
(a)  The primary purpose of this article is to enable rapid response to citizens and location of properties by law enforcement, fire, rescue, and emergency medical service personnel in Columbia County. Secondarily, this article serves to establish standardization of structure numbering to enhance county records of utility service, construction, permitting, licensing, and valuation. 
(b)  This article shall be administered by the individual/individuals, who shall be designated by the deputy county administrator, referred to herein as the "agency". The designated agent shall assign property numbers in accordance with the criteria outlined in chapter 18, article VII of the Code of Ordinances of Columbia County, Georgia (the "Code"). The agency will be responsible for maintaining official records of this article including, but not limited to, an alphabetical list of all roads with properties, listed in order of their assigned numbers. 
(Ord. No. 13-06, 12-3-2013) 
Sec. 18-243. - System of numbering. 
(a)  All properties, lots, and parcels of land shall hereafter be identified by reference to the numbering system adopted herein, except that all existing number identification of buildings or lots or parcels not in conformity with this system shall be changed within (6) months from the adoption of this article so as to conform. 
(b)  The agency shall invite the involvement of the residents of affected areas in determining modified street numbers by public notice of such intent. However, nothing in this chapter shall be considered to usurp authority of the agency to make final decisions regarding the numbering system, numbers assigned, or compliance with this chapter without public involvement. 
(c)  Numbers shall be assigned along both sides of the road, with even numbers appearing on the left side of the road and odd numbers appearing on the right side of the road in the ascending direction. 
(d)  The following criteria shall govern the numbering system: 
(1)  All number origins shall begin from the intersection of the primary or secondary through or cross street. For dead-end roads or subdivision cul-de-sacs, numbering shall originate at the intersection of the adjacent road and terminate at the dead-end. 
(2)  The number assigned to the primary structure shall be the same number assigned to the real property in which the structure is situated. 
(3)  Every structure with more than one principle use or occupancy shall have a separate number for each use or occupancy. For example, duplexes will have two separate numbers. 
(4)  Apartments will have one property number followed by an apartment number based on the building number and apartment location within the building. For example, following the property number, building number one will be addressed with a one prefixing the apartment number, for example, 475 Belair Road, Apt. 101. 
(5)  On those streets accessed from either end, the property numbers shall originate from the end of the street carrying the greatest traffic volume. 
(6)  Notwithstanding the above, streets with the same name continuing into Columbia County from another municipality shall be numbered consistently based on beginning with the next consecutive number following the last number within the other municipality as feasible. 
(7)  Whenever any residence or other structure is constructed or developed, it shall be the responsibility of the new owner to obtain an assigned number from the agency. An assigned number shall be required prior to issuance of the building permit. In new subdivision developments, no numeric address shall be assigned prior to final plat approval by the Columbia County Planning Commission. Numbers shall be assigned and recorded on the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 13-06, 12-3-2013) 
Sec. 18-244. - Compliance. 
(a)  Numbers should be displayed as follows: 
(1)  For single family residential structures, numbers shall be posted using street line posting as described below. 
(2)  For multi-family residential structures, numbers shall be posted using structure posting as described below. 
(3)  For commercial structures, numbers shall be posted using both street line posting and structure posting. 
(b)  All owners of structures shall, within the time-frame stipulated herein, display and maintain the assigned numbers in a conspicuous place on or near said structure in the following manner: 
(1)  Street line posting: The assigned number shall be displayed on a post, fence, wall, mailbox, or on some other structure with an approximate height of four feet at the property line adjacent to the access drive of the numbered structure. The exact height and location of the posting may vary in order to ensure that the sign remains unobstructed from view. The posted numbers shall be visible from both directions on the road. 
(2)  Structure posting: The assigned number shall be displayed on the front of the structure within five feet of the front door and visible from the road where practical. 
(3)  Size and color of numbers: Properties used for residential purposes shall have posted numbers a minimum of three inches high. Commercial properties shall have posted numbers a minimum of four inches high. All numbers shall be a contrasting color to their background. Structure signs and mounting poles meeting these specifications are available for a fee from the Columbia County Fire and Rescue Division Headquarters. 
(4)  Any number aside from the assigned number shall be removed from the structure, mailbox, post or stanchion, to prevent confusion with the number assigned in conformance with this article. No person, agency, or business shall adopt, assign, display, or cite any number other than that assigned as provided herein for the purpose of designating location of property. 
(5)  In residential instances where the property is located on a private drive where more than one residence is located, the assigned number must be posted on the main road. It must also be posted adjacent to the access drive of the property using the street line posting. 
(6)  In situations where a property is located on a private drive and has more than one structure or a structure with more than one principle use or occupancy, numbers should be posted using the structure posting, in addition to the posting requirements of subsection (5), set forth above. 
(7)  The owner, occupant, or person in charge of any house or building to which a number is assigned or modified shall be notified in writing of that assignment at any time after adoption of this article. 
(8)  Notices provided herein shall seek to govern or regulate the placing of assigned numbers as prescribed by the United States Postal Service. 
(Ord. No. 13-06, 12-3-2013) 
Secs. 18-245, 18-246. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - REGISTRATION OF BUILDING CONTRACTORS AND BUILDING INSPECTORS 

Sec. 18-247. - Definitions.
