The intent of this article is the prevention of fraud, the prevention of crime, and the protection of residents' privacy through the reasonable regulation of solicitation activities. Enforcement of this article shall be limited to regulating commercial transactions and the solicitation of funds, and shall expressly exclude restricting solicitations for political campaigns, distribution of religious material, or to enlisting support for unpopular causes. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-129. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
County. The word "county" shall mean Columbia County, Georgia. 
Director. The word "director" shall mean the director of the development services division of the county, or such other county official as the board of commissioners may designate from time to time to carry out the functions of the director as set forth in this article. 
Peddler. A "peddler" is any person who has no permanent, regular place of business within the county; and who engages in the business of selling or offering to sell goods or services by going from place to place within the county, except a person selling agricultural products and holding a letter from a county agent certifying that the products were produced by that person. 
Permit. A "permit" is the right or privilege granted by the county to engage in business as a peddler within the county. Evidence that such right or privilege has been granted shall be in the form of a permit document issued by the board of commissioners, which document shall be kept on the peddler's person. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-130. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall operate a business as a peddler within the county unless a license for such business has first been granted by the county as outlined in this article. 
(b)  No solicitor for subscriptions shall solicit within the county unless a permit has been granted by the county in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Such permit shall be effective only for the period stated in the document unless suspended or revoked prior to expiration. 
(d)  Application for a permit shall be made on forms prescribed by the board of commissioners and shall provide such information as is required by this article and such additional information as may be necessary to define completely the activities to be conducted within the county. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-131. - Application for peddler's license. 
(a)  An application containing the following information shall be completed and filed with the board of commissioners by each applicant for a license under this article: 
(1)  Name of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(3)  Local address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(4)  The applicant's date of birth and age, if an individual; 
(5)  The applicant's Social Security number or federal employer identification number; 
(6)  If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name and home address of each partner, principal, or corporate officer; 
(7)  If the applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; 
(8)  If the applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name, home address, date of birth, age and Social Security number of the principal representative in the county; 
(9)  Name and home address of all employees to work in the county; 
(10)  Name of business represented by the applicant, if different from the applicant; 
(11)  Permanent address of the business represented by applicant; 
(12)  Name of agent conducting sale; if any; 
(13)  Local address and telephone number of sales agent, if any; 
(14)  Type of merchandise or service to be offered for sale; 
(15)  Place where business is to be conducted; 
(16)  Date to be in business and total number of days to be in business; 
(17)  Hours during which business will be conducted; 
(18)  Manner in which business to be conducted; 
(19)  Georgia sales tax number of authorization; 
(20)  State and license tag number of each vehicle to be used in the business; 
(21)  List of cities where business has been conducted by the applicant within the last 12 months. 
(b)  Failure to pay the license, administrative and investigative fees, if any, at the time of filing the application, or failure to furnish all information as required by the application form and/or this article, will cause the application to be deemed incomplete and no action will be taken thereon until such application is complete. All application shall be sworn to by the applicant before a notary public or other officer empowered by law to administer oaths. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-132. - Approval procedures. 
(a)  An application for a license under this article shall be presented to the development services director or designated staff within 45 days after the date such application is deemed complete. 
(b)  Upon approval of the application the license shall be issued. 
(c)  If the application is denied, the development services director shall set forth the reasons for such denial. 
(d)  Any license granted under this article shall expire no later than December 31 of the year issued. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-133. - Display of permit. 
A permit shall, at all times, be kept plainly exposed to public view at the premises for which the license was granted and/or on the person engaging in the activity requiring the permit. The permit shall include a color photo of the natural person applicant. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-134. - Transferability. 
No permit under this article shall be transferable. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-135. - Fees. 
Any peddler as defined by this article shall pay a permit fee of $20.00 per day up to a maximum fee of $100.00 for any one period of continuous business operation within the city during a calendar year. In any case where a higher permit fee is required by another article, the higher fee shall apply. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-136. - Registered agent required. 
Any peddler shall identify a registered agent for service of process in his permit application. Such registered agent shall be a resident of Columbia County and shall be an agent of such peddler upon whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law to be served upon the peddler may be served in the same manner provided by law for the service of a summons or complaint. Said registered agent shall agree in writing to act as such agent, and a copy of the agreement shall be filed with the permit application. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-137. - Exception; Georgia corporations and registered corporations. 
(a)  No applicant which is a corporation, and which submits evidence that the corporation is chartered by the State of Georgia, shall be required to secure a registered agent within Columbia County. 
(b)  No applicant which is a corporation chartered outside the State of Georgia, and which submits evidence that the corporation is currently registered with the secretary of state of the State of Georgia, shall be required to secure a registered agent within Columbia County. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-138. - Hours of operation. 
Any peddler shall provide in writing to the licensing and permits office the hours of operation of the business. No permit under this article shall operate any such activity business except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-139. - Inspection required. 
The Columbia County Sheriff's Office, and authorized agents or employees designated by Columbia County shall be authorized from time to time to make inspections during regular business hours of each business issued a permit under this article, for the purpose of determining that the provisions of this article, are fully complied with. It shall be unlawful for any permittee under this article to fail to allow such county officers and officials access to the premises or to hinder the officer or official in any manner. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-140. - Violation; penalties. 
(a)  Any violation of the provisions of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the board of commissioners may revoke or suspend a permit for violation of this article, which shall be a distinct and separate penalty. Any violation of this article, or any failure to comply with the requirements of this article, shall be grounds for immediate suspension or revocation of any and all permits held by the permittee regardless of the number of permits or locations involved, and regardless of whether or not the permittee knew of or contributed to such violation. It is the intent of this subsection, without limiting the generality thereof, to grant to the board of commissioners the right to suspend or revoke any and all permits held by a permittee when any violation of this article occurs at any place of business operated by the permittee pursuant to a license. 
( Ord. No. 18-11, § 1(Exh. A), 7-9-2018 ) 
ARTICLE VIII. - BUSINESS LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-10 , adopted July 9, 2018, enacted provisions to be designated as art. I, §§ 22-1—22-27. In order to maintain the categorical standards of the Code, said new provisions have been designated as art. VIII, §§ 22-141—22-167. Original section numbers have been maintained in the history notes following each section. 

Sec. 22-141. - Business license required. 
In addition to remitting those occupational taxes due pursuant to Section 78, Article 5 of this Code of Ordinances, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in Columbia County, Georgia, shall apply for a business license for said business, trade, profession, or occupation; which license and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in Columbia County, Georgia. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in Columbia County, Georgia, such business registration shall be shown to the licensing official or representatives thereof, or to any law enforcement officer of said Columbia County upon request. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-1), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-142. - Construction of terms; definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the term "Columbia County" is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean Columbia County, Georgia; wherever the term "county" is used herein, it shall be construed to mean Columbia County, Georgia. Wherever the term "business" is used herein such term shall be construed to mean a business, trade, profession or occupation or practitioner thereof unless otherwise indicated. 
(b)  As used in this article, the term: 
(1)  Business license means a license issued following a registration with and fee paid to Columbia County prior to conducting or transacting business within Columbia County. For the purposes of this article, the term "business license" shall be a type of "regulatory fees." 
(2)  Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. 
(3)  Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the county. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Regulatory fees do not include development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development. 
(4)  Person shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofit, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations. 
(5)  Practitioner of profession or occupation is the one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation, but shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays a regulatory fee. 
(6)  Clerk means the clerk of the board of commissioners of Columbia County. 
(7)  Licensing official means the county administrator or his designee. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-2), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-143. - Qualifications for business license. 
In order to obtain a business license under this article, the applicant must satisfy the following requirements: 
(a)  A license will be issued only to a person who is a citizen of the United States or an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States. Where an applicant is other than a natural person, it must be an entity organized and existing under the laws of the United States or one of its states, an agent of the entity must meet the qualifications set forth herein. 
(1)  Where the applicant for a license is an entity other than a natural person, the application shall be made jointly in the name of the entity and an officer having authority to bind the entity. Said entity shall be registered to do business in the State of Georgia. 
(2)  Licenses issued to entities must be issued jointly to the entity and all of the other persons required by this section to join in the application. All respective partners, officers, directors, or members, as applicable, shall be responsible for the actions of the named licensee and the conduct of the licensed business. 
(b)  The applicant must be at least 18 years of age. 
(c)  No person shall be granted a business license unless it shall appear to the licensing official that the requirements herein have been satisfied. In the case of partnerships, corporations, limited partnerships, limited liability partnerships, limited liability companies or other business entities, a license shall not be issued to the partnership, corporation, limited partnership, limited liability partnership, limited liability company or other entity if any partner, officer, director, shareholder, member or other person required to be listed on the application cannot meet the requirements set forth in this subsection. 
(d)  Reserved. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-3), 7-9-2018 ; Ord. No. 19-01, § 1, 2-19-2019 ) 
Sec. 22-144. - Application for business license. 
(a)  A person desiring to obtain a business license under this article shall make application to the licensing official on the forms prescribed by the Columbia County Board of Commissioners. 
(b)  The application for a business license shall require, but shall not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of each applicant. 
(2)  The name and location of the proposed business and the name and address of the owner of the premises in which the business is to be carried on. 
(3)  Certification from the county tax commissioner that all taxes then due to the county by the applicant have been paid. 
(c)  Failure to pay the associated fees at the time of filing the application, or failure to furnish all information as required by an application form, will cause the application to be deemed to be incomplete and no action will be taken thereon until such application is complete. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-4), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-145. - Application approval procedures. 
Upon receipt of the completed application the licensing official shall review the application to determine: 
(1)  Whether the applicant gave false or misleading information or omitted material facts during the application process. 
(2)  Whether the applicant is delinquent in payment to the county for any taxes or fees past due. 
Upon such findings and determinations of full compliance, the licensing official shall approve the application. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-5), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-146. - Regulatory fee structure. 
(a)  A regulatory fee may be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on applicable businesses, trades, professions and occupations. 
(b)  The regulatory fee schedule or schedules for persons in businesses, trades, professions, and occupations as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 or other provisions of Georgia law shall be adopted by the Columbia County Board of Commissioners and shall be amended from time to time. Said regulatory fee schedule shall be posted in the Columbia County Administration Office and at the building, planning and development office. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-6), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-147. - Purpose and scope of fee. 
This article is adopted pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-8 and 48-13-9 and is for regulatory purposes only. This article is not adopted as an occupational tax. 
(1)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one regulatory fee for each of its locations. 
(2)  A business with multiple locations in the county will not be assessed more than $200.00 for their business license for all their locations combined. 
(3)  No business license or regulatory fee shall be required for those businesses and practitioners of professions or occupations which Columbia County is not authorized to subject to regulatory fees pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c). 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-7), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-148. - Paying regulatory fee of business with no location in Columbia County, Georgia. 
A business license shall also be required on those businesses, trades and practitioners of professions or occupations which operate and conduct business within Columbia County even if said business, trade, profession or occupation does not have a location within Columbia County. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-8), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-149. - The number of businesses considered to be operating in the county. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of this article. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-9), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-150. - Imposition of fee. 
The regulatory fee imposed herein is for regulatory purposes only. Said fee shall be paid before commencing a business, trade or the practice of a profession or occupation as a condition precedent for transacting business or practicing a profession. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-10), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-151. - When fee due and payable; effect of transacting business when fee delinquent. 
Each such regulatory fee shall be for the calendar year 2018 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Said registration and fee shall be payable before commencing business and thereafter on January 1 of each year once the business has commenced and has received its initial license, and be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in this article. Should any regulatory fee imposed by this article remain due and unpaid for 90 days from the due date of the fee, unless otherwise exempted by state law or local ordinance, the person liable for the fee shall be subject to and shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the fee due. In addition, interest on the regulatory fee due and payable after the due date shall be lesser of one and one-half percent per month or the highest rate allowed by law. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-11), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-152. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. 
No business on which a business license is imposed by this article shall be exempt from the fees required herein on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless said business is registered as a charitable nonprofit organization pursuant to the Internal Revenue Code. In such case, said business shall only be required to register with Columbia County and the fee shall be waived. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-12), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-153. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the Secretary of State pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the county registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-13), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-154. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a county business license, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-14), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-155. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
Every person commencing business in the county after January 31 of each year shall likewise obtain the business license and registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in the county, any business, trade, profession, or occupation required to be registered without first having so obtained said registration, shall be subject to penalties provided therefor. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-1), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-156. - When registration and fee due and payable; effect of transacting business when fee delinquent. 
(a)  Each such registration shall be for the calendar year in which the registration was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. There is hereby imposed a penalty upon each business which fails to apply for and obtain an appropriate business registration and pay all fees as provided herein before January 31 of each year, and on January 31 each year hereafter. 
(b)  The registration herein provided for shall be issued by the licensing official, and if any person, firm or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after said fee becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the county, any of the kind of business, trade, profession, or occupation without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall be subject to the penalties provided therefor. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-16), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-157. - Penalty of ordinance violation. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances of Columbia County. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-17), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-158. - Revocation or suspension of business license. 
(a)  Any business license granted under this article shall be subject to revocation or suspension for cause. Whenever, in the opinion of the licensing official, there is cause to revoke or suspend a license a written notice of intention to revoke or suspend a license shall be furnished to the holder thereof not less than ten days before the meeting of the licensing official, at which time the holder of the business license may make such showing as he may deem proper. After a hearing, the licensing official may revoke or suspend the license if, in its discretion, it is in the best interest of peace, good order and the general welfare of the county, or there has been any violation of the ordinances of the county or of the laws of the United States or the state in the conduct of the ownership or operation of a business which is required to obtain a business license. 
(b)  Cause for revocation or suspension shall include, but not be limited to, the following actions by the business license holder: 
(1)  Providing false or forged information to the licensing official in obtaining a business license under this article. 
(2)  Impersonating a business license holder. 
(3)  Using or attempting to use a business license that has expired or been revoked. 
(4)  Violation of any provision of this article. 
(c)  Any grounds for revocation or suspension shall also be grounds for denial of the initial application or renewal of application. 
(d)  The denial, suspension or revocation under this article shall entitle the person applying for or holding the business license to a hearing before the Columbia County Board of Commissioners within 45 days after receipt by the county of written notice of appeal. A notice of appeal pursuant to this subsection must be delivered to the clerk of the Columbia County Commission within 30 days of the denial, suspension or revocation. Any person aggrieved by a decision or order of the county, after exhausting his administrative remedies, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the Superior Court of Columbia County. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-18), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-159. - Businesses not covered by this article. 
(a)  The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed a regulatory fee, registration fee, or other type of regulation pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the State of Georgia or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under chapter 3 of O.C.G.A. title 46. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-3-8 et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the State of Georgia governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(11)  Any other business exempt from the provisions of this article, pursuant to state law. 
(b)  The following persons or businesses are exempted from the regulatory fee imposed by this article: 
(1)  Nonprofit social, charitable, religious or fraternal organizations for the purpose of operating fairs, circuses or carnivals for periods of time not to exceed one week. 
(2)  Individual farmers who raise, grow or cultivate edible food from the soil of the state provided, however, that farm, milk or other farmer cooperatives are not exempted when they engage in selling goods and/or services to the public in competition with persons taxed by virtue of this article. 
(3)  Established churches, religious, charitable and fraternal organizations chartered or operated for nonprofit purposes. 
(4)  Persons exempted from taxation by virtue of the constitution or any statute of the United States or State of Georgia. Such persons shall possess and display at their places of business a certificate of exemption that may be obtained from the licensing official by application of a form provided by the same. The applicant for exemption shall clearly state the provision of this article or other provision of law under which the applicant claims exemption. The certificate shall contain sufficient facts for the licensing official to determine whether the applicant is entitled to the exemption. The certificate of exemption shall remain valid and the business need not reapply for an annual certificate of exemption so long as the conditions entitling the business to the exemption remain the same. The application for the certificate of exemption shall be made under oath. The certificate of exemption shall not exempt any business from complying with the duty to register. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-19), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-160. - Amendment, repeal of provision. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-20), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-161. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore adopted where fees imposed under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of any ordinance heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in said ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such regulatory fee, registration fee or assessment shall be fully paid. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-21), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-162. - Enforcement of provisions. 
It is hereby made the duty of the licensing official to see that the provisions of this article relating to business licenses are observed; and to summon all violators of the same to appear before the court of competent jurisdiction. It is hereby made the further duty of the licensing official to inspect all registrations issued by the county, as often, as in his or her judgment, he or she may deem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-22), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-163. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the Columbia County Board of Commissioners. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-23), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-164. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-24), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-165. - Conditions of issuance. 
The licensing official shall issue the certificate of license only: 
(1)  When satisfied that the business, etc., does not, and will not violate the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the county; 
(2)  Upon the fulfillment of the registration requirements of this article; and 
(3)  Upon the payment of the regulatory fee imposed by the ordinance. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-25), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-166. - Term of certificate or license; transfer. 
Licenses will be issued for a one-year period; however, all licenses expire on December 31, regardless of the date of issuance. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-26), 7-9-2018 ) 
Sec. 22-167. - Misrepresentation deemed violation. 
No person shall use any deceitful means or misrepresentation in obtaining the license or certificate to do business in the county from Columbia County. 
( Ord. No. 18-10, § 1(Exh. A, § 22-27), 7-9-2018 )

ARTICLE II. - COMMUNITY ANTENNA TELEVISION SYSTEMS 

Sec. 26-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Basic service means and consists of the retransmission of television broadcasting station signals, a local origination channel, weather and news channels and any other channels which form the basic service package from time to time being provided by any grantee of cable or video franchises issued by the county or the State of Georgia in the area of its franchise operation in the county for which a charge is made to the subscriber. 
Basic service revenue means the amount of revenue collected from the subscribers for the provision of basic service. 
Community antenna television system , referred to in this article as "CATV system," "cable system" or "system, " means a system for the transmission of audio and/or video and/or data signals by coaxial cable or fiber optic networks, or other means, and such related services as the state of the art permits and a grantee chooses to provide. Such services include, but are not limited to, basic service and premium service. 
County means Columbia County, Georgia. 
County engineer means the county engineer of Columbia County, Georgia. 
Franchise means the term applied to this article following adoption by the board of commissioners and acceptance by the grantee, or following adoption by the State of Georgia and acceptance by the grantee. 
Grantee means any holder of a franchise issued by the county or the State of Georgia. 
Person means a person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, or organization of any kind. 
Premium service means any future services such as motion pictures, shopping services, sporting events and the transmission of such other electronic service information or data as may become technically and economically feasible, and for which service a charge is made to the subscriber. 
Shall means mandatory and not merely directory. 
Subscriber means a person who purchases a service offered by the CATV system. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-1; Ord. No. 14-02, § 1, 2-4-2014) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-32. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 14-02, adopted Feb. 4, 2014, repealed former § 26-32 which pertained to grant of authority, and derived from the 1979 Code, § 2-5.5-2; and Ord. No. 05-03, adopted March 15, 2005. 
Sec. 26-33. - Compliance with applicable laws and ordinances. 
The grantee shall, at all times during the life of this franchise, be subject to the lawful exercise of the police power of the county, and to such reasonable regulations as the county shall provide. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-3) 
Sec. 26-34. - Liability and indemnification. 
By its acceptance of this franchise, the grantee agrees that it will pay all damages and penalties which the county may legally be required to pay as a result of granting this franchise, including the cost of defending any legal action against the county arising out of the installation, operation or maintenance of the CATV system authorized in this article, whether or not any such act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this franchise. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-4) 
Sec. 26-35. - Operation and maintenance of system. 
The grantee shall install such equipment and have the necessary equipment and personnel to maintain its facilities in order to ensure efficient service, and it shall have the necessary equipment and personnel to promptly make repairs, and service shall be interrupted only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-5) 
Sec. 26-36. - Safety requirements. 
(a)  The grantee shall, at all times, employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damages, injuries or nuisances to the public. 
(b)  The grantee shall install and maintain its wires, cables, fixtures and other equipment in accordance with the requirements of chapter 18, and in such a manner so as not to interfere with any existing installations of the county or of a public utility serving the county. 
(c)  All structures, lines, equipment and connections in, over, under and upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys and public ways or places of the county, wherever situated or located, shall, at all times, be kept and maintained in a safe, suitable and substantial condition, and in good order and repair. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-6; Ord. of 11-1-1983) 
Sec. 26-37. - Conditions of street occupancy. 
(a)  All transmission and distribution structure lines and equipment erected by the grantee within the unincorporated areas of the county shall be located so as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys and other public ways and places, and with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin such streets, alleys or other public ways and places. 
(b)  In case of disturbance of any street, sidewalk, alley, public way or paved area, the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the county engineer, replace and restore such street, sidewalk, alley, public way or paved area in as good a condition as before the work involving such disturbance was commenced. 
(c)  The grantee shall have the authority to trim trees upon any street, alley, sidewalk, public way and place of the unincorporated areas of the county so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires, cables or other equipment of the grantee. 
(d)  If at any time during the period of this franchise, the board of commissioners shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade of any street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, the grantee, upon reasonable notice by the board of commissioners, shall relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes and other fixtures at its own expense. 
(e)  In all unincorporated areas of the county where the cables, wires or other like facilities of public utilities are placed underground, the grantee shall place its cables, wires or other like facilities underground to the maximum extent that existing technology reasonably permits the grantee to do so. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-7) 
Sec. 26-38. - Erection, removal and common user of poles. 
No poles or other wire-holding structures shall be erected by the grantee without prior approval of the county engineer with regard to location, height, type and any other pertinent aspect. Any pole or wire-holding structure of the grantee shall be moved or modified by the grantee, at its own expense, upon reasonable notice, whenever the board of commissioners has determined that the public convenience would be enhanced by such action. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-8) 
Sec. 26-39. - Removal of facilities. 
The grantee, upon termination by any subscriber of the grantee's services, shall promptly remove all of its facilities and equipment from the premises of a subscriber upon the subscriber's written request. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-9) 
Sec. 26-40. - Payment to county by holders of franchises issued by county or by the State of Georgia. 
All holders of cable or video franchises issued by the county shall pay to county the same maximum franchise fee allowed by law for cable or video franchises issued by the State of Georgia, which as of the adoption of this section is five percent of gross revenues received from the provision of cable or video services generated in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-10; Ord. No. 14-02, § 3, 2-4-2014) 
Editor's note— Section 3 of Ord. No. 14-02, adopted Feb. 4, 2014, changed the title of § 26-40 from "Payment to county" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 26-41. - Subscriber charge. 
The charges for services offered to the public by the grantee shall be fair and reasonable. Prior to any rate change or adjustment, the grantee shall give notice to the board of commissioners. The grantee shall file with the board of commissioners, or the State of Georgia as the case may be, a schedule of the rates and charges for its basic CATV services offered to the public. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-11; Ord. No. 14-02, § 4, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-42. - County rights in franchise. 
(a)  With regard to a franchise issued by the county, the right is reserved to the board of commissioners to adopt, in addition to the provisions contained in this section and in existing applicable ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of its police power, provided that such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise, shall be reasonable and not in conflict with the rights granted in this section. 
(b)  At any time during normal business hours, the board of commissioners shall have the right to inspect and the grantee shall make available its books, records, maps, plans and/or other like materials of the grantee pertaining to the operation of the CATV system, provided that seven days' notice shall have been given to the grantee as to what records are to be produced for such inspection. 
(c)  During the term of each franchise issued by the county, the board of commissioners shall have the right to install and maintain, free of charge, upon the poles of the CATV system, any wire or pole fixtures necessary for a police alarm system, on the condition that such wire and pole fixtures do not interfere with the operations of the grantee. 
(d)  The board of commissioners shall have the right to hold a public or private hearing on any matter pertaining to each franchise issued by the county, and the grantee shall make available its representatives or agents for such hearing. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-12; Ord. No. 14-02, § 5, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-43. - Maps, plats and reports. 
(a)  On or before March 1 of each year each grantee shall file with the clerk of the board of commissioners true and accurate maps or plats of CATV trunk and feeder lines within the unincorporated areas of the county as of December 31 of the preceding year. 
(b)  Each grantee shall annually file with the clerk, no later than 60 days after the end of its fiscal year, a sworn statement of the number of subscribers to its basic CATV system service residing within the unincorporated areas of the county, the revenues from the operation thereof upon which the payment to the county is based and a computation of the franchises fee due to the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-13; Ord. No. 14-02, § 6, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-44. - Cancellation of franchise. 
(a)  With regard to each franchise issued by the county, the board of commissioners reserves the right to terminate and cancel the franchise and all rights and privileges of the grantee under the franchise if the grantee: 
(1)  Fails to make the payments to the county as provided in section 26-40 for a period of more than 180 days, unless the county shall have granted a waiver of timely payment. 
(2)  Becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged as bankrupt. 
(3)  Willfully violates any of the provisions of the franchise. 
(b)  Termination and cancellation as provided in this section shall be by ordinance duly adopted after 90 days' notice to the grantee, and shall in no way affect any of the county's rights under this franchise or any provisions of law. If such termination and cancellation depends upon a finding of fact, such finding of fact shall be made by the board of commissioners; provided, however, that before this franchise may be terminated and cancelled, the grantee shall be provided with an opportunity to be heard, to present evidence before the board of commissioners and to appeal such proposed cancellation to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  The termination or cancellation of a franchise shall give the county no vested interest in the business or property of the grantee, and the grantee shall have a reasonable period of time to dismantle its equipment in the event of such cancellation or termination. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-14; Ord. No. 14-02, § 7, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-45. - Duration and acceptance of franchise. 
A franchise issued by the county and granted to the grantee to operate a CATV system in the unincorporated area of the county shall take effect and be in force on the dates agreed to by the county as grantee and set forth in the franchise agreement. If the termination date of the franchise shall occur but no action is taken to extend or end its term, the duration of the franchise shall continue on a month to month basis until terminated. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-15; Ord. No. 14-02, § 8, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-46. - Transferability. 
The grantee shall not assign or transfer its franchise issued by the county to another person unless the resultant successor to the grantee shall have a net worth of not less than $1,000,000.00. The board of commissioners shall be notified 30 days prior to any proposed transfer of the franchise, and shall be provided with reasonable evidence of the financial qualifications of the proposed transferee to operate the CATV system in the public interest. Prior to the effective date of the assignment, the assignee shall execute and deliver to the county an agreement to abide by and operate the franchise in accordance with all of the provisions of this article, which shall be in a form and of substance approved by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-16; Ord. No. 14-02, § 9, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-47. - Compliance with other regulations. 
Notwithstanding the terms of a franchise, the grantee shall not be required to operate in violation of any rule or regulation of the Federal Communications Commission or any federal or state laws which may be adopted. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-17; Ord. No. 14-02, § 10, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-48. - Services offered in addition to CATV services. 
The franchises granted under the terms of this article shall entitle each of the grantees to use its CATV system to offer services other than basic service, premium service or any other service that would be considered part of cable television services, which its CATV system is capable of providing, including, by way of example and not limitation, Internet access and services, telephone services, security services, energy management, high speed data transmission and wholesale transport and local loop services. If such additional services are offered, the county reserves the right, by amendment of this section or the adoption of additional ordinances, to impose additional franchise fees for the providing of such services to the extent the county is legally authorized to do so. Prior to imposing such additional franchise fees, the county will notify any grantee which would be affected thereby and give it an opportunity to be heard on the matter by the board of commissioners. If any such additional franchise fees are imposed for the providing of services in addition to CATV services, similar fees shall also be charged to any other provider of the same service who is not a CATV service provider, but who uses county property similar to the way the grantee uses county property to provide the service. Before imposing any such additional franchise fees, the board of commissioners shall make a finding that the additional franchise fees are reasonable and are being equitably charged to those providing the service and making similar use of county property. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.5-19; Ord. No. 14-02, § 11, 2-4-2014) 
Sec. 26-49. - Payment to county by holders of franchises issued by the State of Georgia. 
All holders of cable or video franchises issued by the State of Georgia shall pay to county the maximum franchise fee allowed by law, which as of the adoption of this ordinance [from which this section is derived] is five percent of gross revenues received from the provision of cable or video services generated in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Ord. No. 14-02, § 12, 2-4-2014) 
Chapter 30 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
State Law reference— Georgia Mutual Aid Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-69-1 et seq.; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1—30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISASTERS OR STATES OF EMERGENCY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
State of emergency is as defined by O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(5), and means a condition declared by the governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency or energy emergency is of sufficient severity and magnitude as to warrant extraordinary efforts in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-2(3)(b)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 30-32—30-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SUSPENSION OF PORTIONS OF THIS CODE AND OTHER FORMALITIES 

Sec. 30-56. - Purpose. 
The health, safety and welfare of the citizens and property of the county may be jeopardized during an emergency, disaster or the subsequent recovery period by the inability of the board of commissioners to act expediently without regard to certain formalities. The board of commissioners is authorized pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 38-3-27(b) and 38-3-28 to take actions necessary to provide for the health and safety of persons and property during periods of emergency or disaster, provided that such actions are not inconsistent with any orders, rules or regulations promulgated by the governor of the state or his delegate. The powers and functions exercised by the board of commissioners necessary to conduct the business and affairs of the county during an emergency or disaster proclaimed as such by the appropriate state official may continue without regard to compliance with time consuming procedures and formalities pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-54. In accordance with O.C.G.A. §§ 36-10-4(c)(5) and 32-4-63(6), certain formalities concerning public works contracts may be waived when necessitated by an emergency. The board of commissioners believes that it is desirable to have legislation in place authorizing the board of commissioners to waive certain formalities and procedures, as necessary, in case of an emergency, natural disaster or the subsequent recovery period. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(1)) 
Sec. 30-57. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fee means any fee or rate charged by the county for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and clean up of areas impacted by a disaster or emergency. This term shall not include those fees collected by the county on behalf of the federal or state government, or those fees charged by the county pursuant to a federal or state statute or regulation. 
Subsequent recovery period means the period of time that a disaster or emergency continues to cause disruptions in the area impacted by the disaster or emergency, which period of time shall not exceed six months after the state of emergency declaration by the governor is terminated unless extended by official action of the board of commissioners. 
Temporary dwelling means any mobile or easily movable home, trailer, recreational vehicle or structure not otherwise permitted by the zoning regulations in a particular zoning district. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(3)(a), (c), (d)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-58. - Meetings. 
Upon proclamation by the appropriate state official of an emergency or disaster of manmade or natural causes or enemy attack impending on or affecting the state or the United States, the affairs and business of the county may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual place thereof, within or outside of the county, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the county, all actions taken by the board of commissioners shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the county. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two members of the board of commissioners without regard to or compliance with time consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(2)(a)) 
Sec. 30-59. - Purchasing and public works contracts. 
Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the appropriate state official, or upon the determination by the board of commissioners or its designee of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the board of commissioners, its designee or the emergency interim successor may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder, and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four weeks; provided, however, that any public works contract entered into pursuant to this section shall be entered on the minutes of the board of commissioners as soon as practical, and the nature of the emergency described therein. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(2)(b)) 
Sec. 30-60. - Code enforcement. 
Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the appropriate state official, or upon the determination by the board of commissioners or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the board of commissioners, its designee or the emergency interim successor may temporarily suspend the enforcement of this Code, or any portion thereof, where: 
(1)  The emergency or disaster is of such a nature that immediate action outside this Code is required; 
(2)  Such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare; and 
(3)  Such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(2)(c)) 
Sec. 30-61. - Fees. 
Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor, or upon the determination by the board of commissioners or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the board of commissioners, its designee or the emergency interim successor may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures, as necessary, to encourage the rebuilding of the area impacted by the disaster or emergency. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(2)(d)) 
Sec. 30-62. - Temporary dwellings. 
Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the appropriate state official, or upon the determination by the board of commissioners or its designee, of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the board of commissioners, its designee or the emergency interim successor may authorize temporary mobile homes, trailers, recreational vehicles or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district while the primary dwelling is being repaired, provided that such temporary dwellings or parks are designed by an engineer and the plans are approved by the county health department and the county engineering and environmental services division. The temporary permit shall not exceed six months in duration. In the case of continuing hardship and in the discretion of the board of commissioners or its designee, the permit may be extended for an additional period of six months. Upon expiration of the temporary permit or an extension, the temporary dwelling shall be removed. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-1(2)(e)) 
Secs. 30-63—30-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CURFEWS 

Sec. 30-86. - Purpose. 
The health, safety and welfare of the people and property in the county may be jeopardized during an emergency, disaster or imminent threat thereof, by the presence of looters, vandals, thieves and others who would take advantage of the confusion and devastation that accompanies such an event. The board of commissioners is authorized pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 38-3-27(b)(2) and 38-3-28 to take any action necessary to provide for the health and safety of persons and property during periods of emergency or disaster, provided that such actions are not inconsistent with any orders, rules or regulations promulgated by the governor or his delegate. The board of commissioners believes that it is desirable to have legislation in place authorizing the board of commissioners to enact a curfew when it is determined necessary to maintain order and to protect either the people or property during an emergency or disaster in all or certain areas of the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-2(1)) 
Sec. 30-87. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Curfew means a regulation requiring the withdrawal of any person not otherwise exempt from this division from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. 
Exempt individuals, unless otherwise specified in the resolution implementing the curfew, means and includes those individuals engaged in the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, emergency medical services and hospital services, military services, and utility emergency repairs. The resolution may, in the discretion of the board of commissioners, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, news media employees, building and repair contractors, properly registered according to section 30-113, performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-2(3)(a), (b)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-88. - Institution of curfew. 
(a)  Upon the declaration of a state of emergency by the governor or other appropriate state official, or upon the determination by the board of commissioners or its designee of the existence of an emergency or disaster, the board of commissioners, its designee or the emergency interim successor may adopt a resolution instituting a curfew when it is determined necessary to protect and safeguard the people and property in the county. 
(b)  All unincorporated areas of the county shall be subject to the terms of the curfew, unless otherwise specified in the resolution. 
(c)  The resolution instituting the curfew shall include the dates and hours that the curfew shall be in effect. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-2(2)) 
Sec. 30-89. - Prohibition. 
It shall be prohibited for any person, other than exempt individuals, to appear in public in the territory subject to the curfew, including, but not limited to, streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, vacant lots, parks, public buildings or any other public places, in all or a delineated part of the unincorporated areas of the county, during the stated hours of the curfew. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-2(4)) 
Sec. 30-90. - Violation; penalties. 
Any individual violating the provisions of this division, upon conviction, shall be subject to penalties and costs as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-2(5)) 
Secs. 30-91—30-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REGISTRATION OF BUILDING AND REPAIR SERVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 18. 

Sec. 30-111. - Purpose. 
During and following periods of emergency resulting from natural or manmade disaster, the public is at risk from unscrupulous building contractors and repair services, scams and other unconscionable activities related to constructing, repairing, renovating and making improvements to buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster. Registration of building construction and repair contractors during a declared emergency, which is authorized pursuant to the police powers of the county and O.C.G.A. §§ 38-3-28 and 38-3-56, will provide a means to protect the public from unscrupulous building and repair contractors. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(1)) 
Sec. 30-112. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building contractor means any person engaging in, undertaking or carrying on any business consisting of or relating to building construction, repair, renovation or making improvements to real property including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures attached thereto. 
Doing business means, any building contractor who: 
(1)  Has or operates an office, agency, project site or place of business located in the unincorporated areas of the county, whether permanently, temporarily, periodically or otherwise, that provides the following activities, which include, but are not limited to, the: 
a.  Construction, renovation or repair of dwellings or buildings; or 
b.  Making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto. 
(2)  Performs the following activities or services in the unincorporated areas of the county expressly, which include, but are not limited to, the: 
a.  Construction, renovation or repair of dwellings or buildings; or 
b.  Making of improvements to real property or any fixtures attached thereto regardless of the location of the principal office. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which a disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed three months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the governor. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(3)(a), (b), (d)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-113. - Registration of building contractors. 
During a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period, no person shall engage in, undertake or carry on any business, in whole or in part, within the unincorporated areas of the county, consisting of or relating to building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures attached thereto, without having registered with the board of commissioners the name of the business and identifying the individuals who directly or indirectly own the business, and having paid fees as provided by section 30-115. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(2)) 
Sec. 30-114. - Certification of building contractors. 
All building contractors doing business or proposing to do business in the unincorporated areas of the county during a state of emergency or the subsequent recovery period, shall register and file applications with the clerk of the board of commissioners or such other person designated by the board of commissioners at the county offices or such other place designated by the board of commissioners. The building contractor shall, under oath, provide the board of commissioners with a statement describing the general nature of the business to be conducted, and give true and correct information as may be called for on the registration form, application or certificate provided by the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(4)) 
Sec. 30-115. - Fees. 
Building contractor registration fees under the terms and conditions of this division shall be fixed by the board of commissioners and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. Registration fees shall be paid in full at the time of issuance of the registration certification. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(5)) 
Sec. 30-116. - Display of registration certification. 
Each certification issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted by the building contractor in his place of business, or shall be carried on his person or vehicle used in such business. Such certification shall be exhibited to any authorized enforcement officer when so requested. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(8)) 
Sec. 30-117. - Transferability. 
Each certification issued under this division is granted to, and shall be accepted by, the building contractor under the condition that such certification is not transferable, and after issuance of such certification, no such certification shall be transferred by the county or the building contractor to another individual or entity. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(7)) 
Sec. 30-118. - Revocation; suspension. 
Each certification granted under this division is a mere permit to engage in the business only as long as such business is conducted in a lawful manner. The board of commissioners reserves the right to revoke or suspend any certification granted under this division if the building contractor or his agent or employee acting within the scope of his employment, violates this division or any other county, state or federal law. If, after issuance of a certification under this division, the county desires to revoke such certification, written notice thereof shall be given to the building contractor, which notice shall specify the violation with which the building contractor is charged and a date, time and place at which a hearing shall be held with regard to the violation. The building contractor shall have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing, and shall have the right to be represented by counsel and to introduce and submit evidence in opposition to such revocation. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(9)) 
Sec. 30-119. - Violation; penalties. 
Any building contractor required by this division to pay a registration fee, who engages in business without first registering and receiving a registration certification from the county as required in this division, shall be in violation of this section. Violation of this section, upon conviction, shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. Each day a building contractor does business in the unincorporated areas of the county without complying with this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-3(6)) 
Secs. 30-120—30-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OVERCHARGING FOR GOODS, MATERIALS, SERVICES AND HOUSING 

Sec. 30-141. - Purpose. 
The health, safety and welfare of the people in the county depend upon the availability and affordability of certain essential goods, materials, services and housing. During certain periods of emergency resulting from a natural or manmade disaster, people in the county are at risk from dramatic and unjustified increases in the prices of such goods, materials, services and housing. Such increases in price may be excessive and unconscionable during a state of emergency and may hinder the ability of the county to recover from the disaster. Legislation is necessary to prohibit any person from raising prices for goods, materials, services and housing to excessive, unconscionable or unfair levels during a declared state of emergency or subsequent recovery period. Limitations on price overcharging during a declared state of emergency is authorized pursuant to the police powers of the county and O.C.G.A. § 38-3-28. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-4(1)) 
Sec. 30-142. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Overcharging means charging prices for goods, materials, services or housing which are substantially in excess of the customary charges, or in applicable cases, substantially in excess of the supplier's or provider's costs for such goods, materials, services or housing. The existence of overcharging shall be presumed from a substantial increase in the price at which the goods, materials, services or housing was offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency, but shall not include increases in costs to the supplier directly attributable to higher costs of materials, supplies and labor resulting from the emergency. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which a disaster continues to cause disruptions in the disaster area, but shall not exceed six months after the emergency declaration has been terminated by the governor unless such period is extended by official action of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-4(4)(a), (c)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-143. - Prohibited. 
In order to preserve, protect or sustain the life, health or safety of persons or property in the county, it shall be unlawful during the duration of a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period in which the county has been designated as a disaster area, for any person located or doing business in county to overcharge for any goods, materials, services or housing sold within the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-4(2)) 
Sec. 30-144. - Violation; penalties. 
Violation of this provisions of this division, upon conviction, shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-5.7-4(4)) 
DIVISION 6. - COST RECOVERY 

Sec. 30-145. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of section, the following words or phrases shall have the meanings below: 
Hazardous material shall mean hazardous waste, substances or materials as defined by any federal, state, county or local statute, law, ordinances or codes relating to human and environmental protection. 
Incident shall mean a response by Columbia County Fire Rescue involving a release or discharge of hazardous material. 
Release or discharge shall mean any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, seeping, dumping or disposing into the environment. 
Responsible party shall mean any individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, commercial entity, joint venture, governmental entity, company or any other legal entity that is, in whole or in part, the cause of an actual or threatened release or discharge of hazardous material or is an owner, tenant occupant or party in control of property receiving any benefit, services or equipment provided by Columbia County in response to an incident. When the service rendered by Columbia County directly benefits more than one person, entity or property, each owner, tenant, occupant or party in control of each property so benefited shall be a responsible party. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 1(Exh. A), 10-7-2014) 
Sec. 30-146. - List of services provided. 
A detailed listing of hazardous material response services provided to persons, entities and or agencies will be compiled by Columbia County Fire Rescue. This information shall be forwarded to the Columbia County Risk Management Department, which shall be responsible for the billing. This information shall include: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner, lessee, occupant and/or responsible party(s); 
(2)  Date, time and location of the incident; 
(3)  Any and all incident report or case numbers from responding emergency services; 
(4)  Description of services rendered; and 
(5)  Itemized list of all costs. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 1(Exh. A), 10-7-2014) 
Sec. 30-147. - Applicable recovery charges. 
The applicable recovery charges for service shall begin upon arrival of the first responding unit and shall include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  All personnel costs, including wages, salaries, fringe benefits and insurance, at actual hourly rate per hour, per person for on-duty response and actual over-time rates per hour for off-duty response; 
(2)  Costs for loss, consumption, repair and decontamination of equipment, vehicles, instruments, clothing, supplies and other items, at actual replacement cost; 
(3)  Subsistence supplies, at actual cost; 
(4)  Miscellaneous expenses, at actual cost; 
(5)  Equipment charges shall include, but are not limited to, each fire engine, ladder truck, rescue unit, hazardous material unit and all equipment and apparatus needed by the fire department and other county departments required to respond, and shall be charged based on the then current Federal Emergency Management Agency Schedule of Equipment Rates for like or similar equipment. 
(6)  A charge for billing and processing of two percent of the total cost will be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 1(Exh. A), 10-7-2014) 
Sec. 30-148. - Allocation of funds. 
All funds received from persons, entities or agencies that have been billed for services will be allocated by the Columbia County Risk Manager to each county department from which the expenditures were incurred for personnel costs, decontamination, repair, replacement and purchase of items of both durable and consumable categories. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 1(Exh. A), 10-7-2014)

ARTICLE I. - GRADING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-17 , § 1(Exh. A), adopted June 7, 2016, repealed the former art. I and enacted a new art. I as set out herein. The former art. I pertained to trees and derived from Ord. No. 10-05, § 2(Exh. A), adopted June 1, 2010, Ord. No. 12-05, § 1(Exh. A), adopted May 15, 2012. 

Sec. 34-1. - Major site grading. 
(a)  Intent . The intent of this section is to provide guidance for the responsible design and development of land, while allowing the flexibility to develop sites with unique topographical or design features that require more extensive grading than a typical development. 
(b)  Purpose . The purpose of this section is to: 
(1)  Allow for development of planned developments with creative and imaginative design features that are compatible with the area, but that may require more extensive grading than a typical development; 
(2)  Ensure that the development of land maintains consistency with the county's comprehensive plan and all subsequent amendments and updates; 
(3)  Protect the character and integrity of development within the county; 
(4)  Provide for the effective development of public facilities and services for the site; and 
(5)  Encourage efficient use of land for preservation of sensitive environmental and cultural resources, such as open space areas, waterways, wetlands, and topographic features. 
(c)  Applicability . This section shall apply to all land disturbing activity beyond the minimum necessary to construct roads and related structures, best management practices for managing stormwater, stock pile staging areas, and material storage areas. Land disturbing activity required to construct individual residential or non-residential buildings on individual building lots, as well as land disturbing activity required to construct non-residential or multi-family developments, is exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(d)  Design requirements . 
(1)  For sites intended for residential development, a natural, undisturbed buffer with a minimum width of 50 feet shall be maintained along the exterior boundary of a site affected by major site grading. Effective protective measures shall be employed to ensure that the buffer remains undisturbed during construction. For sites smaller than ten acres, buffer requirements shall follow those required by section 90-139 of the Code. An alternate buffer plan for boundaries adjacent to rights-of-way may be approved by the planning commission as part of preliminary plat approval, provided that the alternate plan does not eliminate the undisturbed buffer completely and meets the intent of the overall buffering requirements of this section. 
(2)  In addition to the requirements of section 90-141 pertaining to tree protection, street trees shall be provided and maintained within, or adjacent to, all existing and proposed street rights-of-way in accordance with the following requirements: 
a.  Street trees shall be planted at a spacing of 40 feet on-center for shade trees or 20 feet on-center for ornamental and understory trees along the entire length of the street frontage of the proposed development or as approved by the administrator based on the development plans. Ornamental and understory trees shall be used as street trees only when there is an overhead obstacle which would preclude the use of taller-growing shade trees. A list of acceptable street trees is available in section 90-145. 
b.  Street trees shall be planted in a minimum six-foot wide tree lawn between the curb and sidewalk, and shall be planted no closer than three feet from the curb or sidewalk. The planning services director may approve an alternate planting plan to avoid conflicts with utilities. 
c.  Street trees shall include only those trees listed in the approved list of tree species in section 90-145, unless use of an alternative species is approved by the planning services director. 
d.  Street trees shall be located and planted in a manner that minimizes conflicts with underground and above-ground utility lines and easements. 
e.  A street tree planting plan shall be included with the development plan, and shall detail species, placement, size, number of trees, and the party responsible for perpetual maintenance. 
f.  Street trees shall be installed prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the building to which the street trees closest relate. 
(3)  A geotechnical/soils report prepared by a qualified geotechnical engineer shall be submitted with an application for a land disturbance permit and shall include the following information: 
a.  Site conditions, including site topography, and vegetation. 
b.  Engineering characteristics of the subsurface material together with laboratory test results to at least 24 inches below proposed grades or to refusal. 
c.  Depth to groundwater if present within 24 inches of proposed grades. 
d.  Conclusions as to the adequacy of the soils of the site for the proposed grading and recommendations of any corrective procedures, if required. 
e.  Foundation and pavement design criteria. Pavement design criteria shall meet a minimum of eight inches of compacted GAB, two inches of compacted asphalt binder course, and one and one-half inches of compacted surface course. 
f.  Site drainage and groundwater management recommendations. 
(4)  Excavation requirements. 
a.  Cut slopes shall not be steeper than two horizontal to one vertical (2H:1V), for slopes steeper than 2H:1V, a slope stability report must be approved by Columbia County. Slopes shall be stabilized in accordance with GSWCC standards. 
b.  Cut slopes shall not exceed 20 feet in height unless horizontal benches with a minimum width of six feet are installed. Horizontal benches shall have proper drainage conveyance. 
c.  All cut slopes greater than 6H:1V shall be located on one parcel. The top of a cut slope shall be no closer than one foot plus 50 percent of the height of the slope to an adjacent property line or environmentally sensitive area but no less than five feet. 
d.  Subdrains shall be provided under any curb and gutter on public roadways of excavation greater than four feet. 
(5)  Fill requirements. 
a.  Fill slopes shall not be steeper than two horizontal to one vertical (2H:1V), for slopes steeper than 2H:1V, a slope stability report must be approved by Columbia County. Slopes shall be stabilized in accordance with GSWCC standards. 
b.  Fill slopes shall not exceed 20 feet in height unless horizontal benches with a minimum width of six feet are installed. Horizontal benches shall have property drainage conveyance. 
c.  All fill slopes greater than 6H:1V shall be located on one parcel. The toe of a fill slope shall be no closer than one foot plus 50 percent the height of the slope to an adjacent property line or environmentally sensitive area but no less than five feet. 
d.  All fills greater than ten feet shall be placed, compacted, inspected and tested in accordance with the following provisions. All monitoring and testing shall be performed by a qualified soil testing agency engaged by the developer. 
1.  Preparation of ground. The existing ground surface shall be prepared to receive fill by removing vegetation, noncomplying fill, and other incompetent material. Where the slope of the existing ground surface is SH:1V or steeper, the fill shall be supported on level benches cut into competent material. The bench under the toe of a fill on a slope steeper than 5H:1V shall be at least ten feet wide.
