Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, corporation, including a municipal corporation, trust or non-profit entity that employs the services of one or more individual persons. 
Enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling that is enclosed on all sides by solid walls or windows (exclusive of doorways), which extend from the floor to the ceiling. 
Health care facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals or other clinics, including weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. Including all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within health care facilities. 
Place of employment means an enclosed area under the control of a public or private employer that employees normally frequent during the course of employment, including but not limited to, work areas, employee lounges, restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias, hallways, and vehicles. A private residence is not a "place of employment" unless it is used as a child care, adult day care, or health care facility. 
Public place means an enclosed area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including but not limited to, banks, educational facilities, health care facilities, hotels and motels, laundromats, poling places, public transportation facilities, reception areas, restaurants, retail food production and marketing establishments, retail service establishments, retail stores, shopping malls, theaters, and waiting rooms. A private residence is not a "public place" unless it is used as a childcare, adult day care, or health care facility. 
Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests or employees, as well as kitchen and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. The term "restaurant" shall include an attached bar. 
Retail tobacco store means a retail store which derives not less than 85 percent of its gross revenues from the sale of tobacco products and accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. 
Service line means an indoor line in which one or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not the service involves the exchange of money. 
Shopping mall means an enclosed public walkway or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional establishments. 
Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, weed, plant, or other combustible substance in any manner or in any form. 
Sports arena means sports pavilions, stadiums, gymnasiums, health spas, boxing arenas, swimming pools, roller and ice rinks, bowling alleys, and other buildings, structures or places where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise, participate in athletic competition, or witness sports or other events. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-69), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-82. - Public areas where smoking is prohibited. 
Smoking is prohibited in all public places and sports arenas within the unincorporated areas of Columbia County, including but not limited to, the following places: 
(1)  Aquariums, galleries, libraries, and museums. 
(2)  Areas available to and customarily used by the general public in the facilities of any business entity patronized by the public, including but not limited to reception areas, waiting rooms, rest rooms, hallways, lounges and display areas. 
(3)  Attached bars. 
(4)  Banks. 
(5)  Bingo facilities. 
(6)  Buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by Columbia County. 
(7)  Educational facilities. 
(8)  Convention facilities. 
(9)  Elevators. 
(10)  Facilities primarily used as theaters for exhibiting a motion picture, stage, drama, dance, lecture, musical recital, or other entertainment performances. 
(11)  Health care facilities. 
(12)  Hotels and motels except as otherwise provided in section 46-85(b). 
(13)  Laundromats. 
(14)  Licensed childcare and adult day care facilities. 
(15)  Lobbies, hallways, clubhouses, recreation rooms, meeting rooms and other common areas in apartment buildings and complexes, condominiums, trailer parks, retirement facilities, nursing homes, and other multiple-unit residential facilities. 
(16)  Polling places. 
(17)  Public transportation facilities, including busses and taxicabs, operating under the authority of Columbia County, and ticket, boarding and waiting areas of public transit depots. 
(18)  Restaurants, including attached bars. 
(19)  Retail stores, retail service establishments and retail food production and marketing establishments. 
(20)  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under the control of an agency, board, commission, committee or council of Columbia County or a political subdivision of the State of Georgia when a public meeting is in progress, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of Columbia County. 
(21)  Service lines. 
(22)  Shopping malls. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-70), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-83. - Prohibition of smoking in places of employment. 
(a)  Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed facilities within places of employment without exception including common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms, vehicles and all other enclosed facilities. 
(b)  The prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all present employees by the effective date of this article (January 1, 2005) and to all subsequent employees upon their application for employment. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-71), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-84. - Additional areas where smoking is prohibited. 
Smoking is prohibited within a distance of ten feet from any door which is used as an entrance to or exit from an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. This ten feet distance shall be measured from the center of the door in question. This distance requirement shall not apply to any door which has a properly operating vertical air curtain. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-72), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-85. - Smoking not prohibited. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 46-82 through 46-84, smoking is not prohibited in the following areas: 
(1)  Private residences, except when used as a licensed child care, adult day care, barbershop, beauty shop, personal care home or other health care facility. 
(2)  Hotel and motel rooms rented to guests and designated as smoking rooms; provided, however, that not more than 20 percent of guest rooms in a hotel or motel may be so designated. 
(3)  Retail tobacco stores provided that smoke from such stores does not infiltrate areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Outdoor areas of places of employment except those covered by the provisions of this section. 
(5)  Outdoor dining areas which may be covered by a roof but must be open on at least three sides. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-73), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-86. - Establishment of additional restricted areas. 
Notwithstanding any other provision in this article, an owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment, facility or outdoor area may declare the entire establishment, facility or outdoor area as a nonsmoking location. Smoking shall then be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to the requirements of section 46-87 is posted. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-74), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-87. - Posting of signs. 
(a)  "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in every public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this article, by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that place. 
(b)  Every public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this article shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  All ashtrays and other smoking paraphernalia shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this article by owner, operator, manger or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-75), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-88. - Nursing homes, long-term care facilities and assisted living facilities. 
Nursing homes, long term care facilities and assisted living facilities shall each adopt smoke free policies and enforce them subject to any restrictions or limitations thereon contained in the rules and regulations promulgated by the Georgia Office of Nursing Home Regulatory Services where applicable. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-76), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-89. - Nonretaliation. 
No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment or customer because that employee, applicant or customer exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-77), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-90. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Any nonprofit organization under the laws of the state of its organization which meets the criteria set forth in either (a) or (b) below, may apply to the board of commissioners for an exemption from this article: 
(1)  A private club which: 
a.  Has at least 75 regular dues-paying members who pay dues of at least $50.00 per year; 
b.  The membership in the club is limited in number and by specified membership criteria; 
c.  Is not open to the general public, but only to its members and their guests; 
d.  Substantially all of its activities are for the pleasure or recreation or other nonprofitable purposes of its members and it does not receive more than 35 percent of its gross revenues from sources outside of its membership; and 
e.  No part of its net earnings inures to the benefit of any for profit private entity or individual. 
(2)  A post or organization of past or present members of the Armed Forces of the United States; 
a.  At least 75 percent of the members of which are past or present members of the Armed Forces of the United States and substantially all of the other members are spouses, widows or widowers of past or present members of the Armed Forces of the United Sates; and 
b.  No part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any for profit private entity or individual. 
(b)  Any organization seeking to avail itself of this exemption shall make exception for this exemption to the board of commissioners on such forms and following such procedures as may be provided for by the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall then make a determination as to whether the applicant meets the criteria for this exemption and on the basis of such determination grant or deny the exemption to the applicant. Any exemption granted by the board of commissioners may be revoked by the board of commissioners at any time that it determines that the requirements for the exemption are no longer being met. 
(c)  Any exemption granted to an entity shall not apply during any time that the facilities operated by the entity are open to the public or are used by a non-member for meetings, gatherings, social events and the like. In such circumstances, the provisions of this article must be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-78), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-91. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by any law enforcement officer or code enforcement officer of Columbia County or an authorized designee. 
(b)  Notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to each person or entity paying employment taxes in Columbia County. 
(c)  Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with any police officer, fire marshal, code enforcement officer, building inspector or building official of Columbia County. 
(d)  The health department, fire marshal or other designees shall, while an establishment is undergoing otherwise mandated inspections, inspect for compliance with this article. 
(e)  An owner, manager, operator, or employee of an establishment regulated by this article shall inform persons violating this article of the appropriate provisions hereof. 
(f)  In addition to the remedies provided by the provisions of this section, Columbia County may apply for injunctive relief to enforce the provisions of this article in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-79), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-92. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article, shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties as set forth in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties established by this section, a violation of this article by a person who owns, manages, operators or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-79), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-93. - Public education. 
The Columbia County Health Department shall engage in a continuing program to explain and clarify the purposes and requirements of this article and to assist owners, operators, and managers in their compliance with it. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-80), 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 46-94. - Government agency cooperation. 
The Columbia County Health Department shall annually request other governmental and educational agencies having facilities within Columbia County to establish local operating procedures in cooperation and compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1(46-81), 9-21-2004) 
Secs. 46-95—46-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BODY ART[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-12, adopted March 15, 2011, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 46-90—46-123. At the editor's discretion, to prevent duplication of section numbers, these provisions have been included as §§ 46-100—46-133. 

Sec. 46-100. - Authority. 
The legal authority for this article is Section 16-5-71 and 16-5-71.1, Section 31-3-4, Section 31-3-5, Title 31 Chapter 40, and Section 48-13-9 all in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-101. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to establish reasonable standards for individuals providing body art services and for the body art establishments within which the body art services are provided. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-102. - Fees. 
Body art establishments and body artists subject to inspection under the provisions of this article shall be required to pay to the board of health an annual inspection fee as determined by the board of health, and approved by the county and the district health director. This fee is due within 30 days of receipt of notification from the board of health. Fees must also be paid to the board of health for the annual renewal of body artist licenses and body art establishment permits. Failure to pay such fees shall be considered in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-103. - Exemptions. 
Anything herein to the contrary notwithstanding, this article does do not apply to a physician or osteopath licensed under O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 34, or a healthcare provider, including but not limited to physician assistants, nurse practitioners, registered nurses, licensed practice nurses and medical technicians acting under the direct supervision of such licensed physician or osteopath. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-104. - Definitions. 
The following terms as used in this article shall have the meanings as set forth below: 
Antimicrobial solution means any solution used to retard the growth of microorganisms for application to human skin and labeled accordingly and has been approved by the FDA. 
Antiseptic means an agent or substance that will destroy or inhibit the growth and development of infectious microorganisms on human skin or mucous membranes which has been approved by the FDA. 
Applicant means any person who applies to the board of health for a body art license, guest body art license, body art establishment permit, or temporary body art establishment permit. 
Aseptic technique means to render or maintain free from infectious material so as to prevent transfer or transmission of infectious agents. 
ASTM means the American Society for Testing Materials International. 
Autoclave means an apparatus for sterilization utilizing steam pressure at a specific temperature over a period of time per manufacturer's specifications. 
Biomedical waste means liquid or semi-liquid blood or other potentially infectious materials, sharps or other contaminated items, which if compressed, would release blood or other potentially infectious materials in a liquid or semi-liquid state and as further defined in Rule 391-3-4-.15 of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources—Environmental Protection Division. 
Blood means human blood, human blood components, and products made from human blood. 
Bloodborne pathogens means pathogenic microorganisms present in human blood that can cause disease in humans. These pathogens include but are not limited to Hepatitis B virus (HBV), Hepatitis C virus (HCV), and Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV). 
Board of health means the Board of Health of Columbia County. 
Body art, body art services or body art procedures means the practice of physical body adornment by means of tattooing, body piercing, or permanent cosmetics. This definition does not include practices considered medical procedures by the Georgia Board of Registration in Medicine. 
Body art establishment, body art studio, tattoo establishment, tattoo parlor or tattoo studio means any permanent building or structure on a permanent foundation in which all or any of these body art services are performed. 
Body art establishment permit means a written permit issued by the board of health to a body art establishment stating that such establishment, after inspection, was found to be in compliance with this article. 
Body artist or tattoo artist means a person who performs tattooing, body piercing or permanent cosmetics, and who is responsible for complying with applicable provisions of this article. 
Body art license shall mean a license issued by the board of health to a specifically identified person authorizing such person to engage in the practice of body art in accordance with this article for a stated period of time. 
Body art regulation shall mean the rules, this article and any regulations and guidelines promulgated by the board of health pursuant hereto or to O.C.G.A. § 31-40-5 as amended from time to time. 
Body piercing means puncturing or penetrating the skin or mucosa of a client for the purpose of inserting jewelry or other adornment into the body for non-medical purposes. Body piercing does not include ear piercing, which is performed on the ear lobe with an ear piercing gun using sterile materials. 
Cleaning room shall mean the area in a body art establishment used in the sterilization, sanitation or other cleaning of instruments or other equipment used for the practice of body art. 
Client or customer shall mean an individual upon whom any body art services are performed. 
Contaminated means the presence or the reasonably anticipated presence of blood, other potentially infectious materials, or potentially harmful chemicals on an item or surface. 
Contaminated waste shall mean any biomedical waste; contaminated items that would release blood or other potentially infectious material in a liquid or semi-liquid state if compressed; items on which there is dried blood or other potentially infectious material and which are capable of releasing these materials during handling; sharps and any wastes containing blood or other potentially infectious materials, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22(1.1) and also in 29 CFR Part 1910.1030(latest edition), known as Occupational Exposure to Bloodborne Pathogens. 
County means the Board of Commissioners of Columbia County, Georgia. 
Critical item(s) means those aspects of performing body art services which, if violated, constitute the greatest hazards to health and safety, including imminent health hazards. Critical items shall include the following: 
(1)  Autoclave does not meet minimum time, pressure or temperature requirements; 
(2)  Lack of a monthly negative spore or microbiological monitoring test for quality control; 
(3)  Non-disposable tubes and needles are not sterilized as per guidelines of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; 
(4)  Reuse of single use articles; 
(5)  Sterile instruments are not properly handled; 
(6)  Reusable instruments are not handled properly; 
(7)  Employees with infectious lesions on hands not being restricted from body art procedures; 
(8)  Employees not practicing proper cleanliness and good hygienic practices; 
(9)  Water supply not approved or hot and cold running water under pressure not available; 
(10)  Approved sewage and liquid waste disposal not available or improper disposal of liquid wastes; 
(11)  Cross connection allowing back-siphonage present in plumbing system; 
(12)  Toilet and hand washing facilities not available for employees; 
(13)  Insect and rodent evidence, harborage, or outer opening present; 
(14)  Toxic items not properly stored, labeled, or used. 
Decontamination means the use of physical or chemical means to remove, inactivate, or destroy bloodborne pathogens on a surface or item to the point where they are no longer capable of transmitting infectious particles and the surface or item is rendered safe for handling, use, or disposal. 
Department means the office of environmental health or any other designee/agent authorized to act on behalf of the board of health such as the Georgia Division of Public Health. 
Disinfectant means a solution registered as a disinfectant by the EPA and intended to destroy or inactivate specific viruses, bacteria, or fungi on clean, inanimate surfaces. 
Disinfection means the destruction of disease-causing microorganisms on inanimate objects or surfaces, thereby rendering these objects safe for use or handling. 
Ear piercing means the puncturing of the outer ear for non-medical purposes, but excluding piercing performed on the ear lobe with an ear piercing gun using sterile materials. 
Easily cleanable means that surfaces are readily accessible and made of such materials and finish and so fabricated that residue may be effectively removed by normal cleaning methods. 
Environmental health inspector means an official appointed by the board of health who is responsible for licensing, permitting, and inspection of body art establishments. 
EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
Equipment means all machinery, including fixtures, containers, vessels, tools, devices, implements, furniture, display and storage areas, sinks, and all other apparatus and appurtenances used in connection with the operation of a body art establishment. 
FDA means the United States Food and Drug Administration. 
Germicidal solution means any solution which destroys microorganisms and is so labeled. 
Gloves means medical grade disposable single use gloves labeled for surgical or examination purposes. 
Guest body artist shall mean a visiting body artist possessing a guest body art license issued by the board of health to perform body art. 
Guest body art license means a temporary license for a period not to exceed 30 days which will permit the guest body artist to practice body art in accordance with this article under the direct supervision of a body artist holding a valid body art license issued by the board of health. 
Hot water means water that attains and maintains a minimum temperature of 110°F. 
Imminent health hazard means any condition, deficiency, or practice, as discovered by the environmental health inspector which, if not corrected, has the potential to result in disease transmission, injury, or loss of life to any person. 
Instruments means hand pieces, needles, needle bars, and other instruments that may come in contact with a client's body or may be exposed to bodily fluids during any body art procedure. 
ISO means the International Standards Organization. 
Jewelry means any ornament used in any body art procedure which is inserted into a newly pierced area. Any jewelry shall consist of a material rated by the ASTM or the ISO as being suitable for permanent surgical implant, such as stainless steel, titanium, niobium, solid platinum or a dense low porosity plastic such as Tygon or PTFE. The jewelry must be free of nicks, scratches, or irregular surfaces and must be properly sterilized prior to use. Copies of the jewelry manufacturer's documentation, which verify compliance with standards, must be available for inspection on request. Solid 14 karat or higher, white or yellow nickel-free gold may also be used. Purity verification must be available for inspection on request. 
Lavatory facilities means a lavatory providing an adequate supply of potable hot and cold running water under pressure, used solely for washing hands, arms, or other portions of the body. The facility shall include a soap dispenser, soap, and single use disposable towels. 
Law means the United States and the State of Georgia constitutional provisions, statutes, rules and regulations; any State of Georgia or Federal department or agency rules and regulations and the ordinances, rules and regulations of Columbia County, Georgia and the board of health. 
Microbiological monitoring for quality control means the use of a standard spore, to challenge the sterilization process. 
Micropigmentation or application of permanent cosmetics means a procedure performed above the jaw line and anterior to the ear and frontal hairline in which color or pigment is applied with a needle or electronic machine to produce a permanent mark visible through the skin. The procedure includes the application of lip, eyebrow, or cheek color for purposes of enhanced aesthetics; scar concealment. Micropigmentation shall not include placing on the body any pictures, images, numbers, signs, letters of the alphabet, or designs. 
Minor means an individual under the age of 18. 
NSF means the National Sanitation Foundation. 
Occupational exposure means a specific eye, mouth, other mucous membrane, non-intact skin, or potential contact with blood or other potentially infectious materials resulting from the performance of an employee's activities. 
Official Code of Georgia Annotated or O.C.G.A. means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as the same is amended from time to time. 
Operator/owner means any person, firm, company, corporation, partnership, association or other legal entity that owns, controls, operates, conducts, or manages a body art establishment. 
OSHA means the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration. 
Other potentially infectious material means the following human body fluids: semen, vaginal secretions, saliva, and any other body fluid visibly contaminated with blood. 
Parenteral means piercing mucous membranes or the skin barrier through such events as needle sticks and piercings. 
Permanent cosmetic micropigmentation practitioner means a person holding a current body art license which permits such person to provide permanent cosmetic micropigmentation services. 
Person means an individual, any form of business or social organization or any other non-governmental legal entity, including but not limited to corporations, partnerships, limited-liability companies, associations, trusts or unincorporated organizations. 
Personal protective equipment means specialized clothing or equipment, such as gloves or lap cloth, worn by an employee for protection against a hazard. General work clothes not intended to function as protection against a hazard are not considered to be personal protective equipment. 
Personnel means the operator/owner, any person who performs body art, individuals having supervisory or management duties, or any other person employed or working in a body art establishment. 
Pierce or piercing means body piercing. 
Potable water means water that is from an approved water system that is safe for drinking. 
Premises means the physical location of a body art establishment. 
Proof of age means a driver's license or other generally accepted means of identification that describes the age of the individual, contains a photograph, and appears on its face to be valid. 
PTFE means Polytetrafluoroethylne also known as Teflon. 
Safe materials means articles manufactured for the specific purpose of body art procedures which are unlikely to cause injury or disease under proper use and care. 
Sanitary means clean and free of agents of infection or disease. 
Sanitized means the application of an EPA registered sanitizer on a cleaned surface by a process that provides sufficient concentration of chemicals for enough time to reduce the microorganism level, including pathogens, to a safe level on utensils and equipment in accordance with the label instructions. 
Sewage or sewerage means human excreta, all water carried waste, and household wastes from residences, buildings, or commercial and industrial establishments. 
Sharps means any object, sterile or contaminated, that may intentionally or accidentally cut or penetrate the skin or mucosa. 
Sharps container means a puncture-resistant, leak-proof container that can be closed for handling, storage, transportation, and disposal and that is labeled with the International Biohazard Symbol. 
Single use means disposable products or items that are intended for one-time, one-person use and are properly disposed of by appropriate measures after use on each client. Single use items include but are not limited to cotton swabs or balls, single-use micropigmentation instruments, tissues or paper products, paper or plastic cups, gauze and sanitary coverings, razors, piercing needles, stencils, ink cups, and protective gloves. 
Solid waste means refuse, garbage, trash, rubbish, and any other item(s) which could cause an unsanitary condition or undesirable health and safety conditions. 
Sterilization or sterilize means the use of a physical or chemical procedure by which all forms of microbial life, including bacteria, viruses, spores, and fungi are destroyed including highly resistant bacterial endospores. This is achieved by holding in an autoclave for 15 minutes, at 15 pounds pressure, and at a temperature of 250 degrees Fahrenheit or 121 degrees Celsius, or any equivalent procedure resulting in complete destruction of microbial life including spores. 
Sterilized indicator means a tape, strip, or other device designed to change color to indicate that sterilization temperature has been achieved during the sterilization procedure. 
Sterilizer means an autoclave certified to meet generally accepted medical standards. 
Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in, piercing, or implanting indelible pigments or dyes under the skin. 
Temporary body art establishment shall mean any location, place, facility or business which is established by an operator/owner on a temporary basis where a body artist or guest body artist has been granted a permit to practice body art by the board of health for a period of no more than seven consecutive days only for the purpose of product demonstration in connection with conventions or industry trade shows. 
Ultrasonic cleaning unit means a unit approved by the board of health, physically large enough to fully submerge instruments in liquid, which removes all foreign matter from the instruments by means of high frequency oscillations transmitted through the contained liquid. 
Universal precautions means a set of guidelines and controls, published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), as Guidelines for Prevention of Transmission of Human Immune-deficiency Virus (HIV) and Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) to Health-Care and Public-Safety Workers in Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report) (MMWR), June 23, 1989, Vol. 38 No. S-6, and as Recommendations for Preventing Transmission of Human Immune Deficiency Virus and Hepatitis B Virus to Patients During Exposure-Prone Invasive Procedures in MMWR, July 12, 1991, Vol. 40, No. RR-8. This method of infection control requires the employer and the employee to assume that all human blood and specified human body fluids are infectious for HIV, HBV, HCV, and other blood pathogens. Precautions include hand washing; gloving; personal protective equipment; injury prevention; and proper handling and disposal of needles, other sharp instruments, and blood and body fluid-contaminated products. 
Utensil means any implement, tool, or other similar device used in the storage, preparation, operation, or processing of body art. 
Violation correction means a plan for correcting deficiencies in meeting the requirements of this article. 
Waste means solid waste, sewage, blood and body fluids or other waste resulting from the operation of a body art studio. 
Work area or work station means an area where clients receive body art services. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-105. - Prohibited facilities. 
Body art studios shall not be allowed in the same building that is used for human habitation, any food service establishment, retail sales, hotel rooms or similar areas. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-106. - Prohibited procedures. 
The following body art procedures shall not be performed in Columbia County, Georgia. 
(1)  Implants, 3-D procedures or other procedures involving insertion of foreign objects under the skin are prohibited. 
(2)  Any body art procedures requiring medical equipment (ex. scalpels, derma punches) other than needles shall be prohibited. 
(3)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-5-71.1, it shall be unlawful for any person to pierce the body, with the exception of the ear lobes, of any person under the age of 18 for the purposes of allowing the insertion of earrings, jewelry, or similar objects into the body, unless the body piercing is performed in the presence of the person's parent or legal guardian. Nipple and genital piercing is prohibited on minors regardless of parental or legal guardian consent. 
(4)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-5-71(a), No person under the age of 18 shall be tattooed. 
(5)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-12-5(b), it shall be unlawful for any person to perform tattooing, piercing, or cosmetic micropigmentation procedures on any area of a person within one inch of the nearest part of the eye socket. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-107. - Body art license. 
No person shall provide body art services in Columbia County, Georgia who does not have a body art license which is current and in good standing. An application for a body art license can be obtained from the board of health. To obtain a body art license, the following procedures must be met: 
(1)  Any person who desires to become a body artist must be at least 18 years of age and must work as an apprentice under a licensed body artist for a period of at least one year within the immediately preceding 36 months. The trainer licensed body artist must provide direct oversight and supervision of the work being performed by the apprentice. Within ten days prior to beginning to serve as the trainer for an apprentice, the licensed body artist must notify the board of health in writing of this arrangement. At the time that the training arrangement ceases to exist, the licensed body artist shall notify the board of health in writing within ten days of such termination that the training process has been discontinued without being completed, or that the training of the apprentice has been successfully completed. 
(2)  The applicant must be in compliance with this article, all Columbia County requirements and all applicable law. The applicant must have all Columbia County taxes paid current. 
(3)  Information to be provided in the application for a body artist license shall include but shall not be limited to: 
a.  Name. 
b.  Date of birth. 
c.  Sex. 
d.  Residence address. 
e.  Mailing address. 
f.  Phone number. 
g.  Place(s) of employment as a body artist. 
h.  Photo I.D. 
i.  Proof of successful completion of an OSHA approved Bloodborne Pathogen/Universal Precautions training program and Basic First Aid/CPR class given or approved by the board of health. 
j.  Listing of the various forms of body art for which the applicant may be licensed. 
(4)  The applicant for his/her initial body art license must provide proof of his/her training and experience which must be at least one year working as an apprentice under the direct supervision of a licensed body artist within the immediately preceding 36 months and the completion of the following courses: Bloodborne Pathogen/Universal Precautions, Tattoo Infection Control and Basic First Aid/Adult CPR training, which shall be acceptable to the board of health. Training/courses provided by professional body art organizations/associations or by equipment manufacturers may also be submitted for consideration. 
(5)  Individuals seeking body art license shall submit a completed application on a form provided by the board of health, pay a license fee determined by the board of health from time to time, and provide proof of satisfaction of all requirements for the license. 
(6)  Body artists who are providing body art services on the date of adoption of this article shall make application for a body art license within 30 days after the date on which this article becomes effective. Such applicants may obtain a body art license if they meet the requirements therefore except for the completion of the courses listed in this section 46-107(4) above; provided, however, that such courses must be successfully completed and the body artist certified as required within six months after the effective date of this article. Failure of the body artist to complete such courses and obtain such certification will result in immediate suspension of the body artist license. 
(7)  A body artist from a jurisdiction other than Columbia County, Georgia who wants to provide body art services or temporary body art services in Columbia County must provide proof of experience with a minimum of one year experience working under the direct supervision of an experienced body artist within the last 36-month period or a minimum of 24 months experience working independently within the last 36-month period, proof of licensing in the other jurisdiction which must be current and in good standing, Bloodborne Pathogen/Universal Precautions, Tattoo Infection Control and Basic First Aid/Adult CPR. Proof of such applicant's experience may be a copy of a business license, tax records, copy of another state's tattoo artist license, or other similar city, county, state, or federal documents which show the prospective applicant as having been in business or operating for 18 months elsewhere. The environmental health inspector shall have final approval on other forms of documentation submitted as evidence or proof. 
(8)  A body artist shall only perform those body art services that are requested in the body art license application and which are approved by the board of health. 
(9)  The body artist license shall be valid from the date of issuance and shall automatically expire annually on January 31 of each year. Body artist licenses which are in good standing may be renewed annually prior to January 31 of each year. 
(10)  In order for a body art license to be renewed proof of completion of the required courses set out in this section 46-107(4) of this article must be provided and a renewal fee in the amount set from time to time by the board of health must be paid to the board of health. 
(11)  All body artist licenses shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area inside the body art establishment where they may be readily observed by clients. 
(12)  A copy of the licensing standards for body art services shall be maintained by the licensed body artist and placed where they will be accessible to all staff members working in the body art establishment where the body artist is providing such services. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-108. - Guest body artist license. 
To obtain a guest body art license, the following procedures must be followed: 
(1)  The board of health may issue a 30 day license to an individual holding a license or similar certificate or registration to engage in the practice of body art issued under the jurisdiction of another city, county, or state of the United States. Such guest body art license will allow a person to practice body art under the direct supervision of a body artist holding a valid body art license issued by the board of health. The issuance of a guest body art license is conditioned upon the applicant demonstrating the following: 
a.  The applicant has received training as a body artist equivalent to the minimum training requirements for a body artist set by this article; 
b.  The applicant shall provide a letter of consent signed by the licensed body artist who will providing the direct supervision of the applicant, a copy of the body art license or certificate held by the applicant, a copy of the body art license held by the supervising body artist, a copy of the body art establishment permit for the establishment where the applicant will provide any body art services; 
c.  An application fee paid to the board of health. 
(2)  No visiting body artist shall provide body art services without a guest body art license issued by the board of health. 
(3)  The supervising body artist must notify the board of health in writing that he/she will provide the direct supervision of the guest body artist at least ten days prior to the date of issuance of the requested guest body artist license. 
(4)  No person shall be issued more than two guest body art licenses in any 12-month period. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-109. - Operator/owner responsibilities. 
The responsibilities of an operator/owner of a body artist establishment include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  The operator/owner shall be responsible for compliance with the requirements of all applicable law. 
(2)  Operator/owner shall not allow any body artist who is under the influence of alcohol, drugs or any other substance which does impair his/her ability to comply with this article while performing body art services. 
(3)  Operator/owner shall refuse to allow body art services to be provided to, and a body artist shall refuse to perform body art services on, any person who is under the influence of alcohol or drugs or any other substance which may impair the mental capabilities of such person or any person who is mentally incompetent and unable to make reasonable cognitive decisions at the time of seeking body art services. 
(4)  Live animals shall not be allowed inside the body art studio or in other areas within the building under the control of the body art establishment permit holder. However, this exclusion does not apply to fish in aquariums or caged reptiles which must be located in the lobby area only. Reptiles may not be handled during business hours. Service animals accompanying disabled persons shall be permitted in the body art establishment. 
(5)  Operator/owner shall ensure the skin of a body artist shall be free of rash, any lesion or visible sign of infection. A body artist shall not be allowed to provide any body art services upon any area of a client that evidences the presence of any rash, lesion or other visible signs of infection. 
(6)  Any future body art procedures not covered within this article which have the potential for transmitting infectious disease must receive written board of health approval prior to being offered to clients or customers. 
(7)  Operator/owner shall not permit body art services to be performed by anyone other than a currently licensed body artist. 
(8)  No person except a duly licensed physician, healthcare provider, including but not limited to physician assistants, nurse practitioners, registered nurses, licensed practice nurses and medical technicians acting under the direct supervision of the licensed physician shall be allowed to remove or attempt to remove any body art from a person. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-110. - Plan submission for body art establishments. 
(a)  Prior to construction, upfitting, remodeling of a body art establishment, properly prepared plans to scale and specifications must be submitted to the board of health for review and approval. This shall not abrogate in any way requirements to obtain other applicable permits and approvals by governmental agencies having jurisdiction. 
(b)  The plans and specifications shall be submitted to the board of health at least 14 business days prior to the anticipated start of construction. Plans shall include floor plan layout, arrangement of equipment, mechanical plans, construction materials and finish schedule and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. 
(c)  The floor plan shall include location of the work station(s) and the identification of sterilization equipment. Preparation by an architect is not required. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-111. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Following the obtaining of the approval of the plans by the board of health and obtaining all other approvals and permits that are required, the operator/owner shall seek the issuance by the board of health of a body art establishment permit. The operator/owner of a body art establishment shall submit to the board of health an application for a body art establishment permit to operate under this article and the law. No body art establishment shall be operated and no body art services shall be provided without a body art establishment permit, which is current and in good standing under this article. 
(b)  The application for a body art establishment permit shall be made on forms provided by the board of health. 
(c)  The operator/owner shall list in its application the exact duties of personnel who have been designated as being responsible for carrying out compliance with the Law and each person having any interest in the operator/owner. The following information shall be included for each person: Name, DOB, gender, home address, home/work phone numbers, identification photos. 
(d)  Prior to being granted a body art establishment permit, each body art establishment shall develop a written statement of policies and standard operating procedures satisfactory to the board of health including: 
(1)  Sterilization. 
(2)  Employee health. 
(3)  Sanitizing areas and equipment between clients. 
(4)  Disposal of waste. 
(5)  Record keeping. 
(6)  Client screening. 
(7)  Aftercare procedures. 
(8)  Incident reporting. 
(e)  Zoning and other local requirements regarding proper location and establishment of a body art studio shall be addressed by the applicant with the responsible local officials and complied with. 
(f)  Existing establishments and personnel: 
(1)  Body art establishments in operation on the date of adoption of this article shall make application for a body art establishment permit within 30 days of the date on which this article becomes effective. 
(2)  The board of health may approve up to a 12-month period from the date of application for compliance of physical facilities of existing establishments; provided however that no exemptions will be granted for circumstances presenting an imminent health hazard. 
(3)  Operators/owners of a body art establishment must successfully complete a tattoo infection control course within six months after the effective date of this article or be subject to immediate suspension of the body artist establishment permit. 
(g)  A new or initial application is required for a body art establishment that has not previously been permitted, when ownership changes or if the body art establishment permit has been revoked and the operator/owner is seeking to reopen the body art establishment. To be eligible for a permit, the body art establishment must be in compliance with this article, all applicable law, all Columbia County requirements and all Columbia County taxes must be paid current. 
(h)  The board of health may issue a body art establishment permit: 
(1)  After an inspection of the proposed body art establishment reveals that it is in compliance with this article; 
(2)  Upon receiving a completed application with applicable fees; and 
(3)  After determining that all requirements for issuance of the permit have been met. 
(i)  The body art establishment permit shall be displayed with in plain view upon entering the body art establishment. 
(j)  Body art establishment permits must be renewed yearly on or before January 31 of each calendar year and are not transferable from one body art establishment to another or from one operator/owner to another. 
(k)  An operator/owner of a body artist establishment may not perform body art services unless such person holds a current body art license in Columbia County, Georgia. 
(l)  A body art establishment permit shall no longer be valid and shall be returned to the county when the body art establishment ceases to operate, has moved to another location, the ownership changes, or the permit is suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-112. - Temporary body art establishment. 
(a)  A temporary body art establishment permit may be issued for body art services provided at a place other than a permitted body art establishment for the purpose of product demonstration or in connection with body art conventions or industry trade shows. Such a permit shall be for a period of no more than seven days. 
(b)  A temporary body art establishment permit may be applied for by the operator/owner of a body art establishment. Such application must contain the location, the operating days, hours of operation of the temporary body art establishment and the plans/description of the temporary body art establishment. 
(c)  Temporary body art establishment permits will not be issued unless: 
(1)  The applicant is a minimum of 18 years of age and demonstrates to the board of health his/her successful compliance with all training, disclosure, consent and educational requirements of this article. 
(2)  Application for a permit for the temporary body art establishment has been submitted for review by the board of health at least 30 days prior to the event. 
(3)  The applicant has paid all required fees set by the board of health. 
(d)  If the applicant currently holds a body art establishment permit issued by the board of health, then only a temporary body art establishment permit is required. 
(e)  The following criteria pertain to temporary body art establishment permitting: 
(1)  No temporary body art establishment permit may be issued for more than seven consecutive days. 
(2)  An applicant for a temporary body art establishment permit shall not receive more than two consecutive seven-day permits and/or license during a 30-day period. 
(3)  A temporary body art establishment permit shall not be transferable from one location to another or from one operator/owner to another. 
(4)  Temporary body art establishment permits shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous place so clients can readily observe it. 
(f)  Temporary body art establishments shall be subject to all health and safety regulations contained in this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-113. - Variance procedures. 
The board of health may grant a variance from the body art establishment or temporary body art establishment provisions for a permit or temporary permit either upon its own motion or upon request of the applicant if it finds that a literal enforcement of such provision will result in demonstrated unnecessary hardship to the applicant and that such a variance will not be contrary to the public interest, public health and/or health and safety of clients. A request for a variance shall be filed by an applicant in writing, setting forth in detail the basis upon which the request is made. Within 30 days of filing for a request for a variance, the board of health shall notify the applicant by certified mail of its approval or denial. If the request is denied, the applicant may request a hearing on the denial. The board of health shall then set a hearing date, time and place. At the hearing, the applicant shall present his/her case. The board of health shall then make a decision which shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-114. - Minimum standards. 
The following minimum standards will apply to body art establishments: 
(1)  Each body art establishment where body art procedures are administered shall provide a work area separate from the areas where observers or visitors are permitted. 
(2)  At least one work area shall provide complete privacy for clients by means of doors, nonabsorbent curtains, or similar approved partitions. 
(3)  A body art establishment shall have a cleaning room to be used exclusively for the cleaning, disinfection, and sterilization of instruments. 
a.  The cleaning room shall have a separate NSF approved instrument sink or stainless steel instrument sink reserved only for instrument disinfection, which shall be equipped with hot and cold running water. 
b.  The cleaning room shall be separated from any other area in the body art establishment by means of doors, nonabsorbent curtains, or similar approved partitions. 
c.  The cleaning room shall be equipped with an ultrasonic cleaning unit and a medical grade autoclave. The autoclave shall be used to sterilize all non-disposable and reusable body art equipment. 
d.  The instrument sink, ultrasonic cleaning unit and autoclave shall each be separated by a minimum distance of 24 inches, unless using a board of health approved splashguard. 
e.  The cleaning room walls, doors, windows, skylight, and similar closures shall be constructed of smooth, nonabsorbent, durable material and be maintained in good repair. 
f.  The cleaning room ceiling shall be maintained in good repair allowing for easy and effective cleaning. 
(4)  A hand washing sink shall be provided for each private work station and every two workstations. Hand washing sinks shall be no more than 30 feet from any workstation. 
(5)  No hand washing sink or instrument sink shall be used as a janitorial sink. 
(6)  Each location shall have the facilities to properly dispose of all waste material. All materials must be disposed of in accordance with Georgia Department of Natural Resources—Environmental Protection Division—Solid Waste Management—Chapter 391-3-4.15. 
(7)  The use of common towels and cloths is prohibited. Hand sinks shall be equipped with a soap dispenser and single use disposable towels. 
(8)  Sanitary facilities and controls. 
a.  Water supply. 
1.  Enough potable water for the needs of the body art studio shall be provided from an approved source that is a public water system; or a nonpublic water system that is constructed, maintained and operated according to applicable state and local codes. 
2.  Water from a public water system shall meet 40 CFR 141—National Primary Drinking Water Regulations and state drinking water quality standards 
3.  Water from a nonpublic system shall meet state drinking water quality standards. 
i.  Water from a nonpublic water system shall be sampled and tested at least annually and as required by state water quality regulations. 
ii.  The most recent sample report for the nonpublic water system shall be retained on file in the body art establishment or the report shall be maintained as specified by state water quality regulations. 
b.  Sewerage. All sewerage, including liquid water, shall be disposed of into a public sewerage system or by a private sewerage disposal system constructed and operated according to law. 
c.  Plumbing. Plumbing shall be sized, installed, and maintained according to all applicable building codes. There shall be no cross-connection between the potable water supply and any other water supply or other source of contamination. 
(9)  Toilet facilities. 
a.  Toilet installation. Toilet facilities shall be designed, installed, and maintained according to law. There shall be separate toilet rooms and/or toilet fixtures to accommodate clients and operators; facilities that have separate equipment cleaning and hand washing areas for personnel may suffice with a common restroom. 
b.  Toilet rooms. Toilet rooms opening directly into work or client waiting areas shall be completely enclosed and shall have tight-fitting, self closing, solid doors, which shall be closed except during cleaning or maintenance. 
c.  [Ventilation.] All toilet rooms shall have sufficient mechanical ventilation to keep them free of excessive heat, steam, condensation, vapors, obnoxious odors, smoke, and fumes. 
d.  Toilet fixtures. Toilet fixtures shall be kept clean and in good repair. A supply of toilet tissue shall be provided at each toilet at all times. Easily cleanable receptacles shall be provided for waste materials. Toilet rooms shall have at least one covered waste receptacle. 
(10)  Lavatory facilities. 
a.  Lavatory installation. Lavatory facilities shall be designed, installed, and maintained according to law. Facilities shall be of sufficient number and location to permit convenient use by clients and operators. 
b.  Lavatory faucets. Each lavatory shall be provided with hot and cold water tempered by means of a mixing valve or combination faucet. Any self-closing, slow-closing, or metering faucet used shall be designed to provide a flow of water for at least 20 seconds without the need to reactivate the faucet. 
c.  Lavatory supplies. A soap dispenser and a supply of antiseptic, hand-cleaning soap or detergent shall be available at each lavatory. A supply of single use sanitary towels shall be conveniently located near each lavatory. Easily cleanable covered waste receptacles shall be conveniently located near the hand washing facilities. 
d.  Lavatory maintenance. Lavatories, soap dispensers, paper towel dispensers, and all related fixtures shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(11)  Solid waste. 
a.  Containers. 
1.  Garbage and refuse shall be kept in durable, easily cleaned containers that do not leak and do not absorb liquids. Containers shall be kept in a clean and sound condition. 
2.  Containers used in work areas shall be kept covered when not in use and after they are filled. 
3.  There shall be a sufficient number of containers to hold all the garbage and refuse that accumulate. 
b.  Garbage and refuse shall be disposed of at such frequency to prevent the development of odor and the attraction of insects, rodents, or vermin. 
(12)  The premises shall be kept in such condition as to prevent the entrance, harborage, or feeding of insects, rodents, or vermin. 
(13)  Floors and floor coverings of all work areas, dressing rooms, locker rooms, toilet rooms and vestibules shall be constructed of smooth, nonabsorbent, durable material and maintained in good repair. Carpeting is allowed in the lobby area only and shall be of closely woven construction, properly installed, easily cleanable, and maintained in good repair. 
(14)  Walls and ceilings. 
a.  Walls and ceilings, including doors, windows, skylight, and similar closures shall be constructed of smooth, nonabsorbent, durable material and be maintained in good repair. Additionally, work area(s) floors, walls and ceilings shall be clean to sight and touch. Facilities existing in a fully completed condition on October 1, 2010, may be exempted from requirements for a ceiling with smooth, nonabsorbent materials; provided that on October 1, 2010, they do not have ceilings of smooth nonabsorbent materials. At such time as the ceilings of such Facilities need to be repaired or replaced, the smooth nonabsorbent materials must be used. 
b.  Light fixtures, vent covers, wall-mounted fans, and similar equipment attached to walls and ceilings shall be easily cleanable and maintained in good repair. 
(15)  Floors, walls, ceilings, and attached equipment and decorative materials shall be kept clean and maintained in good repair. 
(16)  Lighting. 
a.  Permanently fixed artificial light sources shall be installed to provide at least 50 foot candles of light on all work area surfaces and at equipment washing work levels. 
b.  Permanently fixed artificial light sources shall be installed to provide at a distance of 30 inches from the floor at least ten foot candles of light in all other areas. 
(17)  Ventilation. All rooms shall have sufficient ventilation to keep them free of excessive heat, steam, condensation, vapors, obnoxious odors, smoke, and fumes. 
(18)  Poisonous or toxic materials. 
a.  There shall be present in the body art studio only those poisonous or toxic materials necessary for maintaining the establishment and cleaning or sanitizing equipment, as well as controlling insects and rodents. 
b.  Containers of poisonous or toxic materials shall be prominently and distinctly labeled according to law for easy identification of contents. 
c.  Toxic items shall be separated from other forms of materials used in body art procedures. 
d.  Spray bottles may be used for the purpose of cleaning but not for body art procedure preparation. 
(19)  Premises. 
a.  Body art establishments shall be kept neat, clean, and free of litter and rubbish. 
b.  Only articles necessary for the operation and maintenance of the body art establishment shall be stored on or within the establishment. 
(20)  Animals. If applicable, all fish aquariums and reptile cages shall be cleaned and maintained in good repair. 
(21)  Equipment, utensils and instruments. 
a.  Materials. 
1.  Multi-use equipment, utensils and instruments shall be constructed and repaired with safe materials, including finishing materials; they shall be corrosion resistant and nonabsorbent; and they shall be smooth, easily cleanable, and durable under conditions of normal use. Single-service articles shall be made from clean, sanitary, and safe materials. 
2.  Re-use of single service equipment, utensils and instruments is prohibited. 
b.  Design and fabrication. 
1.  General: All equipment, utensils and instruments, including plasticware, shall be designed and fabricated for durability under conditions of normal use and shall be resistant to denting, buckling, pitting, and chipping. 
i.  Operational surfaces on equipment, utensils and instruments shall be easily cleanable, smooth, and free of breaks, open seams, cracks, chips, pits, and similar imperfections, as well as free of difficult to clean internal corners and crevices. 
ii.  Sinks and drain boards shall be self-draining. 
2.  Operational surfaces: Surfaces of equipment, utensils and instruments not intended as operational surfaces, but which are exposed to splash or debris or which otherwise require frequent cleaning, shall be designed and fabricated to be smooth, washable, free of unnecessary ledges, projections, or crevices and readily accessible for cleaning. Such surfaces shall be of material and in such repair as to be easily maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
3.  Needles, needle bars, dyes, or pigments shall be designed and manufactured for the sole purpose of body art. 
(22)  Aisles and working spaces: Aisles and working spaces between units of equipment and walls shall be unobstructed and of sufficient width to permit employees to perform their duties readily without contamination of equipment or of operational surfaces by clothing or personal contact. 
(23)  Temporary body art establishments shall meet the requirements of these regulations subject to the following variations. 
a.  Hand washing facilities must be located within each work or demonstration area. 
b.  Hand washing facilities shall consist of liquid antimicrobial hand soap, single-use paper towels and warm potable water dispensed from an insulated container that contains at least five gallons of potable water with a spigot that is raised a minimum of 25 inches off the floor. 
c.  Waste water shall be collected in a bucket that will hold at least five gallons of waste water placed on the floor under the spigot. Warm potable water shall be replenished and wastewater removed as necessary to the sanitary sewer system, or, in the absence thereof, in a manner approved by the board of health. 
d.  Only single use disposable sterilized supplies can be used. 
(24)  The Columbia County Development Services Division and Water Utility Services Division should be contacted regarding compliance with the applicable building codes. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-115. - Furnishings and fixtures. 
The following shall apply to furnishings and fixtures in a body art establishment: 
(1)  Furnishings of the body art establishment shall be maintained in good condition, intact, and functional. Furnishings must be made of or covered in a material that is easily cleanable and non-absorbent. The body art establishment shall be kept clean, neat, and free of litter and rubbish at all times. 
(2)  Cabinets and closed sealable containers for the storage of instruments, dyes, pigments, single use articles (ex. Gloves, ink caps, carbon, stencils, etc.) shall be provided for each body artist and shall be maintained in a sanitary manner which protects them from contamination. 
(3)  Work tables and chairs shall be provided for each body artist. 
a.  All exposed surfaces of all worktables and chairs shall be constructed of material, which is smooth, nonabsorbent, corrosive resistant, and easily sanitized. 
b.  All exposed surfaces of work tables and chairs shall be sanitized with an antimicrobial solution after each application. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-116. - Personnel. 
(a)  The body art establishment operator/owner shall make available, at no cost to the personnel working in the body art establishment, Hepatitis B vaccination series, as well as any routine booster dose(s) to every person who may have occupational exposure to blood or other potentially infectious material. For new personnel the vaccine shall be made available within ten business days of employment. 
(b)  Proof shall be provided upon request by the board of health that the operator/owner and body artists have either completed or were offered and declined in writing, the Hepatitis B vaccination series; that antibody testing has revealed that the employee is immune to Hepatitis B; or that the vaccine is contraindicated for medical reasons. Contraindication requires a dated and signed physician's statement specifying the name of the person and that the vaccine cannot be given. Personnel who decline to accept the Hepatitis B vaccination series must sign a form indicating their refusal. 
(c)  The operator/owner must maintain a file on all personnel who perform body art procedures. Personnel files must be kept on location during employment and for a minimum of two years after the person is no longer employed by the body art establishment. The personnel files must be available for inspection and include the following: 
(1)  Report of Hepatitis B Vaccination, Hepatitis B antibody testing, contraindication to Hepatitis B vaccine, or signed Hepatitis B Vaccine declination letter. 
(2)  Evidence of Red Cross Basic First Aid/Adult CPR certification or equivalent and completion of an OSHA approved Bloodborne Pathogen/Universal Precautions. 
(3)  A copy of a photo I.D. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-117. - Client files. 
Records of each client receiving body art services shall be prepared by the body art establishment prior to the body art services being performed and shall reflect the client's name, address, proof of age, date procedure performed, design, its location and name of the body artist who provided the body art services. A statement of informed consent to the body artist services informing the client of the risks involved and possible complications that might result from the body art procedure signed by the individual receiving the body art services must be maintained in the file. A statement by the client attesting that he/she is not under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs shall be on file. A copy of procedures signed by the client advising him/her of proper subsequent care of the body art shall be maintained on file. All of these documents shall be retained for a minimum of two years at the body art studio. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-118. - Supplies. 
(a)  Bulk single use articles shall be commercially packaged and handled to protect them from contamination. These articles shall be stored in an area separate from the work area and toilet facilities. 
(b)  All materials applied to the human skin shall be from single use containers and shall be disposed of after each use. 
(c)  Each work station in a body art establishment shall be equipped or stocked in the following manner: 
(1)  For body tattooing services: A minimum of six sterilized needles, six sterilized needle bars, and six sterilized needle tubes; 
For body piercing services: A minimum of six sterilized needles, six sterilized needle tubes, six sterilized forceps, and six sterilized hemostats; 
For cosmetic tattooing or micropigmentation services (with single-use only equipment): Six single-use pens or equivalent instruments. 
(2)  A minimum of two extra packages of disposable towels/tissues other than the package that is being used; 
(3)  A minimum of one extra box of medical grade disposable gloves other than the box being used; 
(4)  An extra supply of bandages, ointment or gel, and antimicrobial soap. 
(d)  A standard first aid kit or equivalent first aid supplies shall be readily accessible in the body art establishments and shall contain as a minimum: 
(1)  4" × 4" gauze pads; 
(2)  Benzalkonium swabs; 
(3)  2" × 2" gauze pads; 
(4)  Gauze roller bandage; 
(5)  Cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) mouth barrier device; 
(6)  Eyewash solution; 
(7)  Smelling salts or ammonia inhalants. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-119. - Dyes and pigments. 
(a)  All dyes and pigments used in tattooing shall be from commercial professional suppliers specifically manufactured as dyes and/or pigments only for the tattooing of human skin. 
(b)  In preparing or mixing of dyes or pigments, only nontoxic sterile materials shall be used. Dyes or pigments shall be mixed and placed in sterile individual single-use containers. 
(c)  After tattooing, the remaining unused dye or pigment in the single-use container(s) shall be properly discarded along with the container(s). 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-120. - Piercing jewelry. 
(a)  The client and body piercer should have appropriate size and quality jewelry chosen before the procedure begins. 
(b)  Jewelry used in piercing shall consist of a material rated by the ASTM or the ISO as being suitable for permanent surgical implant, such as stainless steel, titanium, niobium, solid platinum or a dense low porosity plastic such as Tygon or PTFE. Copies of the jewelry manufacturer's documentation, which verify compliance with these standards, must be available for inspection upon request. Solid 14 karat or higher, white or yellow nickel-free gold may also be used. Purity verification must be available for inspection upon request. 
(c)  The jewelry must be free of nicks, scratches, or irregular surfaces and must be properly sterilized prior to use. 
(d)  All jewelry used in the body piercing must be sterilized in a medical grade autoclave, stored in sterile indicator bags, sealed and dated. 
(e)  Ear studs or other jewelry designed for earlobe piercing are not appropriate jewelry for other body parts and must not be used on body parts other than the earlobe. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-121. - Tattoo preparation. 
(a)  Medical grade disposable gloves shall be worn during the preparation of equipment and during the providing of tattoo services. 
(b)  Needles or needle bars shall be in packaging that indicates sterility prior to tattooing. Needles and other sharps shall be used only once and then disposed of in puncture proof, auto-clavable containers, or disposable biohazard containers. 
(c)  Sterilized instruments shall remain in sterile packages until opened in front of the client. 
(d)  Any part of a tattooing machine that may be touched by the body artist during the procedure shall be covered with a disposable plastic sheath that is discarded after each procedure and the machine shall be disinfected. 
(e)  All devices used to apply pigments must be designed and used to prevent backflow of pigments into the machine. 
(f)  Single-use towels or gauze shall be used in preparing the site to be tattooed and shall be disposed of after use on each patron or client. 
(g)  If shaving is necessary, single-use disposable razors shall be used. 
(h)  After shaving the area to be tattooed, or if the area does not need to be shaved, the site of the tattoo shall be cleaned with soap and water, rinsed with clean water, and germicidal solution applied in a sanitary manner before each placement of design on the skin. 
(i)  When a workstation rinse cup is used alone, the cup and solution shall be disposable and discarded after use on a client. 
(j)  If squirt bottles are used to dispense liquids, the liquid shall be squirted onto a single-use wipe rather than directly onto the client. 
(k)  Single use ointment tubes, applicators, and supplies shall be discarded after each tattoo application. 
(l)  When a paper stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be single use and disposable. The use of roll-on or stick deodorants for tattoo site preparation is prohibited. 
(m)  The stencil shall be applied with antimicrobial soap or a departmental approved product dispensed from a container in a manner that does not contaminate the unused portion. 
(n)  When the design is drawn directly onto the skin, pre-sterilized, single use non-toxic pens or markers shall be used and discarded after each use. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-122. - Body piercing preparation. 
(a)  Medical grade disposable gloves shall be worn during the preparation of equipment for a body art procedure and during the procedure. 
(b)  All piercing needles shall be single use, sterilized disposable type and disposed of immediately after use into a sharps container. 
(c)  All forceps, hemostats, calipers, and tubes must be sterilized and placed in sealed, properly labeled, sterile indicator bags. These items are to be used on one client, in one sitting. After one such use, they must be cleaned in an ultrasonic cleaner, placed in sealed indicator bags, properly labeled, autoclaved and stored in sterile indicator bags. 
(d)  Sterilized instruments shall remain in sterile packages until opened in front of the client. 
(e)  Single-use towels or gauze shall be used in preparing the piercing site and shall be disposed of after use on each client. 
(f)  After shaving the area to be pierced, or if the area does not need to be shaved, the piercing site shall be cleaned with soap and water, rinsed with clean water, and germicidal solution applied in a sanitary manner before beginning the procedure. 
(g)  In the case of oral piercings, the body artist shall provide the individual with antiseptic mouthwash in a single-use cup and shall ensure that the individual utilizes the mouthwash provided. In the case of a lip, labret, or cheek piercing, procedures described in this section for both skin and oral piercings shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-123. - Permanent cosmetic preparation. 
(a)  Before a body artist shall be licensed to provide permanent cosmetic micropigmentation services, he/she shall provide a certificate of successful completion of a cosmetic micropigmentation application course approved by the board of health. 
(b)  A body artist whose license includes permanent cosmetic micropigmentation services shall not be required to have an ultrasonic cleaner and a hospital grade sterilizer for providing such services if only individually packaged, sterile, single use needles, needle chambers, and combo couplers are used. If any instruments are reused, they must be cleaned in an ultrasonic cleaner and sterilized in a medical grade autoclave. 
(c)  In cases of permanent cosmetic micropigmentation procedures being administered in hair and nail salons, such salons must have a body art establishment permit and meet all the requirements of this article. The services must be provided by a licensed body artist. 
(d)  If a manual device is used, it shall be single use and disposable. The device shall be sterilized before use and discarded into a sharps container at the end of each procedure. 
(e)  The use of some rotary pens (also called cosmetic machines) is permitted. Any rotary pen that uses a sponge at the opening of the chamber to stop the pigment or body fluids from getting into the machine or is designed in a manner that does not allow it to be properly cleaned and sterilized is prohibited. 
(f)  Only rotary machines or other instruments that are engineered to prevent cross contamination through the use of detachable, disposable, auto-clavable components that can be autoclaved shall be used. 
(g)  Fresh pigment and sterile disposable pigment containers shall be used for each client. Used pigment and pigment containers shall be discarded after the completion of body art services on each client. 
(h)  All disposable items such as cotton balls, Q-tips, tissue, water cups, that have come into contact with the client, procedure table, chair or workstation shall be discarded into a closed container lined with a plastic bag and removed at the end of the procedure, if full, or if not full at the end of day. 
(i)  After the area upon which the services were provided has dried, a layer of antibacterial ointment or other approved product from a single use collapsible or plastic tube shall be applied. 
(Ord. No. 11-12, 3-15-2011) 
Sec. 46-124. - After body art application. 
(a)  The completed work of body art shall be washed with a single-use towel saturated with an antimicrobial solution. 
(b)  After the area has dried, apply a layer of antibacterial ointment or other approved product from a single use collapsible or plastic tube. 
(c)  A sterile bandage or dressing shall then be applied to the work of body art using a sealed non-sticking pad or wrap. 
(d)  Verbal and written instructions for the care of the body art procedure site shall be provided to each client by the body artist upon completion of the procedure. The written instructions shall advise the client to consult a physician at the first sign of infection and contain the name, address and phone number of the establishment.
