Damage means to impair or injure the usefulness or value of a person or property. 
Device means a plan or scheme. 
Endanger means to expose to danger or harm. 
Epithets means a derogatory or abusive word or phrase used as a descriptive substitute for the name or title of a person or thing. 
Fighting word means a word used in an argument or quarrel which is assertive or combative. 
Fraudulent scheme means a deliberate plan, deception or trick practiced so as to secure an unfair or unlawful gain over another person. 
Gaming means gambling or betting money on the outcome of a game or contest, or to play a game of chance for stakes. 
Hazardous means dangerous. 
Lawful occupation means any regular employment which is allowed, established, sanctioned or recognized by law. 
Lawful pursuit means any activity regularly engaged in which is allowed, established, sanctioned or recognized by law. 
Obscene means offensive to the accepted standards of decency, or offensive or repulsive to the senses. 
Physically offensive means disagreeable to the senses. 
Provoke means to cause someone or something to take action. 
Public property means any property which is maintained for or used by the people or community. 
Riotous conduct means unrestrained, disorderly or uncontrolled behavior which causes a disturbance of the public peace. 
Trick means an indirect, often deceptive or fraudulent means of achieving an end. 
Tumultuous means confusedly or violently agitated so as to cause commotion, noise or a great disturbance. 
Turmoil means utter confusion or agitation. 
Unlawful activity means an activity engaged in which is not allowed, established, sanctioned or recognized by law. 
Utter means to express by means of speech. 
Violent means characterized or caused by great physical force or rough action. 
(b)  Unlawful actions. Any person who shall do or engage in any of the following in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be guilty of disorderly conduct: 
(1)  Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby any person is placed in danger of safety of his life, limb or health. 
(2)  Act in a violent or tumultuous manner towards another, whereby public property or property of another person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged. 
(3)  Endanger lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence or threats of bodily harm. 
(4)  Cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or property of another or public property. 
(5)  Assemble or congregate with another and cause, provoke or engage in any fight or brawl. 
(6)  Collect in bodies or in crowds, and engage in unlawful activities. 
(7)  Assemble or congregate with another and engage in or attempt to engage in gaming. 
(8)  Frequent any public place and obtain money from another by an illegal and fraudulent scheme, trick, artifice or device, or attempt to do so. 
(9)  Assemble with another and engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain a valuable thing in any place or from any person, or attempt to do so. 
(10)  Utter any obscene word or epithet in a public place or any place open to the public. 
(11)  Frequent any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages, narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated. 
(12)  Use fighting words directed towards any person who becomes outraged and thus creates turmoil. 
(13)  Assemble or congregate with another and do bodily harm to another. 
(14)  By act of violence, interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation. 
(15)  Congregate with another in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and refuse to clear such public way when ordered to do so by a peace officer or other person having authority. 
(16)  Damage, befoul or disturb public property or the property of another so as to create a hazardous, unhealthy or physically offensive condition. 
(17)  Assemble or congregate with others in a group or a crowd of more than five people in the parking lot or on the premises of a business establishment which is open and available to the public, not for the purpose of transacting business at the establishment, but for the purpose of socializing, hanging out or consuming products purchased inside the business establishment, so as to interfere with or hinder the operation of the business activities conducted on the property or in the establishment served by such parking lot or premises by taking up parking spaces which are intended to be available for customers of the business, hampering access to the business establishment or by the existence of a group or crowd in the parking lot or on such premises discouraging potential customers from entering the premises of the business establishment; provided that the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment has complained about the situation to the sheriff's department and the sheriff or his deputy has advised the people in the group or crowd of the complaint of the business establishment, requested all of those in the group or crowd to disperse and move out of the parking lot or on such premises and, after being given the opportunity to comply with the request, the person fails to remove himself from the parking lot or on such premises, or, in the alternative, the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment has posted and maintains, at points clearly visible from the place where the people are assembled or congregated, a sign containing the following information in easy to read print: 
a.  Notice of this section; 
b.  Identification of the property reserved for customer use only; 
c.  Identification of the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment; 
d.  Warning that violators will be prosecuted. 
For purposes of determining whether a group or crowd of more than five people have assembled or congregated in a parking lot or on the premises, separate groups of less than five people engaging in the activity set forth in this subsection (b)(17) may be aggregated to determine the total number of people in the parking lot or on the premises participating in such activity. 
(18)  Assemble or congregate with others in a group or a crowd of more than five people in the parking lot or on the premises of a business establishment which at the time is closed to the public, for the purpose of socializing, hanging out or other similar activities against the wishes of the owner, manager or operator of such business establishment; provided that the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment or his representative has complained about the situation to the sheriff's department and the sheriff or his deputy has advised the people in the group or crowd of the complaint of the business establishment, requested all those in the group or crowd to disperse and move out of the parking lot and, after being given the opportunity to comply with the request, the person fails to remove himself from the parking lot or, in the alternative, the owner, manager or operator of the business establishment or his representative has posted and maintained, at points clearly visible from the place where the people are assembled or congregated, a sign containing the following information in easy to read print: 
a.  Notice of this section; 
b.  Identification of the property on which assembling or congregating is not permitted; 
c.  Identification of the owner of the business establishment; 
d.  Warning that violators will be prosecuted. 
For purposes of determining whether a group or crowd of more than five people have assembled or congregated in a parking lot or on the premises, separate groups of less than five people engaging in the activity set forth in this subsection (b)(18) may be aggregated to determine the total number of people in the parking lot or on the premises participating in such activity. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8.1-6; Ord. of 4-11-1989; Ord. of 7-20-1994) 
Sec. 58-7. - Obscene clothing. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Epithets means a derogatory or abusive word or phrase used as a descriptive substitute for the name or title of a person or thing. 
Lewd means obscene; sexually unchaste. 
Obscene means offensive to accepted standards of decency, or offensive or repulsive to the senses. 
Outerwear clothing means shirts, tee shirts, blouses, pants, skirts, jackets, coats and any other article of clothing which is worn as an outer garment. 
Profane means irreverent; serving to debase or defile what is holy; impure. 
(b)  Unlawful wear. No person shall knowingly affix or attach to any piece of outwear clothing, or wear any piece of outwear clothing, which has affixed or attached to it any sticker, decal, emblem, painting, needlework or other device containing profane or lewd words or epithets describing sexual acts, excretory functions or parts of the human body. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8.1-7; Ord. of 8-15-1989) 
Sec. 58-8. - Use of tobacco products on property owned, leased or controlled by Columbia County, Georgia. 
(a)  The following definitions shall apply to the following terms as they are used in this section: 
(1)  Columbia County, Georgia Property, shall mean and include, but is not limited to, all buildings, land, parking lots, parking decks, greenspace, lawns, parks and any other improvements situated or located thereon owned, leased or controlled by Columbia County, Georgia with the exception of County owned roads which are part of the public road system, Wildwood Park, and existing designated smoking areas located at the Columbia County Detention Center, 2273 County Camp Road and located at County owned fire stations, which designated areas shall not be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Tobacco product shall mean any product derived from cultivated tobacco, including but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, bidis, kreteks and pipes. 
(b)  Commissioners, officers, administrators, staff, employees, visitors, vendors, contractors and all others are prohibited from smoking of any tobacco product while on Columbia County, Georgia Property. Use of tobacco products in vehicles that are being operated on or are parked on Columbia County, Georgia Property is prohibited. 
(c)  Any person who violates this section, shall, upon conviction be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8.1-8; Ord. of 4-7-1993; Ord. No. 11-14, § 1, 6-22-2011) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 18. 
Sec. 58-9. - Trespassing upon; tampering with any railroad switch; damaging or obstructing railroad property, equipment or machinery or getting on or off any locomotive engine, railroad car, trailer, container, equipment or machinery. 
(a)  No person shall trespass upon the tracks, rights-of-way, yards, piggy-back facilities, buildings, trestles or other properties located in the unincorporated area of Columbia County and belonging to or in the possession of any railroad company operating in the unincorporated area of Columbia County. 
(b)  No person shall tamper with or damage any railroad switch, wire, line, signal or other property located in the unincorporated area of Columbia County or place any object on railroad tracks which obstruct the movements or operation of a train or which could cause a train to be damaged or derailed while operating in the unincorporated area of Columbia County. 
(c)  No person shall get on or off any locomotive engine, railroad car, trailer, container or other machinery or equipment located in the unincorporated area of Columbia County belonging to or in the possession of a railroad company operating in Columbia County. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to any person acting with the authority or permission of the railroad company which owns or is in possession of the property in question. 
(Ord. No. 04-09, § 1, 10-19-2004) 
Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference— Establishment of recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Hours of operation of public parks. 
All public parks located in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be open from 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. each day, unless otherwise posted at the entrances to such parks; provided, however, the hours when public parks are closed shall not apply to persons using the parks for purposes of launching or removing boats, fishing or camping in areas designated for camping within such parks. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-1) 
Sec. 62-2. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited in public parks. 
No person shall use, possess or consume any alcoholic beverage within any public park located in the unincorporated areas of the county. For the purposes of this section, the term "alcoholic beverage" means beer, wine, liquor or malt beverage as defined by section 6-2 of this Code. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-2) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
Sec. 62-3. - Violation; penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-3; Ord. No. 00-10, § 11, 10-3-2000) 
Secs. 62-4—62-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards and commissioners, § 2-31 et seq. 

Sec. 62-36. - Established. 
There is established and created in and for the county, a recreation board which shall consist of seven members who shall serve without pay. The terms of the current members of the recreation board shall terminate on December 31, 2007. The members of the recreation board shall be appointed as provided for in the bylaws for the recreation board promulgated by resolution of the board of commissioners for the operation of the recreation board. The members of the recreation board appointed to terms beginning on January 1, 2008, or thereafter shall serve for the terms specified in the bylaws. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-11; Ord. No. 07-11, § 1, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 62-37. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies on the recreation board shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term as provided for in the bylaws of the recreation board. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-12; Ord. No. 07-11, § 2, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 62-38. - Recreation director. 
The recreation director, employed by the board of commissioners, is made a member of the recreation board. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-13) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-186 et seq. 
Sec. 62-39. - Officers. 
The officers and their appointment shall be as provided for in the bylaws of the recreation board. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-14; Ord. No. 07-11, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 62-40. - Meetings. 
Meetings of the recreation board shall be held and conducted as provided for in the bylaws of the recreation board. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-15; Ord. No. 07-11, § 4, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 62-41. - Reports. 
The recreating board shall make reports as provided for in the bylaws of the recreation board. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-16; Ord. No. 07-11, § 5, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 62-42. - Functions. 
(a)  The recreation board shall provide advice and recommendations to the board of commissioners, the director of the department of county government which oversees the recreation programs in the county and the recreation director as to the improvement of the recreation services then being provided, the addition of new recreation services, the deletion of existing recreation services, ways to raise funds to support recreation services in the county, recreational facilities that are needed and any other matters that bear upon the scope and quality of the county's recreational program. If a vacancy occurs in the position of recreation director, the recreation board may provide advice and recommendations as to candidates to fill such position. 
(b)  The recreation board may organize and conduct fundraising events and activities to raise funds for the support and improvement of the recreation program in the county. All funds raised by the recreation board shall be deposited in a special account of the county to be designated as the recreation program enhancement fund (hereinafter referred to as the "fund"). These funds shall not be used to offset funds that would otherwise be spent from the general fund and other sources of county revenues to pay for the operations and capital improvements necessary to conduct the county's recreation program. Money in the fund shall be used for training, equipment, capital projects and other expenses or costs designated to ensure that the recreation program in the county is first class and excels above those of other counties. 
(c)  The recreation board shall annually prepare a report of its activities during the preceding year and a proposed budget for the fund, to be presented to the board of commissioners in the spring of each year as part of its budgetary process. Once the budget is approved by the board of commissioners, it shall guide the use of the money in the fund during the ensuing July 1 through June 30 fiscal year. During the fiscal year, the budget may be modified by the board of commissioners as circumstances dictate. The recreation board may submit recommendations to the board of commissioners as to modifications in the approved budget when the recreation board determines such modifications to be desirable. 
(d)  The recreation board shall, throughout the fiscal year, submit requisitions to the county finance department for the disbursement of money in the fund to pay for the projects as designated in the approved budget or approved modifications to the budget. The expenditure of money in the fund shall be administered by the county's financial officials, as are other county funds, provided that requests by the recreation board for expenditures from the fund consistent with the approved budget shall require no further action on the part of the board of commissioners, unless shortfalls in the budgeted revenues shall result in insufficient money in the fund to meet the requested expenditure. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-17) 
Sec. 62-43. - Status of recreation director. 
Nothing contained in this article shall be construed or interpreted to change, alter or modify the status of the recreation director as an employee of and responsible to the county board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10.5-18) 
Secs. 62-44—62-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC SWIMMING POOLS, SPAS AND RECREATIONAL WATER PARKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02-7, § 1, adopted July 16, 2002, amended art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1979, §§ 2-7.1-1—2-7.1-35. 
Cross reference— Zoning, ch. 90. 

Sec. 62-76. - Applicability. 
This article shall apply to all public swimming pools. The term "public swimming pool" shall be defined to mean any structure, chamber or tank containing an artificial body of water used by the public for swimming, diving, wading, recreation or therapy, together with buildings, appurtenances and equipment used in connection with the body of water, regardless of whether a fee is charged for its use. The term includes municipal, school, hotel or motel pools and any pool to which access is granted in exchange for payment of a daily fee. The term shall also include pools and spas operated by or serving camps, churches, day care centers, group home facilities of twelve or more clients, institutions, parks, state agencies, apartment complexes, subdivisions, condominiums, country clubs, mobile home parks, recreational vehicle parks, associations, health clubs, special purpose pools, and recreational water park attractions. 
(Ord. No. 02-7, § 1, 7-16-2002 
Sec. 62-77. - Rules and regulations. 
The operation and maintenance of public swimming pools shall be according to the provisions set forth in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Section 31-45-4 through Section 31-45-11 and regulations of the Georgia Department of Human Resources Public Health, Chapter 290-5-57, "Swimming Pools, Spas and Recreation Water Parks", as amended from time to time, such rules and regulations being incorporated into and made a part of this Code, subject to the enforcement provisions in this article. 
(Ord. No. 02-7, § 1, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 62-78. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The county board of health or its authorized agent shall be authorized to enforce this article, and to enter upon and inspect the premises of any public swimming pool covered under this article. 
(b)  Each and every public swimming pool subject to inspection under the provisions of this article shall be required to pay to the county board of health an annual inspection fee as determined by the board of health and approved by the board of commissioners, due within 30 days of receipt of notification from the county board of health. Failure to pay such fee shall be considered in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The county board of health or its authorized agent shall be authorized to issue citations for violations of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 02-7, § 1, 7-16-2002) 
Sec. 62-79. - Violation; penalties. 
Any party who shall violate any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalties as set forth in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-7, § 1, 7-6-2002) 
Chapter 66 - ROADS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; mobile homes and trailers, ch. 54; subdivisions, ch. 74; road and bridge operation and maintenance regulations adopted by reference, § 82-1; water and sewers, ch. 86. 
State Law reference— Governmental authorization for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; county road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Authority to order removal and relocation of utility facilities; notice; failure to remove. 
(a)  Any utility using or occupying any part of a public road which the county has undertaken to improve or intends to improve shall remove and relocate such utility's facility when, in the reasonable opinion of the county, the facility constitutes an obstruction or interference with the use or safe operation of such road by the traveling public, or when, in the reasonable opinion of the county, the facility will interfere with any contemplated construction or maintenance. 
(b)  Whenever the county reasonably determines it necessary to have a utility facility removed and relocated, the county shall give the utility at least 60 days' written notice directing the removal and relocation of such obstruction. If the utility does not begin removal of such obstruction within a reasonable time sufficient to allow for engineering and other procedures reasonably necessary to the removal and relocation of such facility, the county may give the utility a final notice directing that such removal shall commence not later than ten days from the receipt of such final notice. If the utility does not, within such ten-day period, begin to remove or relocate the facility or, having so begun removal or relocation, fails to complete the removal or relocation within a reasonable time, the county may remove or relocate the facility with its own employees, or by employing or contracting for the necessary engineering, labor, tools, equipment, supervision or other necessary services or materials, and whatever else is necessary to accomplish the removal or relocation of such facility; and the expense of such removal or relocation may be paid and collected as provided in section 66-3. 
(Code 1979, § 2-11.5-1) 
Sec. 66-2. - Authority to obtain replacement right-of-way for relocated utility. 
(a)  Whenever a public road improvement necessitates the acquisition by the county of a utility's privately owned rights-of-way and the relocation of such utility's facilities, the county may, with the written consent of the utility, provide a replacement right-of-way. 
(b)  Whenever a public road improvement requires the relocation of a utility occupying public road rights-of-way, the county may, at the written request of such utility, provide to the utility a right-of-way which is not on a public road right-of-way, and the utility shall reimburse the county for the acquisition costs. 
(c)  Title to property acquired for utility relocation under subsection (a) or (b) of this section, and as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 32-3-1 may be transferred to such utility, however, the procedures for sale of property as set forth in O.G.C.A. § 32-7-4 shall not be applicable to the transfer of property acquired for utility relocation or property on which utilities are located, pursuant to O.G.C.A. § 32-7-3. Any such property transfer to the utility shall be conveyed by the execution of a quit claim deed by the county board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-11.5-2; Ord. No. 02-3, § 1, 3-5-2002) 
Sec. 66-3. - Payment of expenses of removal and relocation of utility facilities. 
The expenses incurred by the county as a result of utility removal and relocation pursuant to section 66-1(b), including the cost of acquiring new land or interest therein pursuant to section 66-2(b), shall be paid out of the available appropriations of the county for the construction or maintenance of public roads. A statement of such expenses shall be submitted to the utility, which shall make payment to the county. If the utility does not make payment or arrange to make payment to the county within 60 days after the receipt of such statement, the county shall certify the amount for collection to the county attorney. Nothing in this section shall be construed so as to deprive any utility compensation for such property interest. 
(Code 1979, § 2-11.5-3) 
Sec. 66-4. - Prohibition of installation on county property of private utilities. 
(a)  No pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, pumps, ditches or similar materials, equipment or facilities shall be installed or maintained in the road rights-of-way or other property of Columbia County by any person or other entity who is not engaged in the business of providing the utility service to the general public and who is installing such items, equipment or facilities solely for the purpose of serving a small number of properties, herein referred to as "private utilities". 
(b)  Neither Columbia County nor any of the public utility providers shall allow a private utility to tap onto or hook up to or otherwise obtain the use of the utility service being provided from its utility lines or systems anywhere within the rights-of-way or property of Columbia County or in any instance where the tap or hook up may be located on private property but the private utility then runs through Columbia County right-of-way or other Columbia County property. Where any tap or connection of a private utility to a public utility system occurs or is discovered which is in violation of this section, it shall be disconnected by Columbia County or the public utility provider to whose lines or system the private utility is attached, as the case may be, after 30 days' prior written notice of the disconnection is given to the owners and occupants (if different from the owners) of the property served by the private utility. This section shall not apply to a private utility which has been installed prior to March 5, 2002 and which has been, prior to such date, and is continuing to be maintained pursuant to a written agreement with Columbia County for as long as such agreement shall remain in force. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to the installation of utility lines or other utility facilities in Columbia County's road rights-of-way or its other property which work is done with the prior written approval of Columbia County and which are to be conveyed and dedicated to Columbia County upon completion of the construction or installation thereof and acceptance by the county. In addition, this section shall not apply to any utility line installed to connect a property to a public utility line or system where the connection is made within a Columbia County right-of-way or other Columbia County property at a point immediately adjacent to the property to be served. 
(d)  Developers of subdivisions which are located in zoning districts providing for professional, commercial or industrial uses may apply to the county for an easement to place water lines, valves and sprinkler heads which are part of a private irrigation system within the public road rights-of-way located within the subdivision. Such easements must be requested at or before the time of filing with the county the preliminary subdivision plat pursuant to section 74-37 of this Code. The 'as built' location of the water lines and sprinkler heads within the public rights-of-way must be shown on the final subdivision plat before it shall be approved by the planning commission pursuant to subsection 74-39(c) of this Code and before the public facilities shown on the final plat are accepted by the board of commissioners. The granting of such an easement shall lie within the sole discretion of the board of commissioners. The terms of the easement agreement pursuant to which the county may grant an easement for these private irrigation systems, shall include but not be limited to, a requirement that an owners association must be formed as a Georgia nonprofit corporation (the "association") and provisions made therefore in covenants running with the land applicable to all of the lots located within the subdivision. The association shall be required to maintain, repair and replace the private irrigation system, to pay for the water purchased from the county for such irrigation system and to otherwise administer the operation of the irrigation system and to what assessment from all members of the association to pay for the expenses incurred by the association. The easement shall terminate and the county may disable or remove the irrigation system from its rights-of-way if the association fails to carry out its functions and or obligations under the easement agreement. The developer and the principals thereof shall guarantee the obligations of the owners association for a period that ends ten years after the developer or any affiliate of the developer last owned any interest or held any lien, security interest or security title in any lot in the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 02-2, § 3, 3-5-2002; Ord. No. 06-06, § 1, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 66-5. - Promulgation of regulations. 
The county may promulgate reasonable regulations governing the installation, fees, construction, maintenance, renewal, removal and relocation of pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, towers, tracks, traffic and other such signals, and other equipment and appliances of any utility in, on, along, over or under any part of the county road system which the county has undertaken or agreed to undertake, or which has been completed by the county, pursuant to its authority, in addition to the requirements of such county regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 2-11.5-4; Ord. No. 02-2, § 1, 3-5-2002) 
Sec. 66-6. - Right to injunctive relief. 
(a)  The county may petition for an injunction to enforce the performance of any duty or act imposed by this article, or for an order to restrain the breach of any duty or the commission of any act imposed, prohibited or unauthorized by this article. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this article, or fails to comply with the requirements of this article, including any regulation promulgated by the county, shall be subject to penalties and fines as set forth in section 1-9. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. The owner of any utility, its agents, representatives, employees or other person who commits, participates in, assists in or maintains such violation may each be found guilty of a separate offense and suffer the penalties set forth in this subsection. 
(Code 1979, § 2-11.5-5; Ord. No. 02-2, § 2, 3-5-2002) 
Secs. 66-7—66-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ROAD REGISTER AND OFFICIAL MAP 

Sec. 66-36. - General intent. 
The intent of the road register and official map is to establish the jurisdiction of the county in maintaining public roads; develop a functional classification and standards for road rights-of-way; identify the roads to be maintained and improved by federal, state and county funds; and establish procedures for the administration, use and amendment of the road register and official map. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-2) 
Sec. 66-37. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all roads in the unincorporated areas of the county, and those designated county roads located inside city limits. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-3) 
Sec. 66-38. - Functional classification system and standards for road rights-of-way. 
(a)  For the purposes of classifying county roads by their functional use, the following categories of roads and required rights-of-way are established: 

 
(b)  The standards for road rights-of-way shall be used in reviewing and approving proposed subdivisions of land within the county as provided in chapter 74 of this Code. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-4) 
Sec. 66-39. - Created; content; conflict. 
(a)  There is created in the county an official document known as the Road Register of Columbia County, Georgia. Such register shall be amended, from time to time, by resolution of the board of commissioners, using the local certification authorization (L.C.A.) form. 
(b)  There is created in the county an official document known as the Official Map of Columbia County, Georgia. Such official map shall be adopted, from time to time, by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(c)  The road register and the official map of the county identify the roads to be maintained and improved by federal, state and county funds within the county. 
(d)  The road register shall contain an alphabetical listing of county maintained roads and a numerical listing of county road numbers. 
(e)  The official map of the county shall contain a graphic representation of the road register. 
(f)  All county owned and maintained roads shall be listed in the road register. 
(g)  In case of a conflict between the road register and the official map of the county, the road register shall control. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-5) 
Sec. 66-40. - Administration; use; amendment. 
(a)  The road register and official map of the county shall be maintained by the director of engineering services. The road register and official map of the county are to be used for the following purposes: 
(1)  Establish priority in funding road improvements by determining functional use and required rights-of-way; and 
(2)  Establish standards for rights-of-way acquisition as part of subdivision plat approval. 
(b)  The road register and official map of the county may, from time to time, be amended by resolution of the board of commissioners, using the local certification authorization (L.C.A.) form. Any proposed amendments shall first be submitted to the engineering services committee for its review. All approved amendments shall be submitted to the state department of transportation through use of a local certification authorization form. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-6; Ord. No. 17-08 , § 17(Exh. Q), 2-6-2018) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-186 et seq. 
Chapter 68 - SISTER CITY PROGRAM[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, adopted June 18, 2002, established a Sister City Program designated as chapter 2-68; however, said provisions have been redesignated as chapter 68 at the discretion of the editor, with the concurrence of the county, for purposes of maintaining Code format. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 68-1. - Sister City Program. 
Nowy Sacz, Poland is hereby declared to be an official Sister City of Columbia County. Columbia County will maintain and foster a Sister City relationship with Nowy Sacz, Poland. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
ARTICLE II. - SISTER CITY ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 68-2. - Creation of advisory board. 
There is established and created in and for Columbia County, Georgia a Sister City Advisory Board (the "advisory board") to consist of seven members who shall serve without pay. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 02-10, § 1, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 07-10, § 1, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 68-3. - Members of the advisory board. 
(a)  The terms of all current members of the advisory board shall terminate on December 31, 2007. The members of the advisory board shall be appointed as provided for in the bylaws promulgated by resolution of the board of commissioners for the operation of the advisory board, and the terms of such members shall be as specified in the bylaws. 
(b)  The county administrator and the director of the community and leisure services division shall serve as ex officio members with vote of the advisory board for so long as such person shall hold such position. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 02-10, § 3, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 07-10, § 2, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 68-4. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies on the advisory board shall be filled as provided for in the bylaws of the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 07-10, § 3, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 68-5. - Officers. 
The officers of the advisory board shall be as provided for in the bylaws and shall be elected as provided for in the bylaws. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 07-10, § 4, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 68-6. - Meetings. 
The advisory board shall meet and conduct its meetings as provided in the bylaws of the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 07-10, § 5, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 68-7. - Reports. 
The advisory board shall provide reports as required in the bylaws of the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 07-10, § 6, 11-6-2007) 
Sec. 68-8. - Functions. 
(a)  The advisory board shall provide advice and recommendation to the board of commissioners, the county administrator, and the director of the community and leisure services division as to ways to improve the sister city program, the addition of new activities to the sister city program, the deletion of existing activities from the sister city program, ways to raise funds to support the sister city program, and any other matters that bear upon the scope and quality of the sister city program. In the event a vacancy occurs in the position of an "ambassador of goodwill", the advisory board may, but is not required to, provide advice and recommendations to the board of commissioners as to candidates to fill such position. 
(b)  The advisory board may organize and conduct fundraising events and activities to raise funds for the support and improvement of the sister city program. All funds raised by the sister city program shall be deposited in a special account of the county to be designated the "sister city program enhancement fund" (hereinafter referred to as the "fund"). These funds shall not be used to offset funds that would otherwise be spent from other sources of county revenues to pay for the operation and improvement of the sister city program. The money in the fund shall be used for other expenses or costs including, but not limited to, travel, cultural programs and costs of entertaining visiting delegates, designated to ensure that the sister city program in the county is first class and excels above those of other governmental entities. 
(c)  The advisory board shall annually prepare a proposed budget for the fund, to be presented to the board of commissioners in the spring of each year as part of its budgetary process. Once approved by the board of commissioners, this budget shall guide the use of the money in the fund during the ensuing July 1 through June 30 fiscal year. During the fiscal year, this budget may be modified by the board of commissioners as circumstances dictate. The advisory board may submit recommendations to the board of commissioners as to modifications in the approved budget when the advisory board determines modifications to be desirable. 
(d)  The advisory board shall, throughout the fiscal year, submit requisitions to the county financial services division for the disbursement of money in the fund to pay for projects as designated in the approved budget, or to approved modifications thereto. The expenditure of money in the fund shall be administered by the county's financial officers, as are other funds; provided that requests by the advisory board for expenditures from the fund consistent with the approved budget shall require no further action on the part of the board of commissioners, unless shortfalls in the budget or revenues shall result in insufficient money in order to meet the requested expenditure. 
(e)  The advisory board may attempt to facilitate the establishment and growth of the Ginny Husen Scholarship Fund. However, as this will be a private charitable fund and not a county fund, the advisory board shall not solicit donations for or make contributions to the scholarship fund. This shall not prevent members of the advisory board, acting in their individual capacities, from undertaking such activities as long as they make it clear that they are not acting in the name of Columbia County. 
(Ord. No. 02-6, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Dead animals, § 14-13; buildings and building construction, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 46; mobile homes and trailers, ch. 54; water and sewers, ch. 86. 
State Law reference— Local, multijurisdictional and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; solid waste management education program, establishment of Georgia Clean and Beautiful Advisory Committee and Interagency Council on Solid Waste Management, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-7.3. 

Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Litter means all discarded sand, gravel, brickbats, rubbish, nonfunctioning motor vehicle parts, small appliances, appliance parts, waste material, tin cans, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals or other discarded materials of every kind and description, which are not defined as "waste" in this section. 
Private property means any property owned by a private person. 
Public property means the right-of-way of any public road or highway; any publicly owned or controlled body of water or watercourse; any public park, playground, refuge, conservation or recreation area; and any other land or buildings owned by the United States, the state or any governmental entity, agency or political subdivision of the state or the United States. 
Responsible authority means the county engineering and environmental services division, or any other division of the county government designated by the board of commissioners to implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter, or its authorized representatives, together with the county sheriff's office. 
Scrap tire means any tire which is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage or defect. 
Waste means all discarded substances and materials exceeding ten pounds in weight or 15 cubic feet in volume, or any such substance of any weight or volume if biomedical waste, hazardous waste (as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-62), a hazardous substance (as such term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-92) or any such substance or material dumped for commercial purposes. This term includes, but is not limited to, bottles; boxes; containers; papers, tobacco products; tires; appliances; mechanical equipment or parts; building or construction materials; tools; machinery; wood; motor vehicles and motor vehicle parts; vessels; aircraft equipment; waste oil; batteries; antifreeze; sludge from a wastewater treatment facility, water supply treatment plant or air pollution control facility; discarded material; or substance of any kind or description resulting from domestic, industrial, commercial, mining or governmental operations, including household, commercial, construction and demolition waste or industrial solid waste which is nonhazardous, nonmedical and in a form classified as solid waste by the state department of natural resources. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-2. - Functions of the responsible authority. 
In order to protect the health, safety and welfare of the people of the county and those temporarily located in the county, the responsible authority is authorized and directed to implement and enforce the provisions of this chapter, and in doing so, to control the storage, collection and disposal of litter and waste within the county, to operate the county's landfill and any other litter and waste collection and disposal facilities, equipment or systems owned and/or operated by the county to approve and regulate the establishment, maintenance and operation of private litter and waste collection systems, and litter and waste disposal methods and sites. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-2) 
Sec. 70-3. - Funds. 
The board of commissioners may make funds available by appropriation, borrowing, collecting fees and charges and operating an enterprise fund or other means, in accordance with the laws of the state and the county, to purchase or lease equipment for the disposal of litter and waste, and for the establishment, maintenance and operation of waste and litter collection systems and disposal methods, facilities and sites. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-3) 
Sec. 70-4. - Disposal. 
(a)  The person which is the owner, user and/or occupant of any land and/or building in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be responsible for the sanitary and proper handling and disposition of litter, waste and scrap tires generated on or located on the land and/or in the building owned, used or occupied by such person. It shall be unlawful to dump, deposit, throw, leave or cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter, waste or scrap tires at any place in the unincorporated areas of the county, including, without limitation, any public or private property, lakes, streams, rivers, ponds or other waters in the unincorporated areas of the county, or which flow through the unincorporated areas of the county, unless the: 
(1)  Property is designed as a solid waste landfill, transfer station or other solid waste disposal site, and properly permitted by the state for such use; or 
(2)  Litter or waste is placed into a receptacle or container installed or maintained on such property for the temporary storage of litter or waste; provided, however, that any litter or waste placed into such receptacle or container must not be allowed to accumulate to the point of overflowing the container or receptacle, or to a point where the container or receptacle cannot be closed. All litter or waste stored in such fashion must be transported to a facility as set forth in subsection (a)(1) of this section within 14 days of being placed in the receptacle or container. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, unless authorized to do so by law or by a duly issued permit, for any person to dump or place waste or litter in or on any: 
(1)  Public highway, road, street, alley, right-of-way or thoroughfare, or on any other public land, except for the placing of litter or waste in containers lawfully provided for the temporary storage of such litter or waste. 
(2)  Fresh water lake, river, canal, pond, stream or creek. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-4) 
Sec. 70-5. - Litter and waste acceptable for disposal. 
(a)  No substance or material shall be placed in any landfill, transfer station or other type of solid waste collection or disposal facility or system owned and/or operated by the county which would cause such facility or system to be in violation of any applicable federal or state law, rule or regulation. The board of commissioners, by resolution adopted from time to time, may limit or restrict the types of substances or materials which may be placed in any landfill, transfer station or other type of solid waste disposal facility which is owned or operated by the county. 
(b)  Yard trimmings shall not be placed in or mixed with solid waste. Yard trimmings include, but are not limited to, grass clippings, leaves, pine straw, shrubbery and limbs. Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any solid waste disposal facility which has liners and a leachate collection system or requires vertical expansion within the county. Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stockpiled, or chipped, composted, used as mulch or otherwise beneficially reused or recycled to the maximum extent feasible. Yard trimmings which are to be collected by any person other than the property owner shall be sorted and stored in such a manner as to facilitate collection, composting or other handling. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-5) 
Sec. 70-6. - Transporting. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to drive or operate a vehicle in the county hauling wet or moist litter or waste which vehicle allows such material to leak, flow freely or spill from such vehicle. 
(b)  Any litter or waste hauled on a moving vehicle in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be placed in an enclosed area of the vehicle, or covered or secured by a tarpaulin or other form of covering or restraint device adequately tied or anchored in such a manner that the litter or waste will not blow or escape from such vehicle while such vehicle is moving or is parked on public or private streets or roadways in the county. 
(c)  Vehicles used for the collection and transportation of waste or litter in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be maintained in good repair, have watertight, metal bodies of easily cleanable construction, and shall be kept sufficiently clean so as to prevent the creation of offensive or noxious odors, insect or rodent habitation, unsightly conditions or other conditions that would constitute a nuisance. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-6) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 
Sec. 70-7. - Regulation of containers and receptacles. 
(a)  Each waste or litter container or receptacle in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be maintained in as sanitary a condition as is reasonably possible consistent with such container's or receptacle's use for waste and litter disposal, and shall not be allowed to create strong, offensive or noxious odors, serve as an insect or rodent feeding area or habitat, become unsightly or cause other conditions which would constitute a nuisance. 
(b)  Every person disposing of waste or litter in the unincorporated areas of the county shall place such waste or litter into containers or receptacles designed to temporarily store such waste or litter, or directly into the landfill, transfer station or other facility intended and properly permitted by the state for the disposal of waste and litter. 
(c)  No person shall deposit any burning or smoldering material in waste or litter containers or receptacles located in the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(d)  No person shall set fire to the contents of any waste or litter container or receptacle, scatter the contents thereof or otherwise vandalize, damage or destroy such container or receptacle. 
(e)  No dead animal shall be deposited in any waste or litter container or receptacle. All dead animals shall be disposed of as provided for in the Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq., and chapter 14 of this Code. 
(f)  No person shall deposit large noncompatible articles in waste or litter containers or receptacles, including, but not limited to, stoves, refrigerators, other appliances, bed springs, mattresses, scrap tires, air conditioning units or similar items. 
(g)  No person shall deposit any explosive material in any waste or litter container or receptacle. 
(h)  No person shall place or store litter or waste in the area surrounding waste or litter containers or receptacles, which is not itself in a waste or litter container or receptacle. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-7) 
Sec. 70-8. - Accumulation. 
(a)  No owner or occupant of any land or building in the unincorporated areas of the county shall allow litter or waste to accumulate on such land or in such building, or shall bury or burn litter or waste on such land or in such building without prior authorization and permission from the applicable regulatory agencies, including, but not limited to, the environmental protection division of the Environmental Protection Agency and/or the state forestry service. Nothing in this subsection shall authorize or be construed to permit the burial or burning of any material which is otherwise prohibited by federal or state law, rule or regulation. 
(b)  No owner or occupant of any land or building in the unincorporated areas of the county shall allow the creation on such land or in such building of a health hazard to neighbors, other citizens or members of the general public, the creation of an unsightly condition or the emission of foul or obnoxious odors as a result of the accumulation of litter or waste. 
(c)  Any person who owns, uses or occupies any land or building in the unincorporated areas of the county shall be responsible for contracting with a properly licensed commercial hauler, or otherwise providing for the collection of such waste and litter, and disposal of such waste and litter at a properly permitted and licensed solid waste disposal facility, on a regular and frequent basis. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-8) 
Sec. 70-9. - Enforcement. 
Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the county sheriff or his designee, and any other official of the county designated by the board of commissioners. Any person authorized to enforce this chapter shall do so in conformance with the laws of the United States and the state, including, but not limited to, the laws relating to searches. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-10) 
Sec. 70-10. - Civil remedies and abatement of nuisance. 
If any person violates any provision of this chapter, the county attorney or other appropriate authority of the county may, in addition to criminal prosecution and other remedies, institute an action for injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful act or to correct or abate such violation. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-11) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 34-31 et seq. 
Sec. 70-11. - Evidence of violation. 
(a)  Whenever litter or waste is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane or other means of conveyance in violation of this chapter, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the means of conveyance has violated this chapter. 
(b)  Whenever any litter or waste is dumped, deposited, dropped, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this chapter and such litter or waste is discovered to contain any article, including, but not limited to, letters, bills, publications or other writings, which display the name of the person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-12) 
Sec. 70-12. - Recycling. 
The board of commissioners finds that it is in the best interest of the citizens of the county, in order to promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the county, to recycle as many waste materials as possible in order to reduce the accumulation of litter and waste within the county and to reduce the overall solid waste materials which must be properly disposed of; therefor, it is the policy of the county to encourage recycling whenever practicable. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-13) 
Sec. 70-13. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any portion of this chapter, and each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  By penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9; 
(2)  In addition, the violator may be ordered to perform community service for a specified number of hours which may, in the discretion of the court in which the conviction is obtained, consist of picking up and removing from any public property in the county all litter and waste located on such public property; 
(3)  In the sound discretion of the court in which conviction of a violation of this chapter is obtained, the convicted person may be ordered to pick up and remove from any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that the person has deposited waste or litter, all waste and litter deposited on such private property by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence, provided that permission of the owner of such private property is first obtained; and 
(4)  The court shall order the violator of this chapter to pay all court costs for such action. 
(b)  If the violation of this chapter involves the ownership, maintenance or operation of a litter or waste disposal site not permitted by this chapter or by federal or state law, rules or regulations, the property owner, user, occupant or other person responsible for the property shall cause the property to be cleaned up. The county shall not be responsible for any costs of cleanup or remediation. Use of the property for such purpose must cease until the property is brought into compliance and all necessary permits are obtained. 
(Code 1979, § 2-12.5-9; Ord. No. 00-10, § 12, 10-3-2000) 
Chapter 74 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Buildings and building construction, ch. 18; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; mobile homes and trailers, ch. 54; individual lot mobile homes, mobile offices and mobile home subdivisions, § 54-96 et seq.; roads, ch. 66; water and sewers, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Approval by planning commission or governing authority on plat of subdivision required for filing or recording in superior court clerk's office, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(d). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Promote the public health, safety and general welfare; 
(2)  Promote the orderly and beneficial development and expansion of communities within the county; 
(3)  Provide adequate light and air; 
(4)  Provide adequate water, sewerage and surface drainage; 
(5)  Prevent undesirable overcrowding of population; 
(6)  Secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; 
(7)  Promote the orderly and desirable subdivision of land; 
(8)  Ensure the orderly and desirable development of streets; 
(9)  Promote the orderly and desirable development of public utilities and services; 
(10)  Provide adequate and sufficient land for schools, parks, playgrounds and other public uses; and 
(11)  Ensure proper legal description and monumentation of all subdivided land. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-1) 
Sec. 74-2. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  This chapter shall govern all subdivision of land within the legal boundaries of the county as established, except for that area lying within the planning jurisdiction of any incorporated town in the county. 
(b)  In this chapter, the term "subdivision" means the division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites or other divisions for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy or building development, and includes all such division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision. 
(c)  In this chapter, the term "subdivider" means any person, firm or corporation having such a proprietary interest in the land to be subdivided as will authorize the maintenance of proceedings to subdivide such land under this chapter, or the authorized agent of such person, firm or corporation for the purpose of proceeding under this chapter. 
(d)  Any owner of land within the county wishing to subdivide such land shall submit to the county planning commission a plat of the subdivision according to the procedures outlined in article II of this chapter, which plat shall conform to the minimum requirements set forth in article III of this chapter. Improvements shall be made as set forth in article IV of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-2) 
Sec. 74-3. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense; words in the singular number shall include the plural, and words in the plural number shall include the singular; the term "shall" is always mandatory and not directory; and the word "may" is permissive. 
Arteries mean the major and minor arterial roads and major and minor collector roads classified as such in the county's growth management plan, as most recently adopted or amended. 
Arteries, limited access primary, means the primary arteries of considerably higher speeds and volumes; where intersections, land access and traffic effects warrant a high degree of control, even prohibition in some cases. 
Arteries, primary, means the major streets classified as Major Arterials in the county's growth management plan, as most recently adopted or amended. 
Arteries, secondary, means the major streets classified as Minor Arterials in the county's growth management plan, as most recently adopted or amended. 
Board of Commissioners means the board of commissioners of Columbia County, Georgia. 
Building setback line, front, means the minimum allowable distance between the centerline of an abutting street or an official future street, and the front of a building or structure on a lot. The front setback distance applies to the full width of the lot and is parallel to or concentric with the street centerline. 
Building Setback Lines 
Centerline means the line determined as the centerline by the official authority having jurisdiction over the street; otherwise it shall be the succession of midpoints between the identifiable limits of any improvements on the ground or of any easement. 
Clerk of superior court means the clerk of the superior court of the county. 
Collector street means the major streets classified as Major Collectors and Minor Collectors in the county's growth management plan, as most recently adopted or amended. 
Columbia County Growth Management Plan means the plan document and accompanying maps adopted by the county pursuant to the Georgia Comprehensive Planning Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-1 et seq., and the Minimum Standards and Procedures for Local Comprehensive Planning adopted by the Georgia Board of Community Affairs, and as may be most recently amended. 
County attorney means the Columbia County Attorney. 
County engineer means the Columbia County Engineer. 
County health officer means the Columbia County Health Officer. 
Cul-de-sac means a land service street that terminates in dead-end turnarounds, and is not intended for future extension. 
Dedicated to public use means land or improvements that has or have been deeded to and accepted by the county for public use and maintenance. 
Deflection angle means the angle between a deviation in the direction of the centerline of a street and the extension of the centerline along a straight course from the point from which the centerline changed direction. (See the following diagram.) 
Double frontage means the incidence where a lot, tract or parcel of land abuts the rights-of-way of more than one public street. 
Easement means a strip of land on which the property owner has granted a person the right to use such land for specific purposes, or the grant of such a right. 
Final plat means a complete and exact plat of a completed subdivision prepared for submission to the planning commission as required by this chapter. 
Hearing means a public review of a subdivision plat during an open meeting of the planning commission. 
Improvements mean the physical additions and changes to land that may be necessary to produce usable, desirable and acceptable lots. 
Intersection means the point at which the centerline of a street intersects the centerline of another street or railway. 
Loop street means a land service street of short length and of such design as to originate and terminate in a "T" intersection with another street. (See the following diagram.) 
Major road plan means the portion of the county's growth management plan that sets out a plan for the future development or classification of major streets and roads in the county. 
Master sewerage plan means the long-range master plan for the development of a public sewerage system as adopted by the board of commissioners. 
On-site disposal means the disposal of sewage from an individual use into the ground, septic tank, grease trap or elsewhere, except into a public or private sewerage system. 
Planning commission means the Columbia County Planning Commission as created in section 90-4 of this Code. 
Plat of record means: 
(1)  An abbreviated version of the final plat of a subdivision that is prepared as required by this chapter for filing with the clerk of superior court; or 
(2)  The filed final plat of a subdivision. 
Preliminary plat means a plat of a proposed subdivision of land which is prepared and submitted in accordance with this chapter. 
Private road means private access from a public road to land abutting on the right-of-way thereof, and roads which are not maintained or owned by the county. 
Registered engineer means a professional engineer licensed and registered to perform the duties of an engineer. 
Registered surveyor means a land surveyor licensed and registered to perform the duties of a land surveyor. 
Reserve strip means a strip or tract of land reserved for the purpose of controlling or limiting access from properties to abutting streets. 
Reverse frontage means a lot or tract of land that abuts two public streets, but does not have vehicular access to one of the streets. 
Service drive means: 
(1)  A land service street that provides vehicular access to the interior, back or side of properties otherwise abutting a public street; or 
(2)  An alley. 
Sewerage, private, means a sanitary sewerage system for the collection of waterborne wastes, complete with a sewage treatment plant or stabilization pond which is owned and operated by corporations or persons other than a public agency or authority. 
Sewerage, public, means a sanitary sewerage system for the collection of waterborne wastes, complete with a sewage treatment plant or stabilization pond which is owned and operated by a public agency or authority. 
Sketch plan means a general illustration, usually drawn freehand, of the proposed subdivision of land. 
Street, collector, means a major street used for traffic of moderate speeds and high peak volumes between land service streets and arteries, or serving as principal entrance streets or primary circulation routes within a neighborhood or other limited area; control of access from abutting properties warranted, but to a lesser degree than arteries. 
Street jog means where two streets or two portions of a single street are separated by a relatively short distance, usually at their intersection with another street. (See the following diagram.) 

Street, land service, means a minor street used for traffic of relatively low speeds and volumes, and for primary access to abutting properties; access controls not necessarily warranted, but through-traffic should be discouraged by the street design. 
Tangent means the straight line distance between the ending of one curve of a line (centerline of a street) and the beginning of another curve of the same line (centerline). (See the following diagram.) 

USCGS means the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey. 
Variance means an alteration or relaxation of the terms of this chapter where such alteration will not be contrary to the public interest, convenience and welfare, and where, owing to conditions peculiar to the property over which the applicant for a variance has no control, a literal enforcement of this chapter would create unnecessary and undue hardship on the applicant in the use of the property. 
Zoning and zoning regulations mean the comprehensive zoning regulations of the unincorporated areas of the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-3; Ord. No. 00-7, § 1, 8-15-2000) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 74-4—74-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROCEDURE FOR PLAT APPROVAL 

Sec. 74-36. - Generally. 
(a)  Review of subdivision plats helps to ensure that all subdivision and sale of land complies with the applicable requirements of the Columbia County Code of Ordinances. Review of a subdivision plat is required for any: 
(1)  Division of land into two or more lots; 
(2)  Recombination of two or more lots; 
(3)  Extension of public utilities (other than individual service lines) or other public facilities; 
(4)  Dedication of public right-of-way; 
(5)  Abandonment of existing public right-of-way; and 
(6)  Extension of public streets. 
(b)  Types of plats. There are two types of plats—Minor plats, approved by the director of planning services, and major plats, approved by the Columbia County Planning Commission. 
(1)  Minor plats. Plats meeting the following criteria are minor plats: 
a.  The subdivision will result in the creation of no more than four lots. 
b.  The subdivision does not require the extension of public utilities (other than individual service lines) or other public facilities. No substantial alteration of existing utility installations is involved. 
c.  The subdivision does not require the dedication of public right-of-way. 
d.  Each proposed lot meets the requirements of the Columbia County Code of Ordinances. 
e.  The subdivision meets the requirements of section 74-42, additional requirements for minor plats. 
(2)  Major plats. 
a.  A subdivision plat that is not a minor plat is considered a major plat. 
(c)  Major plats must be approved by the planning commission as follows: 
(1)  Submission of conceptual design . Early in the project and prior to any detailed design work, the prospective subdivider shall submit to the planning commission a conceptual design that illustrates how the proposed subdivision addresses existing site conditions, including topography, sensitive environmental and cultural features, and adjacent land uses, in accomplishing the overall development goals. Applicants or property owners proposing the subdivision of land that will not require a land disturbance permit are not required to submit for conceptual design approval. In making application for conceptual design approval, the prospective subdivider shall submit: 
a.  A survey of the existing site conditions, including existing topography, significant trees, waterways, wetlands, floodplains, and other environmentally sensitive features; existing structures, including any historic or cultural resources; utilities; and transportation facilities; and 
b.  A general land use plan illustrating proposed access points; street layout; approximate size and location of building types; recreational facilities; open space areas; and environmental protection areas. 
(2)  Submission of preliminary plat . Prior to making any street improvements or installing any utilities, the prospective subdivider shall submit to Columbia County a preliminary plat as specified in section 74-37 that meets the general layout and intent of the approved conceptual design, as well as the performance and maintenance bond required by section 74-45, and environmental bond required by section 34-70(b)(6). Where circumstances warrant, the planning commission may modify the requirements contained in this chapter in accordance with section 74-118. Approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission constitutes authorization for the subdivider to develop the subdivision subject to the minimum standards for improvements set forth in article IV of this chapter, and the minimum standards of design set forth in article III of this chapter. 
(3)  Submission of final plat . After approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation of the final plat and other documents as may be required in connection therewith. A final plat, in accordance with section 74-38, may be approved by the planning commission at any point after approval of the preliminary plat, or concurrently, provided that the requirements of section 74-45 have been met. No building permits shall be issued prior to the written approval of the final plat and subsequent as-built drawings. 
(4)  Submission of plat of record . Upon approval of a final plat, the subdivider shall submit a plat of record prepared in accordance with section 74-39 to the planning commission for its approval. 
(5)  Submission of as-built drawings . Upon the completion of improvements, the subdivider shall submit to Columbia County engineered drawings that show the exact dimensions, geometry, and location of all elements of the work completed. 
(d)  Appeals. 
(1)  Minor plats. An applicant or property owner requesting minor plat approval may appeal the director's decision to the planning commission. A written request for appeal must be received within 15 days of the director's decision, and must specify the grounds for appeal. The director shall transmit to the planning commission all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken, and shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal. Planning commission shall render a decision within 30 days of receiving a request for appeal. If aggrieved by the planning commission's decision, an applicant or property owner may appeal to the board of commissioners. A request for appeal will follow the process as outlined in subsection (2) below. 
(2)  Major plats. An applicant or property owner requesting major plat approval may appeal the planning commission's decision to the board of commissioners. A written request for appeal must be received within 15 days of the planning commission's decision, and must specify the grounds for appeal. The planning commission shall transmit to the board of commissioners all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken, and shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal. The board of commissioners shall render a decision within 30 days of receiving a request for appeal. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-20; Ord. No. 15-17, § 1(Exh. A), 6-16-2015; Ord. No. 15-28, § 1, 11-17-2015; Ord. No. 16-22 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 74-37. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  Submission. At least 15 days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning commission, the subdivider shall submit the following to the planning commission: 
(1)  A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat, and giving the name and address of a person to whom the notice of the hearing by the planning commission on the preliminary plat shall be sent; 
(2)  Five copies of a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision, drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet; and 
(3)  A subdivision review and inspection fee per lot platted for development which fee shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. 
(b)  Contents. The preliminary plat shall meet the general requirements and minimum standards of design set forth in article III of this chapter, and minimum standards for improvement set forth in article IV of this chapter, and shall give the following information: 
(1)  Topography, based on USCGS datum showing contours at vertical intervals of not more than five feet, except when specifically not required by the planning commission; 
(2)  Name, location and acreage of the subdivision; name and address of the owner of record and the subdivider; and the name, registration stamp and signature of the designer surveyor and the zoning district in which the land to be subdivided is located; 
(3)  North point, date and graphic scale; and the total number of lots and average lot size; 
(4)  Vicinity map showing the location of the subdivision in relation to surrounding area; 
(5)  Location of existing site features; property lines, utilities, easements, streets and their classifications, buildings, streams, land subject to flooding or periodic inundation, railroads, sewers, water mains, bridges and drainage structures, zoning both on the land to be subdivided and on the adjoining land, and the names of the adjoining property owners or subdivisions; 
(6)  Proposed layout of streets showing the proposed street names, rights-of-way and pavement widths (classifications to be determined by the planning commission); and evidence of the approval of the street plans by the county engineer; 
(7)  Exact boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, by bearings and distances; lot lines with approximate dimensions; and the minimum front building setback line; 
(8)  Locations and dimensions of easements, parks, playgrounds and land to be dedicated to public use, other than street rights-of-way; and land to be used for purposes other than residential; 
(9)  Proposed layout of the water distribution system, showing connections to existing or proposed water supply systems; and evidence of approval of the water system plans by the county engineer; 
(10)  Proposed layout of the sewerage system, showing connections to the public sewerage system, where required, and evidence of approval of the system plans by the county engineer and any other state or local agencies or officers having jurisdiction over such systems (approval of county health officer where on-site disposal is to be used or approval of the state water quality control board where private sewerage is to be provided); 
(11)  Proposed layout of the stormwater and surface water drainage system and evidence of approval of the system plans by the county engineer as set forth in section 74-84, and by the soil erosion and sedimentation control regulations as set forth in chapter 34, article III of this Code; 
(12)  Any adjoining areas to be developed at a later date by the subdivider as an extension of or addition to the proposed subdivision as part of a continuing or long-range development program; and 
(13)  Certain other information as may be required by the planning commission, the county engineer or the county health officer. 
(14)  Any legal instruments, including, but not limited to, grants of easements, declarations of covenants and articles of incorporation and bylaws of the owners association, to be reviewed by the county attorney as required by subsection 74-43(b) of this Code. 
(c)  Certificate of approval. A certificate of approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall be inscribed on the plat as follows:
