"Pursuant to the land subdivision regulations of Columbia County, Georgia, all of the requirements for approval having been fulfilled, this preliminary plat was given approval by the Columbia County Planning Commission on ________, 20_______. 
This approval does not constitute approval of a final plat. This certificate of approval shall expire and be null and void on ________, 20_______. 

 
(d)  Action by the planning commission. The designated representative of the planning commission shall check the plat for conformance to the provisions of this chapter, and report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission which shall afford a hearing on the preliminary plat. Not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing, notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be sent by registered or certified mail by the planning commission to the person designated in the letter requesting preliminary plat review and approval. Thereafter, the planning commission shall give approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat. No plat shall receive preliminary approval unless the land to be subdivided is located in the zoning district which permits the development proposed and is the zoning district which is designed most appropriately for the development proposed. A notation of the planning commission's action shall be made on two copies of the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the plat is disapproved. One copy of the preliminary plat shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent and one copy shall be retained in the files of the planning commission. Approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat, it indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to the preparation of the final plat. Approval of a preliminary plat shall expire and be null and void after a period of one year unless an extension of time is approved by the planning commission. If action on a preliminary plat is not taken by the planning commission within 60 days of the date of submittal, the preliminary plat shall be considered approved, and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. 
(e)  Construction authorization. Approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission constitutes authorization for the subdivider to develop the subdivision in accordance with the approved preliminary plat and subject to the minimum standards set forth in articles III and IV of this chapter. However, the subdivider, subdivision owner or agent of the subdivider or owner shall not transfer, sell, agree to sell or negotiate to sell any part of the subdivision, by reference or exhibition, until after the planning commission has approved the final plat and filed the plat of record. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-21; Ord. No. 01-11, §§ 4, 5, 11-6-2001; Ord. No. 06-02, § 1, 3-7-2006) 
Sec. 74-38. - Final plat. 
(a)  Final plats of real estate in the county shall be prepared in accordance with the standards set forth in O.C.G.A. tit. 15, ch. 6, art. 2. 
(b)  Plats shall also be prepared in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Plats shall be not larger than 17 inches by 23 inches, and shall be signed by the surveyor. 
(2)  Plats shall conform substantially to the preliminary plat, if applicable, as approved. Plats shall meet the general requirement and minimum standards of design set forth in article III of this chapter, and minimum standards for improvements as set forth in article IV of this chapter. Plats shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals not more than 100 feet, and shall show the following information, where applicable: 
a.  Name, location and acreage of subdivision; tax map and parcel number of the remainder of the parent tract, if any; name and address of the owner of record and the subdivider; and the name, registration stamp and signature of the surveyor of the subdivision; 
b.  North point, date and graphic scale; and the total number of lots and the average lot size; 
c.  Vicinity map showing the exact location of the subdivision in relation to the surrounding area, and showing streets or roads at a scale of one inch equals 1,000 feet; 
d.  Exact boundary lines of the subdivision tract; names and locations of adjoining subdivisions and streets; and the location and ownership of adjoining property; 
e.  Layout of streets showing street names, rights-of-way, pavement widths and classifications, street centerlines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii and lengths of tangents; 
f.  Lot lines with dimensions and bearings; minimum front building setback lines; lots numbered in numerical order and blocks lettered alphabetically; and the area of each lot; 
g.  Locations, dimensions and purposes of any easements, recreational areas, land to be dedicated for public use, land to be used for purposes other than residential, and land for future development; 
h.  All dimensions shall be to the nearest one-hundredth of a foot, and all bearings and angles shall be to the nearest minute; 
i.  Location, material and description of any monument and marker; 
j.  Sufficient data to readily determine and reproduce on the ground the location, bearing and length of every street, lot line, boundary line, front building setback line and block line, whether curved or straight; 
k.  A complete current mailing address of the surveyor, engineer or other preparer of the plat; 
l.  Floodplain data; and 
m.  Such other information as may be required by the planning commission, county engineer, county health officer or board of commissioners. 
(3)  Each plat shall contain, in such language as prescribed by the planning commission, a certificate by the surveyor as to survey and platting requirements; a certificate by the owner as to ownership and dedication of streets, easements, utilities, parks and open spaces; a certificate as to floor elevation as related to the sanitary sewer system; a certification of acceptance by the board of commissioners; and a certificate of final plat approval by the planning commission. 
(4)  At the time of requesting final plat approval, a signed copy of any legal instruments, with all exhibits attached, as required by zoning or the other chapters of this Code shall be furnished to the county for review by the county attorney. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-22; Ord. No. 06-02, § 2, 3-7-2006; Ord. No. 11-19, § 1, 11-1-2011) 
Sec. 74-39. - Final plat of record. 
(a)  After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been given approval by the planning commission, within one year from the date of such approval, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission an original and three duplicate copies prepared in accordance with the provisions of section 74-38. 
(b)  The designated representative of the planning commission shall check the final plat for conformance with the approved preliminary plat and with the provisions set forth in this Code, where applicable, and shall report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission, which shall afford a hearing on the final plat. 
(c)  The planning commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original and three reproductions of the original final plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval if the final plat is disapproved. 
(d)  If action on the final plat is not taken by the planning commission within 60 days of the date of submittal, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-23; Ord. No. 10-01, § 1(Exh. A), 4-20-2010) 
Sec. 74-40. - Recorded plat. 
After approval of any map or plat of a subdivision of land or any other map or plat requiring approval under O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(d) by the county planning commission, a municipal planning commission or a municipality within the county, the map or plat shall be filed for record in the office of the clerk of superior court as follows: 
(1)  The clerk shall file for record all approved maps or plats of a subdivision of land, any other plats requiring approval under O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(d) or any other maps or plats certified by a licensed surveyor indicating approval is not required under the provisions of O.C.G.A § 15-6-67(d). 
(2)  There must be filed with the clerk at the time of recording one original and three copies bearing original signatures, in black ink, of the licensed land surveyor who prepared the plat placed across the registration seal in order to be a valid or recordable map or plat as required by O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(b)(2)(E). The clerk shall enter thereon the filing date and plat cabinet, slide and number where the map or plat is filed. One duplicate copy of the original map or plat shall be delivered to the county planning commission. 
(3)  Any person "at the time of filing" requesting additional copies, shall include with the original and three copies, furnish the number of additional copies requested. Any person requesting additional copies or certified copies after time of filing must make such request to the clerk of superior court. 
(4)  If changes are requested to a recorded plat by the owner(s) of the land affected by such changes, the new plat must clearly show the existing property lines that are to be abandoned and state a reference to the previous plat and relevant deed with a description of the plat and date it was drawn before submitting the requested change to the county for processing in accordance with section 74-39. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-23.1; Ord. No. 01-9, §§ 1, 2, 10-2-2001; Ord. No. 10-01, § 1(Exh. A), 4-20-2010; Ord. No. 11-20, § 1, 11-1-2011) 
Sec. 74-41. - Sale or conveyance of subdivided land. 
No person shall transfer, convey, sell, agree to sell or negotiate to sell any part of a subdivision of land by reference to or exhibition of a plat which has not been prepared, approved and recorded in the manner prescribed in article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-23.2) 
Sec. 74-42. - Additional requirements for minor plats. 
Where approval is sought for a plat which depicts the subdivision of a tract of land into not more than four lots or tracts of land, including the remaining portion of the original tract which shall be treated as one of the four lots, the following conditions must be met: 
(1)  The size and shape of each lot resulting from the subdivision must meet the minimum standards set forth in chapter 90 of this Code for the zoning district in which the land being subdivided is located, except that if the parent tract does not have 150 feet of public road frontage the subdivision may be approved if it provides access to the newly formed lots as described in subsection (2) below. 
(2)  Ingress and egress to each lot resulting from the subdivision is provided by an access road at least 30 feet in width fronting on a public road of not less than 30 feet in width, with a curb cut for the access road of not less than 18 feet in width. Such access road shall run back to some or all four of the lots in the subdivision by frontage on a private road of not less than 30 feet in width with the owners of the lots owning either fee simple title to, or a permanent easement over, a strip or strips of land not less than 30 feet in width which permanent easement or fee simple strip may be exclusive to one or more of the lots or non-exclusive for use by all of the lots; provided that all of the lots must have the required ingress and egress. Such fee simple title or permanent easement shall not serve land not included in the subdivision as shown on the plat. Under no circumstances shall there be more than two access roads serving the lots in the subdivision. The topography of such 30-foot wide strip or strips of land must be suitable for the construction and maintenance of an access road to the lots being served, and it must not be burdened with improvements, easements or other encumbrances that would interfere with its use as a right-of-way for an access road. Any access road serving the lots must consist of dirt, gravel or a higher grade paving surface at least 18 feet in width. The access road can be maintained on a surface of dirt except at the point where the access road intersects the public road where the paving of the access road must consist at least of gravel from the edge of the paved county road to the right-of-way line of the county road in order to protect the paving of the county road. 
(3)  If the deed or deeds to any of the lots do not provide for maintenance and repair of the access road(s) in accordance with the requirements set forth herein, then the cost of maintenance and repair of the access road(s) must be paid in equal shares by the owners of each of the lots depicted on the plat, and each such owner shall be responsible for seeing that such maintenance and repair is performed. If the county engineer, in his/her discretion, is satisfied that all of the conditions of this section have been met, then the plat may be submitted by the county engineer to the planning commission for approval or in those situations where permitted, to a licensed surveyor for certification. Columbia County shall not be responsible for construction, repair or maintenance of any access road unless the county has accepted ownership of the road in accordance with all requirements which have been established by the county. 
(4)  Any plat or map for which approval is sought under this section 74-42 of the Code must meet the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67 in order that the clerk of superior court shall file and record in his/her office such maps and plats in the county. This will require approval by the county planning commission unless there is an exemption under [O.C.G.A.] § 15-6-67(d). 
(5)  Changes to plats depicting four lots or less must be made in accordance with the requirements set forth in subsection 74-40(4) of the Code. 
(6)  Lots or tracts of land resulting from the subdivision of land as depicted on a plat approved under this section, including the remaining portion of the original tract, may not be further subdivided under the provisions of this section for a period of five years after the date of the recording of the plat. If the original tract is subdivided into less than four lots as shown on the plat for which approval is sought, then the original tract may at a later date be subdivided further but only up to a grand total of not more than four lots being subdivided out of the original tract, including the original tract; provided that these subsequently subdivided lots may not be further subdivided for a period of five years after the date of the recording of the plat depicting their subdivision. The term "original tract," as used in this section, shall mean the entire tract of land as it existed immediately prior to the subdivision of any portion of such tract of land as depicted on the plat for which approval is being sought. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-24; Ord. No. 11-17, § 1, 11-1-2011; Ord. No. 14-04, § 1, 2-18-2014; Ord. No. 15-17, § 2, 6-16-2015) 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 15-17, adopted June 16, 2015, changed the title of § 74-42 from "Plats depicting subdivisions of four lots or less" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 74-43. - Subdivisions with private roads. 
(a)  The subdivision of land creating lots abutting on private roads shall be permitted, provided that the: 
(1)  Private roads and the rights-of-way therefor are constructed and maintained in accordance with the requirements of this Code and minimum specifications therefor, as promulgated from time to time by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  Fee simple title to the rights-of-way for the roads are vested in the owners of the lots abutting such private roads, or a nonprofit state corporation of which all owners of lots having a right to use the roads are required by covenants running with the land to be members (referred to in this section as the "owner's association"). 
(3)  Private roads are subject to a perpetual easement for ingress and egress to all of the lots in the subdivision, which easement shall be appurtenant to and pass with title to the lots in the subdivision. 
(4)  Owner's association shall, by covenants running with the land recorded in the office of the clerk of superior court, have the obligation to maintain the private roads and rights-of-way therefor in a good, safe and well-kept condition, and shall be required to levy annual assessments on lots in the subdivision to pay the cost thereof, and to establish and maintain reasonable reserves for future significant repair, rebuilding, repaving and maintenance of such roads, not required on an annual basis, which assessments, if unpaid, when due, become and continue to be a lien on the lot against which they were levied until they are paid. 
(b)  A subdivision of land creating lots fronting on private roads shall require approval of a preliminary plat and a final plat as set forth in this chapter for subdivisions using public roads, which shall be filed with the engineering services department for processing and consideration by the planning and zoning commission and the board of commissioners if any of the improvements located in such subdivision are to be dedicated to the county. At the time of the filing of the plat for preliminary approval, the owner of the land shall also file all legal instruments, including, but not limited to, grants of easements, declarations of covenants and articles of incorporation and bylaws of the owner's association, to be reviewed by the county attorney to determine if all of the requirements of subsection (a)(2), (a)(3) and (a)(4) of this section have been met. At the time of requesting final plat approval, a copy of the signed documents, with all exhibits attached, together with a certificate of incorporation for the owner's association from the secretary of state and a copy of the minutes of the organizational meeting of the owner's association certified by its secretary must be furnished to the county attorney for review. 
(c)  Subdivisions containing more than four lots, but not more than 12 lots, including the remaining portion of the original tract, access to which is provided by private roads, shall, at a minimum, provide access to the lots by not more than two private roads which must be at least 18 feet in width located within a right-of-way of not less than 30 feet in width, and built and paved in accordance with specifications established by the board of commissioners. If a subdivision is developed and access provided pursuant to the provisions of this subsection, the lots resulting from such subdivision, including the remaining portion of the original tract, may not be further subdivided without meeting all of the requirements of articles III and IV of this chapter for the development of subdivisions. Any subdivision containing more than 12 lots, access to which is provided by private roads, shall provide access to the lots by roads meeting all of the requirements of articles III and IV of this chapter for the development of subdivisions; provided, however, that if all of the lots in the subdivision are five acres or larger, the streets do not have to be paved, but must meet all other development construction standards. If all lots in the subdivision are 2.5 acres or larger, concrete curbs and gutters are not required. The term "original tract," as used in this subsection, means the entire tract of land as it existed immediately prior to the subdivision of any portion thereof as depicted on the plat for which approval is being sought. 
(d)  An appropriate permanent sign identifying the roads in the subdivision as private roads must be erected by the developer and maintained in good condition by the owner's association or the developer at all locations where private roads intersect with public roads. 
(e)  Subdivisions developed with the use of private roads must, except as specifically otherwise provided in this chapter, comply with all other requirements of this Code dealing with or relating to the subdivision of land and the construction of improvements on such land. 
(f)  No plat of a subdivision of land utilizing private roads for ingress and egress to the lots contained in such subdivision shall be approved unless it is in full compliance with the requirements of this section, unless a variance from any such requirement is granted by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-25) 
Sec. 74-44. - Reserved. 
Sec. 74-45. - Performance and maintenance bond. 
(a)  A performance and maintenance bond, letter of credit, cash bond, or other equivalent form of security as approved by the county attorney, running in favor of the county, in a minimum amount of $5,000.00 or any amount equal to at least 30 percent of the actual construction cost of all improvements to be dedicated to the county, whichever is greater, shall be posted with the county by all subdividers or persons where street or other improvements are made and offered to the county for acceptance and maintenance except as noted in this section. The performance and maintenance bond, cash bond, letter of credit or other equivalent form of security shall guarantee all improvements against defects in design, material and workmanship and further guarantee that all such improvements shall be installed and maintained in first class condition for the required period and faithful performance by the subdivider or other person of all provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Any bond, except cash bond, or letter of credit or other equivalent form of approved security shall be on forms supplied by the county and shall not be terminated or otherwise allowed to expire prior to the satisfactory completion of the maintenance period under section 74-46, or until released by the board of commissioners. Such bond, cash bond, letter of credit or other equivalent form of approved security along with evidence of payment of the required premiums shall be filed with the county. 
(2)  Such bond, cash bond, letter of credit or other equivalent form of security shall be posted prior to commencement of construction. No preliminary plat shall be approved or recorded by the county and no construction shall commence until and unless a satisfactory bond is posted. 
(3)  Separate bonds required by this section shall be required for each subdivision unit, phase or like entity approved by the county pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 16-19 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 74-46. - Maintenance. 
(a)  All subdivisions in which subdivider intends to dedicate all, or a portion of, the improvements located thereon to the county shall meet the requirements of this section. The subdivider shall maintain and repair all improvements, other than water and sewer, dedicated to the county for two years, unless extended pursuant to this section, from the date of written acceptance of the as-built drawings. The subdivider shall pay the reasonable costs for the county to maintain and repair all dedicated water and sewer improvements for two years, unless extended pursuant to this section. 
(1)  The subdivider shall request in writing that the county inspect the development at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the maintenance period. Failure to notify the county in writing shall extend the maintenance period until inspection is requested and all determined improvements are made. 
(2)  If upon inspection as provided in subsection (1) of this section, the county determines that work or repairs are needed in order for the improvements to meet county specifications or requirements under this chapter, the subdivider shall be notified in writing by the department of the deficiencies, failure to comply or violations. Thereafter, for deficiencies, failure to comply or violations related to improvements other than water and sewer, the subdivider shall extend the maintenance bond one year and shall have 60 days from receipt of such notification to correct such deficiencies, noncompliance or violations. If the deficiencies, noncompliance or violations are not corrected within such time, then the maintenance bond, cash bond, letter of credit or equivalent form of approved security posted by the subdivider shall be, if approved by the board of commissioners, forfeited and called upon up to the cost of the repairs or the total amount of the bond. Should the amount of the bond be inadequate to pay for the cost of correcting the deficiencies, noncompliance or violations, then the subdivider shall pay any and all costs beyond bond coverage. For deficiencies, failure to comply or violations related to water and sewer, the subdivider shall pay the county the reasonable cost to correct the same. 
(3)  The subdivider shall pay to the county for each inspection, subsequent to the initial inspection provided under subsection (1) of this section, a reinspection fee in an amount set from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners to defray the cost of reinspection. 
(4)  The maintenance period shall continue until such time as the county has inspected and accepted the improvements in writing. 
(5)  If a period of 30 months elapses from the commencement of the maintenance period for any subdivision and defects, noncompliance or violations still exist to the extent that the subdivision has not been accepted by the county, the county is authorized to withhold the issuance of any and all permits or to refuse inspection to subdivider on the project in dispute and any other project in which the subdivider, or officer or owner thereof, has a financial interest. 
(Ord. No. 16-20 , § 1(Exh. A), 6-7-2016) 
Secs. 74-47—74-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL STANDARDS AND MINIMUM STANDARDS OF DESIGN 

Sec. 74-76. - Suitability of land. 
(a)  Land physically unsuitable for subdivision. The planning commission has found the following land to be unsuitable for development: 
(1)  Land which is subject to flooding, bad drainage, steep slopes, rock formations or other such features which may endanger health, life or property, aggravate erosion, increase flood hazard or necessitate excessive expenditures of public funds for supply and maintenance of services; and 
(2)  Land which other public agencies concerned have investigated and found, in the best interest of the public, not suitable for the type of platting and development proposed; 
such lands shall not be approved for subdivision unless adequate methods are formulated by the developer for meeting the problems created by subdivision of such land. 
(b)  Land unsuitably located for subdivision. The planning commission shall not approve what it considers to be scattered or premature subdivi-sion of land which would endanger health, safety or property because of lack of or adverse effect on water supply, schools, proper drainage, good transportation, other public services or public funds for the supply or maintenance of such services. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-30) 
Sec. 74-77. - Name of subdivision. 
The name of each subdivision must have the approval of the planning commission. The subdivision name shall not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of an existing subdivision. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-31) 
Sec. 74-78. - Street classifications. 
Streets and roads are classified in the county growth management plan according to the function that they are to serve the type, speed and volume of traffic they will carry, and the required standards of design. The classifications of streets and roads as used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  Primary arteries; 
(2)  Secondary arteries; 
(3)  Collector streets; and 
(4)  Land service streets. 
The designation in the county growth management plan of arterials and collectors shall not prevent other streets proposed in or adjoining subdivisions from being similarly classified. For the purposes of this chapter, land service streets are further classified by street design and use. Street classifications and subclassifications are as follows: 
(1)  Primary arteries—(PA) 
(2)  Secondary arteries—(SA) 
(3)  Collector streets—(CS) 
(4)  Land service streets—(LS) 
a.  Residential: 
1.  Small lot subdivisions (lots less than 50,000 square feet). 
2.  Large lot subdivisions (lots larger than 50,000 square feet with a minimum frontage of 125 feet). 
3.  Rural subdivisions (lots larger than 2.5 acres). 
4.  Large lot rural subdivisions (lots larger than 5.0 acres). 
b.  Industrial. 
c.  Commercial. 
d.  Service drive. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-32; Ord. No. 00-7, § 2, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 74-79. - Relation to present, proposed and future street system. 
(a)  Location and width of streets and roads. The location and width of all streets and roads shall conform to the official major road plan as adopted by the planning commission. 
(b)  Connection of at least one existing street: At least one connecting street that terminates at, adjoins, or traverses a proposed subdivision and which will be used to provide access to the subdivision shall be a paved road not later than the approval of final plat for the first phase of the subdivision. If such access road is not a paved road it must be paved continuously in a manner meeting all of the requirements of this article from the nearest paved road on the public road system of the county, any adjoining county, any municipality located within the county or of the State of Georgia to at least one subdivision entrance. However, for those subdivisions that are creating lots under the provisions of section 74-42 of the Code, plats depicting subdivisions of four lots or less, and for those subdivisions that are creating lots larger than 15 acres under section 74-43 of the Code, subdivisions with private roads, at least one public road providing access to the subdivision shall be improved at least to the same standard as is required within the proposed subdivision from the nearest paved road on any of the public road systems described immediately above. 
(c)  Layout of new streets: The proposed street system within a subdivision shall be determined by the planning commission to adequately balance the privacy of the future occupants with the free flow of traffic within the county, and to adequately provide for access for public safety by fire, police and emergency medical vehicles, and for school buses. In making such determination, satisfaction of the following requirements shall be considered by the planning commission: 
(1)  In the opinion of the planning commission where it is necessary to provide for street access to adjoining property, proposed streets shall be extended by dedication and improvement of right-of-way to the boundary of such property. 
(2)  Unless approved otherwise by the planning commission, a subdivision shall provide a street connection to each public street that it adjoins, and shall provide direct or indirect continuity through the subdivision between each connection. 
(3)  The proposed street layout should be designed to minimize cut and fill within the right-of-way to provide better access to the subdivision lots. The design should also minimize the area of tree removal required for installation of streets, utilities and drainage features in order to reduce the number of large trees removed during construction. 
(4)  To the greatest extent practical, cul-de-sacs should be avoided in favor of loop streets or a curvilinear or grid system of streets. 
(d)  Reverse frontage lots: 
(1)  Except in the R-A Residential-Agricultural district reverse frontage lots shall be provided along all arterial and collector roads abutting a residential subdivision unless the planning commission specifically determines that the provision of such lots would create an unusual and burdensome hardship on the property owner due to topographic or dimensional disadvantages of the property. Reverse frontage lots shall not be required in the R-A Residential-Agricultural district where lots are platted with road frontage widths greater than 150 feet and driveways are separated by more than 300 feet unless the planning commission determines that limiting access to the collector or arterial street is necessary for safety reasons. 
(2)  An easement shall be provided to the county extending along the entire line of reverse frontage across which there shall be no right of access as follows: 
a.  Equal in depth to the minimum front building setback required by the zoning district. Within the easement existing vegetation shall remain or shall be supplemented or replaced by additional planting to provide substantial natural screening between the lots and the arterial and collector roads. Existing trees with ten inches diameter at breast height (dbh) or greater shall not be removed unless removal is approved by the county to prevent danger due to injury or disease to the tree; or 
b.  No less than 25 feet in depth and in accordance with the provisions and requirements of section 90-139, buffer requirements, of the zoning ordinance. Existing trees with ten inches diameter at breast height (dbh) or greater shall not be removed unless removal is approved by the county to prevent danger due to injury or disease to the tree. 
(3)  All buffer and landscaping treatments are subject to the review and approval of the planning commission. Modifications may be approved by the planning commission to achieve equivalent screening results, depending on the topography, orientation or other physical factors of the site. 
(e)  Interval of intersection with arteries. Subdivision streets which intersect an artery shall do so at intervals not less than the following: 
(1)  Limited access primary artery, 1,200 feet; 
(2)  Other primary artery, 800 feet; and 
(3)  Secondary artery, 400 feet. 
(f)  Large parcels. When land is subdivided into parcels larger than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the opening of streets in the future, and for logical resubdivision. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-33; Ord. No. 00-7, § 2, 8-15-2000; Ord. No. 01-06, § 1, 8-21-2001; Ord. No. 08-03, § 1, 5-20-2008) 
_____
Sec. 74-80. - Design of streets. 
(a)  Width of street right-of-way. The minimum width of right-of-way measured from lot line to lot line shall be as follows: 

 
 * Or greater amount as may be required by the planning commission. 
** Requires prior approval of the planning commission. 
_____
(b)  Vertical alignment of streets. 
(1)  Grades on arteries, collectors and industrial land service streets shall not exceed seven percent; grades on commercial land service streets shall not exceed ten percent; grades on residential land service streets shall not exceed 13 percent; all curbed and paved raised edge streets shall have a minimum grade of one percent. 
(2)  All changes in grade shall be connected by a vertical curve constructed so as to afford a minimum sight distance, which shall be measured from the driver's eyes, which are assumed to be 3¾ feet above the pavement surface, to an object six inches high on the pavement. The minimum sight distance shall be the minimum stopping sight distance for the rated speed of the street as follows: 

 
(c)  Horizontal alignment of streets. Where a deflection angle of more than ten degrees in the alignment of a street occurs, the radius of curvature of the centerline of such street shall be not less than the following: 

 
* The planning commission may approve a 50-foot curvature to make more efficient use of land. 
(1)  A tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. 
(2)  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than the minimum stopping sight distance set forth in this section of the street intersected shall not be allowed. 
(3)  All streets shall intersect at right angles. Such intersecting streets shall continue as perpendicular from the center point of the intersection for not less than the minimum stopping sight distance for their respective rated speeds in accordance with this section. 
(4)  Right-of-way lines at street intersections shall have a radius of curvature of not less than 20 feet. Wherever necessary to permit the construction of a curb having a desirable radius without curtailing the sidewalk at a street corner to less than normal width, the street right-of-way line at such street corner shall be rounded or otherwise set back sufficiently to permit such construction. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  Service drives. Service drives or alleys shall be provided to the rear of all lots used for business purposes, and shall not be provided in residential blocks, except where the subdivider produces evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys or service drives, such as subdividing adjacent to an artery, or where specifically required by the planning commission. 
(f)  Culs-de-sac. Culs-de-sac shall not be more than 700 feet long unless necessitated by topographic or other conditions and approved by the planning commission. Such streets shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 80 feet, and a street right-of-way diameter of at least 100 feet. 
(g)  Street names. Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment with others already existing and named shall bear the names of existing streets. In no case shall the name for a proposed street duplicate existing street names, irrespective of the use of the suffix street, avenue, boulevard, road, pike, drive, way, place, court or other derivatives. The planning commission can assist the subdivider in avoiding duplication and in coordinating the names of streets within the subdivision through its index list of street names and guides for naming and suffixing. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-34) 
Sec. 74-81. - Blocks. 
(a)  Length. Blocks shall not be less than 400 feet, nor more than 1,200 feet in length, except as the planning commission considers necessary to secure efficient use of land or desired features of street patterns. In blocks greater than 800 feet in length, the planning commission may require at locations it deems necessary one or more public crosswalks of not less than ten feet in width to extend entirely across the block, or pedestrian easements in lieu thereof. (See section 74-83.) 
(b)  Width. Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two rows of lots, except where reverse frontage on major streets is provided or when prevented by topographic conditions or size of property or location next to an artery, in which case, the planning commission may approve a single row of lots. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-36) 
Sec. 74-82. - Lots. 
(a)  Adequate building sites. Each lot shall contain a building site not subject to flood or periodic inundation. 
(b)  Arrangement. Each lot must abut a public street or road. Side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines, where practical. 
(c)  Minimum lot dimensions and areas. 
(1)  The size and shape of lots shall meet the minimum standards set forth in the county's zoning regulations, chapter 90 of this Code, and orientation of lots shall be such as the planning commission deems appropriate for the use contemplated, type of water supply and sewage disposal, soil characteristics, improvements and relation to the street system. 
(2)  The minimum depths of building setback lines for lots platted for all purposes shall be subject to the provisions of the county zoning regulations, chapter 90 of this Code, as well as the following: 
a.  Wherever fill is proposed to raise land, the building setback line shall be located not less than 25 feet from the outer edge of the fill. 
b.  To prevent infringement of sight lines at intersections, the setback distances for corner lots shall be based on the minimum stopping sight distances for automobiles approaching the intersection as set forth in section 74-80. The building setback line for the corner lot shall not be closer to the street right-of-way line than that line which connects the two points located on the centerlines of the two streets, the prescribed minimum stopping sight distance from the center of the intersection. 
(3)  Properties reserved or platted for commercial or industrial purposes shall be adequate in size to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. Platting of individual lots should be avoided in favor of an overall design of the land to be used for such purposes. Land shall not be platted for commercial or industrial purposes unless the subdivider can demonstrate to the planning commission: 
a.  A site arrangement that prevents undue interference with through traffic. Each industrial subdivision or area shall utilize a single collector for all heavy traffic between the area and the general system of streets and roads. Industrial streets and individual industrial parcels shall be oriented at right angles with the collector and with adjacent railroads; 
b.  An on-site parking area; 
c.  An insulation against any adverse effects on any present or future adjacent residences; and 
d.  A parcel size sufficient in area to allow future expansion. 
(d)  Double and reverse frontage lots. 

Double and Reverse Frontage Lots 
(1)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots should be avoided except where specifically required by the planning commission to provide separation of residential development from arterial and collector roads or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation of property. 
(2)  Reverse frontage lots shall be provided along all arterial and collector roads abutting a residential subdivision unless the planning commission specifically determines that the provision of such lots would create an unusual and burdensome hardship on the property owner due to topographic or dimensional disadvantages of the property. 
(3)  An easement to the county extending along the entire frontage, across which there shall be no right of access, and screening shall be provided along the line of reverse frontage lots abutting such arterial and collector roads, as follows: 
a.  In the R-A, residential-agricultural zoning district, the easement shall be equal in width to the minimum front building setback required by such zoning district. Within the easement, the existing vegetation shall be left undisturbed, but may be supplemented with additional plantings. 
b.  In all other residential zoning districts, the easement and screening shall be established as a buffer in accordance with the provisions and requirements of section 90-139 of this Code. The width of the buffer/easement for a natural buffer shall not be less than the minimum front building setback required by the zoning district in which it is located, or not less than 25 feet in width for a structural buffer if it creates an opaque screen to a height of not less than six feet. 
c.  All buffer and landscaping treatments are subject to the review and approval of the planning commission. Modifications may be approved by the planning commission to achieve equivalent screening results depending on the topography, orientation or other physical factors of the site. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-36(a)—(c); Ord. No. 00-7, § 2, 8-15-2000) 
Sec. 74-83. - Public use and service areas. 
(a)  Public open spaces. Where a school or recreation area, which is shown on an official map or in a plan made and adopted by the planning commission, is located in whole or in part in the applicant's subdivision, the planning commission may require the dedication or reservation of such open space within the subdivision, up to a total of ten percent of the gross area of the plot, including any water frontage for park, school or recreational purposes. 
(b)  Easements. 
(1)  Utilities. Except where alleys or rear service drives are permitted for such purpose, easements along rear and/or side lot lines, or elsewhere, if necessary, not exceeding 20 feet in width, shall be required for the extension of existing or planned utilities. 
(2)  Pedestrian. In cases and at such locations as the planning commission deems advisable, easements along side or rear lot lines, not exceeding 12 feet in width, may be required for pedestrian or bicycle traffic to and from schools, parks and other public places. 
(3)  Drainage. In cases in which a subdivision is traversed by a stream or drainage channel, there shall be provided a stormwater easement of such width along each side of the stream as the planning commission deems necessary for the purpose of widening, deepening, protecting, relocating or otherwise improving such drainage element. 
(c)  Community assets. In all subdivisions, due regard shall be shown for all natural features such as large trees and watercourses and for historical spots and similar community assets which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to the property. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-37) 
Sec. 74-84. - Drainage. 
In addition to the requirements set forth in section 74-117(b), any plan for subdividing property shall include the following: 
(1)  A plan showing the acreage of all on-site and off-site drainage areas contributing flow through the project. 
(2)  A hydrology report which shall include: 
a.  Minimum design frequency of a 25-year storm; 
b.  Minimum time of concentration of ten minutes; 
c.  Detailed calculations indicating the formula used; 
d.  Coefficient of run-off; 
e.  Time of concentration; 
f.  Rainfall intensity; 
g.  Discharged velocity; and 
h.  Source of all data used. 
(3)  Where the drainage area exceeds 150 acres, two formulas shall be used, and the average of the two shall be submitted. 
(4)  In addition to the requirements set forth in section 74-83(b)(3), the following shall also be required: 
a.  A five-foot easement along all side property lines. 
b.  A ten-foot easement along all rear property lines. 
c.  All storm drainage pipes shall be located within a ten-foot easement. 
d.  All stormwater discharged into natural drainage areas shall be as straight as possible. 
e.  All storm drainage pipes shall be at least 18 inches in diameter, and 18 inches below the surface, and shall have a slope of at least one percent. 
f.  Catchbasins shall be located at all low points of streets, and shall be located so as to service no more than four acres. 
g.  High water elevation contour based on a 25-year storm at the entrance of each head wall. 
(5)  To control erosion, all drainage easements, natural ditches and drainage areas shall be grassed and/or rip-rapped as necessary. 
(6)  All plans of subdivisions shall include a method of control so as to prevent the silting and/or erosion of natural drainage areas, natural drains and streams, and adjoining property. Such plans shall also provide for control of the rate of discharge of excess water. 
(7)  In addition to the requirements set forth in this chapter, all property located in a floodprone area shall be developed in accordance with the minimum standards of the United States and the state which govern floodprone areas. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-38) 
Secs. 74-85—74-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 74-116. - Compliance with article before final plat approval. 
The tangible improvements as set forth in this article are required before a final plat shall be approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-40) 
Sec. 74-117. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Monuments and lot markers. Numbered concrete monuments, four inches in diameter or square, three feet long with a flat top shall be set at all street corners, at all points where the street lines intersect the exterior boundaries of a subdivision, at the intersection of curves and tangents along street lines and at all corners of the plot. The top of the monument shall have an indented cross to properly identify the location, and shall be set flush with the finished grade. All other lot corners shall be marked with iron pipes or pins which are not less than three-fourths inch in diameter and 24 inches long, and shall be driven so as to be flush with the finished grade. 
(b)  Storm drainage. An adequate drainage system, including necessary ditches, pipes, culverts, drains, inlets, bridges, etc., shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water. All storm drainage systems shall comply with the county's specifications for such systems, and shall be approved by the county engineer before such systems may be installed and before final plat approval will be issued by the planning commission. 
(c)  Street development. Every subdivision developer shall be required to grade and improve new streets and alley as follows: 
(1)  Preparation of right-of-way. The full width of all roadways shall be prepared so that pavement and sidewalks, where required, may be constructed in such a manner that future extension of additional utilities or street improvements will not damage yards of abutting property. Abutting property shall be suitably sloped to the right-of-way line. Due regard shall be shown for desirable trees not impairing visibility. 
(2)  Preparation of subgrade. Before grading is started, the entire area to be paved shall first be cleared of all stumps, roots, brush and other objectionable materials. In all areas to be graded or filled, the subdivider shall stockpile the topsoil to be spread later in all disturbed areas not paved. 
(3)  Protection of banks. Immediately after grading, filling and respreading of topsoil, all areas of disturbed soil shall be fertilized and seeded, or in steep areas, sodded or otherwise appropriately treated, with suitable vegetative cover to retard erosion. 
(4)  Pavement base. Pavement base material shall conform to the county's specifications for such material, and shall be approved by the county engineer. 
(5)  Minimum width of pavement. The minimum width of pavement, measured between curbs, required for arteries, collectors and land service streets shall be as follows: 
_____ 

 
* Arteries and collectors protected from curb cuts as set forth in section 74-79(d) may be approved with a pavement width of 24 feet. 
_____ 
(6)  Curb-and-gutter and paving . All new streets shall be surfaced by the developer with paving materials as required by county specifications regarding street paving and surface materials. Curbs and gutters on all new streets shall be constructed by the subdivision developer in accordance with the county's specifications for curbs and gutters. Raised asphalt curb is prohibited, unless proposed along streets in the R-A (residential agriculture) or R-1 (single-family residential) zoning districts. Where a subdivision abuts an existing state or county road, the developer shall be required to improve such road so that it will comply with the minimum requirements of this chapter. 
(7)  Preparation and development of new streets. The preparation and development of all new streets shall comply with the county's specifications, and shall be approved by the county engineer before such streets may be developed and accepted by the county engineer and board of commissioners before final plat approval will be issued by the planning commission. 
(8)  Turn lanes. Turn lanes may be required at all entrances to subdivisions and industrial and commercial developments which front on arterial and collector streets. Turn lanes shall be 12 feet in width, plus curb and gutter, for a minimum distance of 200 feet, which distance shall be measured from the intersection of the right-of-way lines. 
(d)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks may be required where deemed by the planning commission as an integral part of a pedestrian traffic system within a one-mile radius of existing or planned schools, neighborhood recreation or commercial areas or other public places. Where provided, sidewalks shall be located not less than one foot from the property line to prevent interference or encroachment by fencing, walls, hedges or other plantings or structures placed on the property line at a later date. 
(e)  Sanitary sewerage. In the areas of the county designated for sewerage service in the master sewerage plan prepared by the county engineer, all subdivision developers shall be required to install a sanitary sewerage collection system. The layout and specifications of the system shall be in accordance with the master sewerage plan and other applicable county specifications, and shall require the approval of the county engineer. Where sanitary sewerage collection systems are not specifically required by the county engineer, all lots shall contain adequate area for the installation and safe operation of approved septic tanks and disposal fields, and must be approved by the county health officer and other agencies having jurisdiction over such matters. 
(f)  Public water systems. Each subdivision developer shall be required to provide a potable water supply subject to the approval of the county health officer. Where specifically required by the county engineer, each subdivision developer shall provide the subdivision service from the county water system. Any water lines or mains that are installed by any person which are to be attached to the water system of the county shall be constructed in accordance with county specifications and approved by the county engineer. 
(g)  Site improvements. Banks which infringe on sight lines at intersections (see section 74-82(c)(2)) shall be appropriately graded to correct the deficiency. Wherever grading or filling occurs on lots within the subdivision, the subdivider shall first stockpile the topsoil from the affected areas immediately after grading and filling, and shall redistribute to areas of disturbed soil, sufficient topsoil to support growth of lawn grass and other vegetation, and shall immediately seed such areas with appropriate vegetative cover to prevent erosion, silting of streams and other damages. Due regard shall be shown for such desirable trees which are already on the site, and grading and filling should be planned to preserve as many of such trees possible; however, no retained planting shall infringe on sight lines at intersections. If trees are planted by the subdivider, they shall be located five feet inside or behind property lines where they are less subject to injury, decrease the chances of motor accidents and enjoy more favorable conditions for growth. If trees are to be planted within a planting strip in the right-of-way, the proposed locations and species of such trees to be used must be submitted for the planning commission's approval since the public inherits the care and maintenance of such trees. The planning commission will assist the subdivider in location of trees and species to use under varying conditions. Where land is platted or reserved for commercial or industrial use bordering and across minor streets from residential lots, a suitable buffer planting of trees and shrubs which are approved by the planning commission shall be required, and such trees and shrubs shall not infringe on sight lines at intersections where planted. 
(h)  Street name signs. Appropriate street signs add sales value to land subdivisions and enable strangers, delivery concerns and potential lot buyers to find their way around. Street name signs of a type approved by the county shall be placed at all intersections. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-41; Ord. No. 15-26, § 1, 11-3-2015) 
Sec. 74-118. - Variances. 
The planning commission may authorize variances from the general requirements and minimum standards of design contained in this article and article III of this chapter, provided the subdivider makes a specific request and shows to the satisfaction of the planning commission that topographical or other conditions peculiar and particular to the site are such that strict adherence to the requirements of this article and article III of this chapter would cause such person an unnecessary hardship, and would not carry out the intent of this chapter. Any authorized variance is to be stated in writing in the minutes of the planning commission with the reasons for which the departure was justified and the conditions under which such variance was granted. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-42) 
Sec. 74-119. - Guarantee in lieu of completed improvements. 
No final subdivision plat shall be approved by the planning commission or accepted for record by the clerk of the superior court until one of the following conditions has been met: 
(1)  All required improvements have been constructed in a satisfactory manner and approved by the board of commissioners; or 
(2)  The board of commissioners has accepted a performance bond in an amount equal to the estimated cost of installation of the required improvements, whereby improvements may be made and utilities installed without cost to public bodies in the event of default of the subdivider. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-43) 
Sec. 74-120. - Filing fees. 
The board of commissioners may establish, by resolution, a schedule of filing fees to be paid upon the filing of a preliminary subdivision plat, a final subdivision plat or any other plat or document for which approval is provided for in this chapter. The schedule of fees shall be posted in the offices of the engineering services department and shall be provided to any person upon request and shall be set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. The board of commissioners may amend the schedule of established filing fees or add additional filing fees from time to time as it shall deem appropriate. All such filing fees shall be due and payable upon the filing of the plat or other document requiring the payment of such fee, and such application shall not be deemed complete and ready for processing until such filing fee has been paid. In establishing the amount of such filing fees, the board of commissioners shall set such fees at an amount necessary to reimburse the county for the costs incurred by it in processing, reviewing and acting upon such application for approval as the board of commissioners, in its discretion, shall determine. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-44) 
Secs. 74-121—74-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 74-151. - Administration of chapter; planning commission approval required. 
(a)  No plat of property lying within the unincorporated areas of the county shall be filed or recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court until it has been submitted to and approved by the planning commission, and such approval has been entered in writing on the plat by the planning commission. 
(b)  The board of commissioners shall not accept, layout, open, improve, grade, pave or light any street unless such street shall have been accepted, opened or otherwise received the legal status of a public street, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat approved by the planning commission. 
(c)  The clerk of superior court shall not file or record a plat which does not have the approval of the planning commission as required by this section. 
(d)  Any deed or other instrument of conveyance, including a security deed, bond for title or any other document purporting to convey title to real estate, filed for record in the office of the clerk of the superior court, wherein the property to be conveyed is described in some manner other than by reference to a recorded plat, shall be accompanied by a certificate signed by the party filing such deed, or other instrument, which certificate shall be in the following form: 
I, ___________, do certify that the instrument herewith filed for record in the Office of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Columbia County, Georgia, does not involve the subdivision of property and does not subdivide a larger tract of land. 
This _____ day of ________, 20_______. 

 
(e)  No person shall transfer, sell or agree to sell any land to be subdivided by reference to or exhibition of, or by other use of, a plat of the subdivision of such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court, provided further, that the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring such land shall not exempt the transaction from the requirements of this section. 
(f)  No building permit shall be issued for, and no building or other structure shall be erected on, any lot within the unincorporated areas of the county unless the street giving access to such lot upon which such building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted and opened as, or shall otherwise receive the legal status of, a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat approved by the planning commission. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-50) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-186 et seq. 
Sec. 74-152. - Violation; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(b)  The county, through its attorney or other official designated by the board of commissioners, may, in addition to other remedies, institute injunction mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Any building erected in violation of this chapter shall be deemed to be an unlawful structure, and the building inspector, county attorney or other official designated by the board of commissioners may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed. 
(Code 1979, § 2-13-51; Ord. No. 00-10, § 13, 10-3-2000) 
Chapter 78 - TAXATION[1]

IX, § II, ¶ VIII; taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I; homestead exemption for educational purposes, 1987 Ga. Laws, page 4267; homestead exemption for aged, 1988 Ga. Laws, page 4622; homestead exemption for aged and disabled persons, 1992 Ga. Laws, page 6175, as amended, 1994 Ga. Laws, page 4080. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 78-1—78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Local depository financial institutions business license tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 

Sec. 78-31. - Levied. 
(a)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is levied for the year 1984 and each year thereafter an annual business tax upon all depository financial institutions located within the county which tax shall be at the rate of a one-quarter percent of the gross receipts of depository financial institutions. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Depository financial institution means state and national banks, state building and loan associations and federal savings and loan associations. 
Gross receipts means gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-40; Ord. of 10-4-1983, § 1) 
Sec. 78-32. - Minimum tax amount. 
The minimum annual amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to section 78-31 shall be $1,000.00. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-41) 
Sec. 78-33. - Filing of return. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(c), each depository financial institution subject to the tax set forth in section 78-31 shall file a return of its gross receipts with the board of commissioners on March 1 of each year following the year in which such gross receipts are measured. Such return shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of revenue based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The board of commissioners shall assess and collect the tax levied in section 78-31 based upon the information provided in the return. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-42) 
Sec. 78-34. - Due date of tax. 
Taxes levied pursuant to section 78-31 shall be due not later than 30 days after filing of the return as set forth in section 78-33, unless such time is extended by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-43) 
Sec. 78-35. - Copy of this article to be sent to financial institutions. 
The clerk of the board of commissioners is directed to forward a copy of this article to each depository financial institution located in the county, and to the home office of each such depository financial institution if located outside of the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-44) 
Secs. 78-36—78-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL AND MOTEL TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— County hotel/motel occupancy tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 78-66. - Levied; exemptions; use of proceeds of the tax. 
Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3), there is levied and imposed an excise tax at the rate of five percent of the charge to the public for and upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room, lodging or accommodation furnished by any person within the unincorporated areas of the county, operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin or other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. Such tax shall not include charges for homes, apartments or accommodations furnished for extended occupancy or for the use of meeting rooms. 
The proceeds of this excise tax shall be used in the manner provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-70; Ord. of 3-18-1986, § 1; Ord. of 4-3-1990, § 1; Ord. No. 07-14, § 1, 12-4-2007) 
Sec. 78-67. - Due date of tax. 
The hotel and motel excise tax levied in section 78-66 shall become delinquent for each month after the twentieth day of each succeeding month during which it remains unpaid. 
Interest and penalties as specified in section 78-73 shall be applied to any portion of the hotel-motel excise tax remaining unpaid after the twentieth day of each month. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-71; Ord. No. 04-2, § 1, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 18-06, § 1, 6-5-2018 ) 
Sec. 78-68. - Dealer's collection fee. 
Dealers collecting the hotel and motel tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for, in the amount of three percent, in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. Upon the failure to make a timely report and remittance by the 20th day of the month next succeeding the month in which such sales were made, such collection fee shall be forfeited in addition to all other applicable penalties. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-72) 
Sec. 78-69. - Remittance; application of funds. 
Dealers shall pay the hotel and motel tax with such remittance form as prescribed by the county comptroller. Each dealer shall remit the tax, payable to the board of commissioners, to the county comptroller's office. During the years 1990 and 1991, 60 percent of the hotel and motel tax collected shall be deposited to the general fund of the county, and 40 percent of such tax collected shall be applied to the development of tourism and industrial development within the county. During the years 1992 and 1993, 40 percent of the hotel and motel tax collected shall be deposited to the general fund of the county, and 60 percent of such tax collected shall be applied to the development of tourism and industrial development within the county. During the years 1994 and 1995, 20 percent of the hotel and motel tax collected shall be deposited to the general fund of the county, and 80 percent of such tax collected shall be applied to the development of tourism and industrial development within the county. Beginning in the year 1996, 100 percent of the hotel and motel tax collected shall be used exclusively for development of tourism and industrial development within the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-73) 
Sec. 78-70. - Verification of books and records. 
All books and records of each dealer shall be subject to inspection and audit by the county to verify compliance with this article. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-74) 
Sec. 78-71. - In addition to other taxes. 
The excise tax provided for in this article shall be in addition to any license fee or occupation tax or charge which may be imposed upon dealers within the incorporated areas of the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-75) 
Sec. 78-72. - Violation; penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article or fails to comply with any requirements of this article shall, upon conviction, in addition to any interest or penalty provided for in this article, be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-76; Ord. No. 00-10, § 9, 10-3-2000; Ord. No. 03-1, § 3, 2-18-2003) 
Sec. 78-73. - Interest, penalties for delinquent or deficient payment, fraud. 
(a)  Interest upon failure to pay tax. When any innkeeper fails to make any return or to pay the full amount of the tax required by an ordinance authorized by this article, there shall be imposed, in addition to other penalties provided by law, a penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than 30 days and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional 30 days or fraction of 30 days during which the failure continues. 
(b)  Penalty for late payment. The penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater. 
(c)  Penalty for fraud or intent to evade. In the case of a false or fraudulent return or of a failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud Columbia County of any tax due under an ordinance authorized by this article, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. 
(d)  Mitigating factors. If the failure is due to providential cause, an innkeeper may demonstrate the applicability of such mitigation in the procedure set out in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-58 and if shown to the satisfaction of the Columbia County governing authority, the return may be accepted exclusive of penalties and interest. 
(Ord. No. 03-1, § 1, 2-18-2003; Ord. No. 04-2, § 2, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 18-07, § 1, 6-5-2018 ) 
Sec. 78-74. - Failure to file report. 
If any person subject to this article fails to file a report, the board of commissioners, or its designee, shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods for which the person failed to make the report and shall be based upon any information which is in the board of commissioner's possession, or which may come into its possession pursuant to inspection or audit under section 78-70. Upon the basis of the estimate, the board of commissioners, or its designee, shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid, adding to the sum computed a penalty equal to 25 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or more periods. The tax amount determined to be paid shall be subject to any applicable interest or penalty provided for in this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-1, § 2, 2-18-2003) 
Secs. 78-75—78-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2; general assembly authorized to provide for taxation of insurance companies based on gross direct premiums received from insurance policies within the unincorporated areas of counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(c). 

Sec. 78-101. - Levied on gross direct premiums. 
Beginning January 1, 1984, and annually thereafter, there is levied a tax of 2½ percent upon the gross direct premiums of all foreign, alien and domestic insurance companies. The tax shall be in addition to the taxes levied by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4, and such tax may be levied upon the gross direct premiums received by such companies on or after January 1, 1984. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-30; Ord. of 8-17-1983, § 2) 
Sec. 78-102. - Calculation of tax; allowable deductions. 
The insurance premium tax shall be levied upon premiums derived from policies insuring persons, property or risks in the unincorporated areas of the county from January 1 to December 31 of each year, without regard to business ceded to or assumed from other companies. The tax shall be imposed upon gross premiums received from direct writing without any deduction allowed from premium abatement of any kind or character, for reinsurance or for losses or expenses of any kind; provided, however, deductions shall be allowed for premiums returned, changes of rates or cancelled policies, provided that deductions shall be permitted for returned premiums or assessments, including all policy dividends, refunds or other similar returns paid or credited to policyholders. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-31) 
Sec. 78-103. - Filing with state insurance commissioner. 
Within 45 days after the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the clerk of the board of commissioners is directed to file a certified copy of this article with the state commissioner of insurance. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-32) 
Sec. 78-104. - Authority to levy. 
The taxes levied by this article are levied pursuant to authority granted by state law. 
(Code 1979, § 2-10-33) 
Secs. 78-105—78-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OCCUPATIONAL TAX AND LICENSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), adopted Nov. 17, 2015, repealed the former Art. V, §§ 78-136—78-156, and enacted a new Art. V as set out herein. The former Art. V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1979, §§ 2-10-1—2-10-21; Ord. No. 95-7, §§ 1—7, adopted Dec. 19, 1995; Ord. No. 01-8, § 1, adopted Oct. 16, 2001; Ord. No. 02-4, § 1, adopted Mar. 5, 2002; Ord. No. 03-12, § 1, adopted Oct. 7, 2003. 

Sec. 78-136. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
The occupation tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes. The occupation tax applies only to those businesses, practices and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5—48-13-26. All other applicable businesses, practices and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-137. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Applicant means the natural person applying for the occupational tax benefit. For a sole proprietor the sole proprietor is the natural person application. For a partnership, corporation, limited liability company or other entity, the natural person applicant is an officer having authority to bind the entity. 
Business means any person, partnership, corporation, limited liability company or other entity who engages in, causes to be engaged in, and/or is represented as being engaged in any occupation, practice of a profession, sale of any goods or services, commercial activity, or other activity with the object of financial gain, benefit or advantage, either directly or indirectly. 
Dominant service or product means the type of service or product from which a business or practice providing multiple services or products derives the greatest amount of income. 
Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer, and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax or state income tax from such individual's compensation, or whose employer issues to such individual, for purposes of documenting compensation, a form I.R.S. W-2, but not a form I.R.S. 1099. 
First responder means peace officers certified under the Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Council as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 35-8-10 et seq., certified emergency medical technicians, paramedics, and cardiac technicians as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 31-11-52 et seq., and certified firefighters as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 25-4-1 et seq. 
Location and office mean, and shall include, any structure or vehicle where a business, profession or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project, or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. 
Occupational tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business which has been enacted by the county as a revenue-raising ordinance or resolution. 
Practice, practitioner and practitioners of professions and occupations mean one who state law requires licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Such terms shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business if the business pays an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015; Ord. No. 16-04 , § 1, 3-29-2016) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-138. - Payment required. 
For the calendar year 1995 and succeeding years thereafter, except those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations excluded by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-16(a) each business and practitioner of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices located within the county shall pay an occupation tax per fixed location as set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-139. - Tax on businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with no location or office in the state. 
(a)  Those businesses, practitioners of professions and occupations with no location or office within the state shall pay an occupational tax, as set out in this article, if such business has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the county for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(b)  The number of employees of a business or practice, subject to this section, shall include only those employees engaged in substantial efforts within the state. 
(c)  Businesses and practitioners subject to this section shall be required to pay an occupation tax only to one local government in the state. Such payment will be made to the county only if the largest dollar volume of business is done or service is performed within the county. 
(d)  If a business or practitioner subject to this article provides the county development services division with proof of payment of a local business or occupation tax in another state which purports to tax the business' or practitioner's sales or services in the state, the business or practitioner shall be exempt from this county's occupational tax. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-140. - Tax levied. 
(a)  The amount of occupation tax to be levied upon an individual business or practitioner shall be based upon the number of employees of the business or practitioner as follows:
