(b)  The number of employees shall be computed on a full-time position basis or a full-time position equivalent basis, provided that, for the purposes of such computation, an employee who works 40 hours or more weekly shall be considered a full-time employee, and that the average weekly hours of employees who work less than 40 hours weekly shall be added and such sum shall be divided by 40 to produce full-time equivalents. 
(c)  No business or practice shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each location of such business or practice. Each fixed location within the county where business or practice is conducted shall be considered a separate business for occupation tax purposes. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-141. - Issuance of tax certificate; proper zoning required; revocation of tax certificate. 
(a)  Under the payment of the occupational taxes assessed in this article, it shall be the duty of the development services division to issue to each business an occupational tax certificate, provided that all information required has been furnished. The information required shall include the name and address of the business, a description of the type of business and the products and services being provided, the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code of the business, the number of employees, the applicant for the business and the applicant's relationship to the business, and any other information deemed necessary by the director. Provided further that the business or applicant is not disentitled to such under other provisions of this Code, or federal or state law. All businesses, other than a natural person as sole proprietor, are required to produce a certificate from the Georgia Secretary of State that such corporation is in good standing according to the records of his office. 
(b)  No tax certificate shall be issued unless the business and premises for which such application is made shall comply to all respects with the county zoning ordinance and with all other laws and ordinances applicable thereto. 
(c)  Those businesses, practitioners of professions and occupations with no location or office within the county shall be exempt from the occupational tax upon providing a completed occupational tax registration for businesses outside Columbia County and a paid occupational tax certificate from another jurisdiction within Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-142. - Election of tax by certain practitioners. 
(a)  Practitioners of professions and occupations listed in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(19) shall elect one of the following as their entire occupation tax: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on the number of employees, as set forth in section 78-140; or 
(2)  A fee per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. A practitioner paying according to this subsection shall not be required to provide information to the county relating to the gross receipts of the business or practice. The per practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(b)  The election between subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of this section shall be made on an annual basis, and must be submitted to the county development services division prior to January 1 of each calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-143. - Classification of businesses or practitioners with more than one type of service or product. 
(a)  A business or practitioner with more than one type of service or product shall be classified according to such business' or practitioner's dominant service or product. 
(b)  The business or practice occupational tax certificate of each business or practice operated in the county shall identify the services or products provided by the business or practitioner. No business or practitioner shall provide or offer to provide any products or services without first having such product or service registered with the county's development services division, and shall have such noted on the business' or practitioner's occupational tax certificate which is required to be displayed. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-144. - Local government using different tax criteria. 
(a)  When more than one local government levies an occupation tax on a business or practitioner which has locations encompassed by the county and other local governments, and such governments use different criteria to establish the amount of occupation tax, the county shall base its tax on the number of employees who are employed within the county's geographical jurisdiction by such business or practitioner. In the case of an employee who works for the same business or practice in more than one municipal corporation or county, the county shall include such person as an employee in its occupation tax calculations if the employee works for the longest period of time within the calendar year within the county's geographic jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh.. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-145. - Transfer of certificate. 
Occupational tax certificates shall not be transferrable. Transfer of ownership or change in location shall be treated as the termination of the business and the establishment of a new business and a new certificate shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-146. - Reserved. 
Sec. 78-147. - Real estate brokers subject to tax. 
Real estate brokers maintaining a principal or branch office within the county are subject to the occupation tax imposed by this article. The license, occupation or professional tax shall permit the broker and the broker's affiliated associate brokers and salespersons to engage in all of the brokerage activities set forth in O.C.G.A. § 43-40-1 without further licensing or taxing other than the state licenses identified pursuant to O.C.G.A. ch. 40, tit. 43. No additional license, occupation or professional tax shall be required of the broker's affiliated associate brokers or salespersons. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-148. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in tax. 
(a)  The board of commissioners may, by subsequent ordinance or resolution, provide for an exemption or reduction in the occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professional as part of a plan for economic development or attracting, encouraging or maintaining selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in the occupation tax shall not be granted arbitrarily or capriciously, and the reasons for the granting of such exemption shall be set forth in the minutes of the meetings in which the board of commissioners makes such a determination. 
(b)  State and local authorities, as well as nonprofit organizations, are exempt from any occupation tax levy. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-149. - When tax due and payable. 
All occupation taxes authorized and imposed by this article, shall be due and payable annually within 30 days following January 1 of each year. In the event that any person commences business on any date after January 1, the tax shall be due and payable prior to the commencement of the business. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-150. - Amount of fee or tax due from businesses commenced on or after July 1. 
When any person commences business on or after July 1 in any calendar year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-151. - Display of certificate and licenses. 
(a)  Each business or practitioner shall exhibit and display all occupational tax certificates issued to them under this Code in a conspicuous place in their business establishment at which address the certificate was issued. Any transient or nonresident business or practitioner shall carry the occupational tax certificate either upon his person or in any vehicle or other conveyance which is used in the business and the person shall exhibit the same to any authorized enforcement or police officer. 
(b)  Each business or practitioner subject to any special or occupation tax under this article, who is also licensed by the state, shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business, and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(c)  Any business or practitioner who is required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall provide the county development services division with proof that such requirements has been fulfilled prior to providing or offering to provide services or products in the county. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-152. - Inspection of books and records. 
The board of commissioners, through its designated representative, may inspect the books and records of any business or practitioner operating in the county for the purpose of verifying the information related to the calculation, assessment and collection of the occupation tax imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Secs. 78-153, 78-154. - Reserved. 
Sec. 78-155. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention of this section that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-156. - Delinquency; violation; penalties. 
(a)  Interest for all delinquent occupation taxes under this article shall accrue at a rate of 1.5 percent per month. 
(b)  Should any occupation tax imposed by this article remain due and unpaid for 90 days from the due date of such tax, the business or practitioner liable for the tax shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the tax due. 
(c)  Should any business or practitioner fail to renew its occupational tax certificate by July 1 following its expiration, the occupational tax certificate permitting the business will be automatically revoked. 
(d)  Any business or practitioner convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be subject to suspension by the county of such business' or practitioner's occupational tax certificate and shall be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances of Columbia County, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 15-29, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 78-157. - Exemption for persons practicing independently as licensed or certified first responders. 
Any first responder shall be exempt from the payment of any occupational tax levied herein; provided however that this exemption shall only apply to the practice of such persons when they are working outside of their primary employment, as independent contractors on special assignments for which a license or certification is used or required. 
(Ord. No. 16-04 , § 2, 3-29-2016) 
Secs. 78-158—78-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - IMPROVEMENTS AND SERVICES FINANCING 

Sec. 78-191. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Department head means the employee, agent, contractor or elected official of the county charged with the responsibility of carrying out the duties set forth in this article. 
Tax assessor means the employee in charge of the county tax assessor's office. 
Tax commissioner means the county tax commissioner. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-192. - Purpose; scope. 
The purpose of this article is to provide for the services and improvements set forth in this section, and to provide for the manner and method of assessing the costs of such services and improvements, or the creation of special tax districts to pay for such services and improvements. The following services and improvements are covered by this article: 
(1)  Police and fire protection; 
(2)  Garbage and solid waste collection and disposal; 
(3)  Public health facilities and services, including hospitals, ambulances, emergency rescue services and animal control; 
(4)  Street and road construction and maintenance, including curbs, sidewalks, streetlights and devices to control the flow of traffic on streets and roads; 
(5)  Parks, recreational areas, programs and facilities; 
(6)  Stormwater and sewerage collection and disposal systems; and 
(7)  Development, treatment, storage, purification and distribution of water. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-2) 
Sec. 78-193. - Preliminary survey and recommendation. 
Whenever a proposal to adopt or provide any of the improvements or services as set forth in section 78-192 has been filed with the board of commissioners, or the board of commissioners on their own motion have considered a proposal to furnish such improvement or to provide such utility, the board of commissioners shall cause the appropriate department head to make a preliminary survey and recommendation to the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-3) 
Sec. 78-194. - Hearing; notice. 
Whenever the board of commissioners shall determine from the preliminary survey that such project has merit and will serve a public need, and that the costs thereof shall be borne in whole or in part by the owners of the property affected, the board of commissioners shall set a time and place for a public hearing before the board of commissioners on such preliminary survey. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the owners of the property affected, by regular mail, if practicable, at least ten days in advance of such hearing, and by publication of such notice, one time, not less than ten days in advance of such hearing, in the newspaper in which notices of sheriff's sales for the county are published. Such notice shall generally describe the improvement or service to be constructed or furnished, the area affected and the manner in which the costs therefor shall be assessed or taxed against the owners of the affected property. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-4) 
Sec. 78-195. - Action on proposal. 
At the time and place fixed for a hearing as set forth in section 78-194, and after publication of the notice of such hearing, the board of commissioners shall proceed to hear the proposal, including objections thereto, if any, of any party at interest, and shall take such action rejecting such proposal, postponing such proposal until some future date, or approving the proposal, whichever action, in the judgment of the board of commissioners, will best promote the public interest. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-5) 
Sec. 78-196. - Resolution authorizing work. 
If the proposal for service or improvement is accepted by the board of commissioners, and in the best judgment of the board of commissioners the costs of such work shall be assessed against the affected property owners, the board of commissioners shall pass a resolution authorizing the necessary work to be done in order to provide such improvement or service, and shall provide in such resolution the manner and method of assessing the costs therefor against the property owners affected, and designating the department head whose responsibility it is to carry out such proposals. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-6) 
Sec. 78-197. - Report of work and cost. 
The department head charged by the resolution passed pursuant to section 78-196 shall, upon completion of the work or upon instituting the service, make a full report thereof to the board of commissioners, which report shall include the final costs of the project, and whether or not the costs, in whole or in part, to be assessed against the affected property owners is greater than or less than the amount anticipated in the preliminary survey. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-7) 
Sec. 78-198. - Assessment resolution. 
Upon receipt of the report as set forth in section 78-197, the board of commissioners shall, if the cost is greater or less than the anticipated cost, pass a resolution providing for the amount to be assessed against the affected property owners. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-8) 
Sec. 78-199. - Notice to owner of assessment; collection. 
The department head shall cause the affected property owner to be notified of the amount of the assessment as set forth in section 78-198, and shall collect the assessment in full in accordance with the terms and conditions of payment as set forth in the resolution. Failure to receive such notice shall not invalidate the assessment. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-9) 
Sec. 78-200. - Imposition of lien. 
The costs of any improvement constructed pursuant to this article or resolution as set forth in this article shall be a lien upon the affected properties from the date of the completion of such improvement, and shall be enforceable in the same manner as executions for taxes are enforced, and shall have the same rank and character as liens for taxes. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-10) 
Sec. 78-201. - Executions for assessments in arrears; issuance. 
Whenever the owner of any property shall fail to pay any assessment when due, the department head shall notify the clerk of the board of commissioners of the amount of the assessment in arrears, the name of the property owner and the affected property. The clerk shall issue an execution therefor, which execution shall be issued in the name of the board of commissioners, and shall be signed by the chairman of the board of commissioners. Such execution shall issue in rem against the property and in personam against the owner of such property, and in addition to the amount in arrears, shall include the sum as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk for the issuance of such execution. Subsequent costs shall be the same as those now allowed by law to the sheriff for the performance of similar services. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-11) 
Sec. 78-202. - Recording of execution; enforcement. 
All executions issued against property and the owner of such property shall immediately be recorded on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of the superior court, and shall be handed to the sheriff, and subsequent proceedings thereon shall be as provided by law for the enforcement of execution for taxes. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-12) 
Sec. 78-203. - Creation of special tax districts. 
In the judgment of the board of commissioners, whenever services or improvements to be furnished under this article cannot be paid for in the manner and method provided in this article, the board of commissioners shall, by appropriate resolution, create a special tax district within the unincorporated areas of the county in which the services or improvements shall be furnished. Such resolution shall provide for the services or improvements to be furnished, the costs thereof, the area affected thereby and the amount to be assessed against each property owner in such district, and shall designate the department head who is charged with the responsibility of carrying out the improvements or services. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-13) 
Sec. 78-204. - Notice of completion to tax assessor and tax commissioner. 
Upon completion of the improvements or institution of the services furnished pursuant to a resolution adopted under section 78-203, the department head shall notify the tax assessor and tax commissioner of the action taken, the district involved and the costs to be assessed against the property owners of such district. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-14) 
Sec. 78-205. - List of taxpayers to be furnished to tax commissioner. 
The tax assessor's office shall compile a list of the property owners within the special tax district, and shall immediately furnish such list to the tax commissioner. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-15) 
Sec. 78-206. - Collection of assessments. 
The tax commissioner shall, on the next succeeding tax bill, place on such tax bill the amount to be assessed against the property owners affected by such assessment, pursuant to the resolution for such work, which shall be collected in the same manner as other ad valorem taxes levied by the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-8-16) 
Secs. 78-207—78-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ENERGY EXCISE TAX 

Sec. 78-251. - Energy excise tax definitions. 
As used in this article, the terms: "dealer;" "energy;" "local sales and use tax;" and "purchaser" shall have the same meanings as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 1, 4-2-2013) 
Sec. 78-252. - Imposition; rate; remitting; recovery; liabilities. 
In accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-110 et seq., there is imposed within the territorial limits of the special district created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-111, an excise tax on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy when such sale, use, storage, or consumption would have constituted a taxable event for purposes of sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq. but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 2, 4-2-2013) 
Sec. 78-253. - Excise tax rate; phase-in. 
(a)  Such excise tax shall be levied and collected by the governing authority of Columbia County pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-112 and 48-13-114 and as provided in this section. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, the rate of such excise tax shall be phased in over a four-year period as follows: 
(1)  For the period commencing January 1, 2013, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2013, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 25 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(2)  For the period commencing January 1, 2014, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2014, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 50 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(3)  For the period commencing January 1, 2015, and concluding at the last moment of December 31, 2015, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 75 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; and 
(4)  On or after January 1, 2016, such excise tax shall be at a rate equivalent to 100 percent of the total amount of local sales and use tax in effect in such special district that would be collected on the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy but for the exemption in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. 
(c)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2(c)(4), if a project of regional significance under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3(92) is started in the special district, it shall not be subject to the phase-in period contained in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of subsection (b) of this section, and the sale, use, storage, or consumption of energy in connection therewith shall be subject to the rate specified in paragraph (4) of subsection (b) of this section notwithstanding the January 1, 2016 limitation in that paragraph (4). 
(d)  (1)  Following such initial imposition during the phase-in time period, on or after January 1, 2016, the rate of the excise tax levied and collected by the governing authority of Columbia County shall be directed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(d). Such rate shall be controlled by the maximum amount of local sales and use tax in effect in the special district, but in no event more than two percent except in the case where the municipal option water and sewer tax is levied where that rate will be three percent within such municipality. 
(2)  In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district decreases from two percent to one percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be reduced at the same time such local sales and use tax rate reduction becomes effective. 
(3)  In the event the total rate of local sales and use taxes in effect in the special district increases from one percent to two percent, the rate of the excise tax under this article shall likewise be increased at the same time such local sales and use tax rate increase becomes effective. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 3, 4-2-2013) 
Sec. 78-254. - Imposition; remittance; recovery. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-112(c), such excise tax shall be: 
(1)  Imposed only at the time sales and use tax on the sale or use of such energy would have been due and payable under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30 but for the exemption under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2; 
(2)  Due and payable in the same manner as would be required under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq., except as other provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq.; 
(3)  A debt of the purchaser of energy until it is paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as authorized for the recovery of other debts; 
(4)  Remitted to the governing authority of Columbia County by the dealer collecting such excise tax; and 
(5)  A liability of the dealer at the applicable rate on the charges actually collected or the amount of excise taxes collected from purchasers, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 4, 4-2-2013) 
Sec. 78-255. - Exemption certificates. 
(a)  The governing authority of Columbia County, or the collecting officer appointed under section 78-258 of this article, shall make diligent efforts to identify all energy providers and purchasers in the special district and to ascertain whether such a purchaser has completed a uniform exemption certificate provided from the website of the Georgia Department of Revenue seeking to qualify such purchaser for the exemption under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-3.2. Such certificate shall be utilized by such governing authority or collecting officer for the purpose of determining the applicability of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)  An energy provider shall be authorized to rely upon such uniform exemption certificates. An energy provider shall not be liable for failing to collect and remit the excise tax imposed pursuant to this article if the purchaser has failed to submit such uniform exemption certificate to the energy provider. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 5, 4-2-2013) 
Sec. 78-256. - Commencement of collections. 
(a)  Due date of tax. The excise tax imposed pursuant to this article shall become effective upon the date of its adoption and shall be due and payable to the governing authority of Columbia County monthly on or before the twentieth day of every month and each respective month in which such taxes are collected, and payment shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding monthly period showing the gross sales and purchases arising from all sales and purchases taxable under this section during the preceding calendar month. 
(b)  Interest upon failure to pay tax. When any dealer fails to make any return or to pay the full amount of the tax required by an ordinance authorized by this article, there shall be imposed, in addition to other penalties provided by law, a penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than 30 days and an additional five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional 30 days or fraction of 30 days during which the failure continues. 
(c)  Penalty for late payment. The penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater. 
(d)  Penalty for fraud or intent to invade. In the case of a false or fraudulent return or of a failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the governing authority of any tax due under an ordinance authorized by this article, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. 
(e)  Mitigating factors. If the failure is due to providential cause, a dealer may demonstrate the applicability of such mitigation in the procedure set out in O.C.G.A. § 48-8-123 and if shown to the satisfaction of the Columbia County governing authority, the return may be accepted exclusive of penalties and interest. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 6, 4-2-2013; Ord. No. 14-13, § 6, 11-4-2014; Ord. No. 18-05, § 1, 6-5-2018 ) 
Sec. 78-257. - Allocation, distribution, and expenditure of proceeds. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114(b), the excise tax proceeds shall be allocated and distributed by the governing authority of Columbia County at the end of each calendar month. An amount equal to one percent of such proceeds collected by Columbia County shall be paid into the general fund of Columbia County to defray the costs of collection and administration. 
(b)  The remainder shall be distributed in accordance with the intergovernmental agreement as required under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114(b) and (c). Within 30 days following the end of each calendar month, the remainder shall be distributed to the general fund of Columbia County and the general fund of each participating municipality in accordance with the applicable provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-114(c)(1) or (2) as follows: 
(1)  If two local sales and use taxes are in effect in the special district, an amount equal to one-half of the proceeds shall be distributed to the general fund of Columbia County and the general fund of each participating municipality located in the county according to the same proportionate share as specified under the distribution provisions of the first local sales and use tax and an amount equal to one-half of the proceeds of the excise tax shall be distributed to the general fund of Columbia County and the general fund of each participating municipality located in such county according to the same proportionate share as specified under the distribution provisions of the second local sales and use tax; or 
(2)  If only one such local sales and use tax is in effect in the special district, then the proceeds of the excise tax shall be distributed to the general fund of Columbia County and the general fund of each participating municipality located in the county according to the same proportionate share as specified under the distribution provisions of the local sales and use tax. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, proceeds of the excise tax deposited in the general fund of Columbia County may be expended for any lawful purpose as determined by the governing authority of Columbia County. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 7, 4-2-2013) 
Sec. 78-258. - Administrative provisions; audits; examinations; collecting officer. 
(a)  The governing authority of Columbia County shall be authorized to designate a collecting officer for collection and administration of the excise tax under this article. 
(b)  The collecting officer shall be authorized to provide for procedures necessary to the proper implementation of this article, including, but not limited to, periodic auditing of dealers collecting and remitting the excise tax. The collecting officer, or the designee of the collecting officer, is specifically authorized to examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, or other facilities of any purchaser which is required to remit the excise tax under this article. 
(c)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-118, as part of the audit report required under O.C.G.A. § 36-81-7, the auditor shall include, in a separate schedule, a report of the revenues pertaining to the excise tax under this article. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, § 8, 4-2-2013) 
Chapter 82 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 58; transporting solid waste, § 70-6. 
State Law reference— Authority of county to regulate traffic in unincorporated areas, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20; uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
DIVISION 1. - TRANSPORTATION REGULATIONS 

Sec. 82-1. - Road and bridge operation and maintenance regulations adopted by reference. 
O.C.G.A. tit. 32, known as Highways, Bridges and Ferries, and O.C.G.A. tit. 40, §§ 40-6-1—40-6-395, known as Uniform Rules of the Road, the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, are adopted as and for the transportation regulations of the county, and are incorporated in this section, by reference, as if set out in full in this section. The intent of this chapter is to establish the basis for administration, maintenance and financing of the county road system. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-1) 
Cross reference— Roads, ch. 66. 
Secs. 82-2—82-20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BICYCLE PATHS 

Sec. 82-21. - Applicability. 
This division shall apply to all bicycle paths owned and/or maintained by Columbia County which are intended for use by bicycles and pedestrians and which are designated as such by resolution of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 82-22. - Violation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized vehicle on any bicycle path. The term "motorized vehicle" means any instrument of travel propelled by a motor or engine of any kind, including, but not limited to, mopeds, motorcycles, golf carts, go carts, electric scooters and battery operated vehicles. The term "motorized vehicle" does not include EAPMDs. "EAPMD" or "electric personal assistive mobility device" means a self-balancing, two nontandem wheeled device designed to transport only one person and having an electric propulsion system with average power of 750 watts (one horsepower) and a maximum speed of less than 20 miles per hour on a paved level surface when powered solely by such propulsion system and ridden by an operator who weighs 170 pounds. 
This section shall not apply to the use of a motorized vehicle as part of an emergency rescue effort or in the enforcement of the provisions of this division by authorized emergency personnel or law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 16-01 , § 1, 2-16-2016) 
Sec. 82-23. - Penalties. 
Any person violating this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 82-24. - Enforcement. 
The sheriff of Columbia County and the sheriff's deputies, as well as such county employee or employees as the board of commissioners may appoint, shall be authorized to issue citations for violations of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 02-11, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Secs. 82-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OFF-ROAD VEHICLES 

Sec. 82-26. - Definition. 
As used in this Division 3, the term off-road vehicle means any motorized vehicle designed for or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland, or other natural terrain and not intended for use predominately on public roads unless said vehicle has been duly registered and licensed for use on public roads pursuant to Section 40-2-20 of the Official Code of Georgia in which event said vehicle shall be limited to operation on the roadway as defined in Section 40-1-1(53) of the Official Code of Georgia to include that portion of the highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel exclusive of the berm or shoulder. Off-road vehicle includes, but is not limited to, four-wheel drive or low-pressure tire vehicles, two-wheel vehicles, three-wheel vehicles, golf carts, go-carts, electric scooters, amphibious machines, ground effect or air cushion vehicles, and any other means of transportation deriving power from any source other than muscle or wind, except that such term shall exclude any motorboat; any military, fire, or law enforcement vehicle; any vehicles used exclusively on airports; all farm machinery, farm tractors, and other self-propelled equipment for harvesting and transportation of forest products, for clearing land for planting, for utility services and maintenance, for earth moving, construction, or mining; and self-propelled lawnmowers, snowblowers, garden or lawn tractors, while such vehicles are being used exclusively for their designed purposes. 
(Ord. No. 03-2, § 1, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 82-27. - Operating restrictions. 
Any person operating an off-road vehicle in the unincorporated areas of the county under any of the following conditions shall be deemed to be in violation of this division: 
(1)  Without operative brakes or without mufflers or other silencing equipment; 
(2)  On any portion(s) of any county or state right-of-way whether or not improved. 
(Ord. No. 03-2, § 1, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 82-28. - Penalties. 
Any person violating this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 03-2, § 1, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 82-29. - Enforcement. 
The sheriff of Columbia County and the sheriff=s deputies, as well as such county employee or employees as the board of commissioners may appoint to serve as code enforcement officers, shall be authorized to issue citations for violations of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 03-2, § 1, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SPEED LIMITS 

Sec. 82-31. - Speed zones established. 
(a)  The board of commissioners, by resolution, shall establish speed zones and speed limits on all state road systems (on-road system) and county road systems (off-road system) within the county. 
(b)  The board of commissioners, by resolution, shall amend the speed zones and speed limits of the county, from time to time, within the discretion of the board of commissioners. 
(c)  Appropriate signs shall be erected denoting the speed limit in each speed zone within the county. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-7; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Secs. 82-32—82-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-61. - Statement of purpose. 
It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety and general welfare, and to provide for locations for parking certain vehicles in areas considered hazardous to the public and which distract from neighborhoods. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-9; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Sec. 82-62. - Designated fire lanes; violation; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to allow his vehicle, trailer, camper, mobile home, boat with trailer, truck, bus or construction equipment to be parked in an area designated and marked as a fire lane and/or fire zone, except for loading and unloading, not to exceed five minutes. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-10; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 82-63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-08, § 1, adopted Nov. 2, 2010, repealed § 82-63, which pertained to parking requirements and derived from Code 1979, § 2-16-62; Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, adopted Nov. 5, 2002; Ord. No. 09-02, §§ 5—8, adopted June 2, 2009. 
Secs. 82-64—82-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HANDICAPPED AND DISABLED PARKING 

Sec. 82-86. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Counterfeit means a copy of any kind of handicapped parking permit which is not authorized by and does not carry the official seal of the department of public safety. 
Handicapped parking lane means an area on public or private property which has been designated as reserved for use of handicapped persons as follows: 
(1)  By a blue metal reflection sign which is at least 12 inches in width and 18 inches in length, and is erected at such height or in such manner that it will not be obscured by a vehicle parked in the space, and bearing the words, "Permit Parking Only," "Tow-Away Zone" and "Maximum Fine $500.00." Such warnings shall be printed in white letters, not less than one inch in height, on three separate lines, and centered on the sign. The sign shall also bear the international symbol for accessibility which shall be centered between the second and third warning. The sign required by this subsection shall be the official authorized sign for handicapped parking place designations in the state; 
(2)  Where the parking place is designated before January 1, 1988, by a sign bearing the words "Tow-Away Zone" and "Handicapped Parking Only," or the words "Tow-Away Zone" and the universal symbol of accessibility, that designation shall be deemed to meet the requirements of subsection (1) of this definition until such time as the sign is replaced for other reasons, at which time any new sign erected shall fully comply with the requirements of subsection (1) of this definition; or 
(3)  Where the parking place is on private property, is constructed solely from concrete, was used by the public, or was finished prior to July 1, 1987, and which is designated by having imprinted and maintained in reflective paint upon each place the words "Tow-Away Zone" and "Handicapped Parking Only," or the words "Tow-Away Zone" and the universal symbol of accessibility, that designation shall be deemed to meet the requirements of subsection (1) of this definition until such time as the concrete lot is renovated, repaired or remodeled, at which time a sign shall be erected which shall comply with the requirements of subsection (1) of this definition. 
Handicapped person means a person who, by reason of illness, injury, age, congenital malfunction or other incapacity or disability has a significant loss or impairment of mobility. 
Institution means an institution for which a permit or conditional permit may be issued under O.C.G.A. art. 1, ch. 7, tit. 31. 
Permanently handicapped person means a handicapped person whose disability or incapacity can be expected to last for more than 180 days. 
Ramp means, in addition to any other specified meanings, the following: 
(1)  Any ramp or curb ramp as defined in ANSI A117.1-1986 by O.C.G.A. ch. 3, tit. 30; and 
(2)  Any vehicle-mounted lift used by handicapped persons for the purpose of access to and from the vehicle upon which such lift is mounted. 
Temporarily handicapped person means a handicapped person whose disability or incapacity can be expected to last for not more than 180 days. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-11; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-87. - Offenses; violation; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand, or for an owner to allow his vehicle to be parked in any handicapped parking place, unless there is displayed on the dashboard or hung from the rearview mirror of the parked vehicle a valid unexpired handicapped parking permit, or unless there is attached to the parked vehicle a specially designated license plate for disabled persons authorized under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-222(d). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand, or for an owner to allow his vehicle to be parked in any handicapped parking place, except for the purpose of allowing a handicapped person to enter or get out of such vehicle while in such parking place. However, nothing in this subsection shall prevent an ambulance or emergency vehicle, in an emergency only, from stopping in a handicapped parking place. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain a handicapped parking permit by fraud counterfeit. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the one to whom a handicapped parking permit or specially designated license plate for the disabled person is issued, to make use of a handicapped parking permit or specially designated license plate for a disabled person. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a handicapped parking permit for an institutional vehicle other than the vehicle for which the permit has been issued. 
(e)  No person shall park a vehicle so as to block an entrance or egress ramp used by handicapped persons on public or private property. 
(f)  Penalties for violations of this section shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any person violating subsection (c) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(2)  Any person violating subsection (a), (b), (d) or (e) of this section shall be subject to a fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk. 
(g)  In addition to the penalties set forth in subsection (f) of this section, any vehicle which is illegally parked in a handicapped parking place which is marked by a sign bearing the words "Tow-Away Zone" as set forth in the definition of "handicapped parking lane" in section 82-86 and O.C.G.A. § 40-6-221(2) on public or private property may be towed away or caused to be towed away by a proper law enforcement agency or the official security agency of such property at the expense of the owner of the vehicle or, if the vehicle is leased or rented, at the expense of the person responsible for payment on the lease or rental agreement. 
(h)  A property owner who is required to provide handicapped parking places shall designate each handicapped parking place with a sign meeting the applicable requirements specified for such parking place in the definition of "handicapped parking lane" in section 82-86 and O.C.G.A. § 40-6-221(2), and upon failure to designate each such handicapped parking place, the property owners shall be subject to a fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk for each place which is not so designated; provided, however, that the fine will be waived if the required designation is made within 14 days from the date of the citation. If the property owner fails or refuses to properly designate the handicapped parking places on his property within such 14-day period, he shall, on the 15th day after receiving the citation, be subject to a fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk for each required handicapped parking place, and an additional fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the county clerk for each day that the owner fails to comply with the provisions of this subsection, until the handicapped parking places are properly designated. All fines assessed under this subsection shall be paid into the treasury of the county issuing the citation against the owner. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-12; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Sec. 82-88. - Specially designated disabled license plates. 
Any person to whom a specially designated disabled veteran's license plate has been issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-2-68—40-2-71, and any person to whom a specially designated disabled person's license plate has been issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-2-72 shall be authorized to park the passenger motor vehicle on which the specially designated license plate is attached in a handicapped parking place without the necessity of obtaining a handicapped parking permit pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-13; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Sec. 82-89. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The board of commissioners or the sheriff's department, in its discretion, may appoint a person who is a citizen of the United States, of good moral character, has not previously been convicted of a felony, and is a handicapped person as defined in section 82-66 and O.C.G.A. § 40-6-221(3), to enforce the provisions of this division within the county in which the appointing law enforcement agency exercises jurisdiction. Each person appointed pursuant to this section shall take and subscribe an oath of office as prescribed by the appointing authority. Any person appointed and sworn pursuant to this section shall be authorized to enforce the provisions of this division in the same manner as any law enforcement officer of the state or the board of commissioners, subject to the limitations provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(b)  No person appointed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall: 
(1)  Be deemed to be a peace officer under the laws of this state; 
(2)  Be deemed an employee of or receive any compensation from the county or appointing law enforcement agency; 
(3)  Be required to complete any training or be certified pursuant to the requirements of O.C.G.A. ch. 8, tit. 35; 
(4)  Have the power or duty to enforce any other traffic or criminal laws of the state, county or municipality; 
(5)  Have the power to possess and carry firearms and other weapons for the purpose of enforcing the handicapped parking laws; provided, however, that a person who possesses a valid license to carry a pistol or revolver issued under O.C.G.A. § 16-11-129, and who carries such weapon in a manner permitted under O.C.G.A. § 16-11-126 shall not be in violation of this subsection; or 
(6)  Be entitled to any indemnification from the county for any injury or property damage sustained by such person as a result of attempting to enforce the handicapped parking laws of the state and the county. 
(c)  Neither the county or other department, agency, board or officer of the county shall be liable or accountable for or on account of any act or omission of any person appointed pursuant to this section in connection with such person's enforcement of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-14; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1) 
Sec. 82-90. - Out-of-state handicapped license plates or permits. 
The county shall honor visitor's out-of-state handicapped license plates and similar special parking permits on the same basis as handicapped license plates and special parking permits issued within this state. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-15) 
Sec. 82-91. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article are applicable to both public and private property; and all law enforcement officers of this county are expressly authorized to enforce the provisions of this division on private property as well as on public property. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-16) 
Secs. 82-92—82-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NO PARKING ZONES AND YELLOW CURB LINES 

Sec. 82-111. - Determination. 
(a)  The engineering department shall investigate the roads, streets, highways and public rights-of-way of the county to determine areas in which on right-of-way parking creates a hazard to the public or to the utilization of such right-of-way or creates an undue burden on the residents and/or property owners bordering such right-of-way. 
(b)  The engineering department shall report the results of its investigation to the board of commissioners with recommendations as to those areas that should be designated as no parking zones and/or yellow curb lines or as restricted parking zones. 
(c)  The board of commissioners shall, by resolution, designate those areas which shall be no parking zones and/or yellow curb lines or restricted parking zones. 
(d)  The engineering department shall furnish a notice of those areas designated as no parking zones, yellow curb lines, or restricted parking zones to the code enforcement officials and to the county sheriff, and shall maintain a file reflecting those areas designated as no parking zones, yellow curb lines, or restricted parking zones. 
(e)  The engineering department shall cause each no parking zone, yellow curb line, or restricted parking zone to be posted and delineated by clear markings or signage pursuant to the provisions set forth in the manual on uniform traffic control devices. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-17; Ord. of 4-2-1991, § 1; Ord. No. 05-09, § 1, 8-2-2005) 
Sec. 82-112. - Restrictions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand, or for an owner to allow his vehicle, trailer, camper, motor home, boat with trailer, bus or construction equipment to be parked in an area designated and marked as a no parking zone and/or yellow curb line, except for commercial vehicles engaged in loading and unloading, not to exceed ten minutes, unless otherwise stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-17.1) 
Sec. 82-113. - No parking zones in school zones. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand, or for an owner to allow his vehicle, trailer, camper, motor home, boat with trailer, bus or construction equipment to be parked in an area designated and marked as a no parking zone located within a posted school zone. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-17.2) 
Sec. 82-114. - Enclosed yellow striped area. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand, or for an owner to allow his vehicle, trailer, camper, motor home, boat with trailer, bus or construction equipment to be parked in an enclosed yellow striped area, unless otherwise set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-17.3) 
Sec. 82-115. - Restricted parking zones. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand or for an owner to allow his vehicle, trailer, camper, motor home, boat with trailer, bus or construction equipment to be parked in an area designated and marked as a restricted parking zone except for commercial vehicles engaged in loading and unloading, not to exceed ten minutes, unless otherwise stated in this chapter, or unless a decal or sticker appears on the parked vehicle, trailer, camper, motor home, boat with trailer, bus or construction equipment issued by Columbia County, which sticker shall be issued only to the residents and/or owners of property bordering the restricted parking zone and/or occupants and guests of such bordering properties. 
(Ord. No. 05-09, § 2, 8-2-2005) 
Sec. 82-116. - Citations. 
(a)  The board of commissioners and/or any lawful sheriff's deputy may designate persons to issue citations for violations of this division by attaching a copy of the citation to the offending vehicle. 
(b)  The owner of such offending vehicle shall appear before the magistrate on the date and time stated on the citation. 
(c)  Upon the offending vehicle owner's failure to appear before the magistrate on the date and time stated on the citation, the magistrate shall issue a show cause order to the offending owner of the vehicle to appear before the magistrate on a certain day to answer the charge cited. The show cause order shall be mailed to the owner of such offending vehicle at his last known address. 
(d)  Should the owner of such offending vehicle fail to appear for such show cause hearing, the magistrate shall issue an order authorizing the sheriff to impound the offending vehicle at the owner's expense and, after 30 days' notice to the owner, to sell the offending vehicle to satisfy all pending fines and expenses. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-19) 
Sec. 82-117. - Violation; penalties. 
Any person who violates the provisions of this division as it relates to no parking zones, no parking zones within a school area and parking within a yellow striped area shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-18; Ord. No. 00-10, § 17(a), 10-3-2000; Ord. No. 05-09, § 2, 8-2-2005) 
Secs. 82-118—82-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TRAILERS, RECREATIONAL VEHICLES, INOPERATIVE VEHICLES AND LARGE VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-05 , § 1(Exh. A), adopted March 29, 2016, repealed the former Div. 4, §§ 82-141—82-143, and enacted a new Div. 4 as set out herein. The former Div. 4 pertained to inoperative vehicles and trailers and derived from Code 1979, §§ 2-15-20—2-15-23; an ordinance adopted April 2, 1991, § 1; Ord. No. 00-10, § 17(b), adopted Oct. 3, 2000) 

Sec. 82-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Axle means a supporting shaft or member on which a wheel or pair of wheels revolves. 
Boat means a craft designed to float on water. 
Bus means a long motor vehicle which is used for carrying passengers. 
Camp trailer means a trailer as defined in this section which is pulled behind a motorized vehicle, and is used for recreational camping as a shelter or carrier for equipment. 
Inoperative vehicle means a vehicle as defined in this section which, for any reason, is nonoperational. 
Limousine means a car licensed to transport passengers in return for payment, typically more luxurious than a taxi and not fitted with a taximeter. 
Motor home means a motor vehicle built on a truck or bus chassis, and which is equipped to serve as a self-contained living quarters for recreational travel. 
Owner , whenever used in this division in relation to parking a motor vehicle, shall mean and include the titled owner, any person who has purchased the vehicle but not yet applied for title in his name, any operator of the vehicle, any person renting the vehicle and any person who operates a vehicle owned by a business, partnership or corporation. 
Portable storage container means a self-storage container that is delivered to and retrieved from a home or business for long term off-site or on-site storage. Portable storage on demand or PODS are a familiar trade name for such containers. These containers are not on a chassis and do not have axles or wheels. 
Temporary storage container means a portable storage unit that does not have a permanent foundation or footing and which includes cargo containers, portable storage containers, truck trailers, construction trailers, and bulk solid waste containers. Such structures shall not be considered a building. 
Trailer means a transport vehicle designed to be hauled by an automobile, truck or tractor, or a furnished van drawn by a truck or automobile and used as a house or office. 
Tractor unit means a heavy-duty towing engine that provides motive power for hauling a towed or trailered load, including but not limited to a semi-trailer. 
Truck means a motorized vehicle designed and/or used for transporting loads. 
Vehicle means a device, such as a motor vehicle or a piece of mechanized equipment, used for transporting passengers, goods, apparatuses or equipment. 
(Ord. No. 16-05 , § 1(Exh. A), 3-29-2016) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-142. - Applicability. 
Vehicles and trailers subject to the provisions of this division are defined as inoperative vehicles, tractor units, camper trailers, motor homes, trailers, boats, trucks with more than two axles, buses and construction equipment. 
(Ord. No. 16-05 , § 1(Exh. A), 3-29-2016) 
Sec. 82-143. - Prohibited conduct; violation; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to allow his vehicle and trailer subject to this division to be parked on any public right-of-way, except for loading and unloading, which loading and unloading shall not exceed 12 hours. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (d), below, it shall be unlawful for an owner to allow his inoperative vehicle, tractor units, trucks with more than two axles, buses or construction equipment to be parked visibly from a public right-of-way in areas zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, PRD, and PUD and in areas used for residential purposes but which are zoned C-1, C-C, C-2, C-3, M-1, M-2, P-1, PDD, and S-1. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any motor home or camper to be used as a residence for a period of time exceeding 14 calendar days in any given calendar year, unless otherwise allowed by chapter 54. 
(d)  It shall be lawful for one inoperative vehicle to be parked in areas zoned R-1, R-2, R-3 and R-4, PRD, and PUD and in areas used for residential purposes but which are zoned C-1, C-C, C-2, C-3, M-1, M-2, P-1, PDD, and S-1, if the inoperative vehicle is in the active process of being repaired, is owned by the resident occupant and has a current state license tag. Use of a residential property for repair of an inoperative vehicle shall be limited to no more than 60 days in a calendar year. Such work shall be performed inside a fully enclosed structure. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any temporary storage container or portable storage container, as defined in this division, to be kept on a lot used for residential purposes for more than 14 calendar days in a calendar year. Temporary storage containers and portable storage containers are not permitted to be placed in public rights-of-way. 
(f)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 16-05 , § 1(Exh. A), 3-29-2016) 
DIVISION 5. - RESERVED OR RESTRICTED PARKING 

Sec. 82-144. - Applicability. 
(a)  This division shall apply to all reserved or restricted parking spaces in parking lots or parking facilities owned and/or operated by Columbia County. 
(b)  The term "reserved parking space" means a parking space in parking lots or parking facilities owned and/or operated by Columbia County which has been marked and designated as reserved for use only by designated officials, as defined herein. Designation shall be by metal reflection signs erected at such height or in such manner that it will not be obscured from the view from a vehicle parking in the space, and bearing the words, "Reserved Parking for Permit # " and listing the permit number of the designated official for whom the space is reserved, and "Tow-Away Zone All others towed at owner's expense". Such warnings shall be printed in letters not less than one inch in height. 
(c)  The terms "restricted parking space" means a parking space or group of spaces in parking lots or parking facilities owned and/or operated by Columbia County which has been marked and designated for use only by a designated group of individuals as defined herein. Designation shall be by metal reflection signs erected at such height or in such manner that it will not be obscured from the view from a vehicle parking in the space, and bearing the words, "Reserved Parking for Permit # " and listing the permit number of the group of designated officials for whom the space is reserved, and "Tow-Away Zone All others towed at owner's expense". Such warnings shall be printed in letters not less than one inch in height. 
(d)  "Designated official" means any governmental official or other individual designated by resolution adopted by the board of commissioners to use a reserved parking space. 
(e)  "Designated group of individuals" means any group or class of individuals designated by resolution adopted by the board of commissioners to use restricted parking spaces. 
(Ord. No. 02-9, § 1, 8-20-2002) 
Sec. 82-145. - Violation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to stop or stand, or for an owner to allow his vehicle to be parked (i) in any reserved parking space, unless such person is the designated official for whom such parking space is reserved or (ii) in any restricted parking space unless such person is a member of the designated group of individuals for which such parking space is restricted to his/her use. 
(Ord. No. 02-9, § 1, 8-20-2002) 
Sec. 82-146. - Penalties. 
Penalties for violations of this section shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any person violating this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to penalties and costs as set forth in section 1-9; and 
(2)  Any vehicle illegally parked in a reserved parking space or a restricted parking space may be towed away or caused to be towed away by a proper law enforcement agency, the official security agency of such property, or any county employee or employees as the board of commissioners may appoint, at the expense of the owner of the vehicle or, if the vehicle is leased or rented, at the expense of the person responsible for payment on the lease or rental agreement. 
(Ord. No. 02-9, § 1, 8-20-2002) 
Sec. 82-147. - Enforcement. 
The sheriff of Columbia County and the sheriff's deputies, as well as such county employee or employees as the board of commissioners may appoint, shall be authorized to issue citations for violations of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 02-9, § 1, 8-20-2002) 
Secs. 82-148—82-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WRECKER OPERATORS ON COUNTY CALL LIST 

Sec. 82-176. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Board means the board of commissioners of the county. 
Call list means the wrecker service rotating call list established by the sheriff pursuant to section 82-178. 
County means Columbia County, Georgia. 
GVW means the rated gross vehicle weight of a vehicle. 
Operator means the owner of any wrecker towing service which is offering its services in the county. 
Permit and towing permit mean the towing permit issued for a wrecker vehicle pursuant to this article. 
Regulations mean the policies, procedures, rules and regulations promulgated by the sheriff pursuant to section 82-178. 
Sheriff and sheriff's department mean the sheriff and sheriff's department of Columbia County, Georgia. 
Wrecker inspector means the officer of the sheriff's department designated by the sheriff to carry out the obligations of the wrecker inspector under this article. 
Wrecker vehicle means any truck or other vehicle which is used to move or transport disabled, abandoned or other vehicles. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-24; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-177. - Classification of wrecker vehicles. 
For purposes of this article, each wrecker vehicle for which a permit is sought under this article will be placed into one of three classifications based on the capacities of the wrecker vehicle and the equipment carried on such vehicle, with the minimum requirements of each classification being as follows: 
(1)  Class A. A class A wrecker vehicle shall be those vehicles designed for towing passenger cars, pickup trucks, small trailers and other vehicles having a weight not in excess of the gross vehicle weight (GVW) of the wrecker vehicle. Such towing vehicles shall have: 
a.  A tow truck chassis with a minimum manufacturer's capacity of one ton, and a towing capacity of 10,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Individual boom capacity of not less than four tons; 
c.  Individual power wench pulling capacity of not less than four tons; 
d.  At least 100 feet of three-eighths-inch, or larger, cable on each drum; and 
e.  Dollies. 
(2)  Class B. A class B wrecker vehicle shall be those designed for towing medium size trucks, trailers and vehicles having a weight not in excess of the rated GVW of the wrecker vehicle. Such towing vehicles shall have: 
a.  A tow truck chassis with a minimum manufacturer's capacity of 1½ tons, and a towing capacity of 18,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Double booms constructed to permit splitting with each boom to operate independently or jointly, with an individual boom capacity of not less than six tons, and an individual power wench pulling capacity of not less than six tons, or a single boom with a capacity of not less than 12 tons, and a power wench pulling capacity of not less than 12 tons; 
c.  At least 200 feet of one-half-inch cable, or larger, on each drum; and 
d.  Cradle tow plate or tow sling to pick up vehicles with the cradle of the tow plate to be equipped with a safety chain. 
(3)  Class C. A class C wrecker vehicle shall be those designated for towing large trucks, road tractors and trailers having a weight not in excess of the rated GVW of the wrecker vehicle. Such towing vehicles shall have: 
a.  A tow truck chassis with a minimum manufacturer's capacity of not less than three tons, and a towing capacity in excess of 18,000 pounds GVW; 
b.  Double booms constructed to permit splitting with each boom to operate independently or jointly, with an individual boom capacity of not less than 12 tons, and an individual power wench pulling capacity of not less than 12 tons, or a single boom with a capacity of not less than 24 tons, and a power wench pulling capacity of not less than 24 tons; 
c.  No less than 200 feet of nine-sixteenths-inch cable, or larger, on each drum; and 
d.  Air brakes constructed so as to automatically lock wheels upon failure. 
For issuance of a permit, the wrecker inspector may approve a wrecker vehicle which he finds is functionally equivalent to a vehicle as set forth in one of the three classes in subsections (1)—(3) of this section, although the wrecker vehicle does not meet each and every specification for such wrecker vehicle classification. The applicant shall bear the burden of demonstrating, through technical literature, a letter from the manufacturer or other reliable source that the wrecker vehicle is functionally equivalent to the requirements set forth in subsections (1)—(3) of this section. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-25; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-178. - Call list. 
The sheriff shall establish a call list for each of the three classes of wrecker vehicles set forth in section 82-177. The operators listed on such call list shall be called for assistance by the sheriff's department or other county officials, as needed, on a rotating basis, with the class of wrecker vehicle being called to the scene which is most appropriately designed and equipped to handle the vehicles which are to be towed. The call list for each class of wrecker vehicles shall include not more than 12 operators. If a call list is full, the sheriff shall place operators who apply for inclusion on the call list on a waiting list with priority on the waiting list being based on the date the application is filed with the sheriff, the earliest application date being the date of higher priority, subject, however, to the provisions of section 82-184. The sheriff shall promulgate, and may amend from time to time, policies, procedures, rules and regulations for the establishment and use of the call list which shall be consistent with the provisions of this article, but which may contain additional requirements for inclusion of operators on the call list, and the operation and use of the call list which the sheriff finds to be in the best interest of the public, for the protection of the public, for the safe, prompt and efficient removal of disabled or abandoned vehicles from public roads, and the cleanup of accident sites, and for otherwise safe and efficient towing of vehicles as required by the county and the sheriff. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-26; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-179. - Towing permit required. 
No operator shall be placed on the call list as set forth in section 82-178 prior to obtaining a towing permit from the county, as provided for in this article, for each wrecker vehicle used by such operator. Permits will be issued for class A, B and C wrecker vehicles, depending on which of the requirements set forth in section 82-177 the wrecker vehicle being permitted meets. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-27; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-180. - Permit application. 
(a)  Any operator desiring to obtain a towing permit for a wrecker vehicle shall file with the wrecker inspector an application setting out the following: 
(1)  Name, business address, business telephone number, home address and home telephone number of the operator seeking the permit. 
(2)  The business address at which the wrecker vehicle for which the application is being made is based, and a description of the buildings, fenced storage area and other facilities located at such address which are utilized in connection with the wrecker towing business. 
(3)  The number of wrecker vehicles available for use by the applicant, and the towing permit numbers of each vehicle, if towing permits have been previously used for such wrecker vehicles. 
(4)  A full description of the wrecker vehicles for which a towing permit is being sought, with sufficient information to determine the proper classification of each wrecker vehicle. 
(5)  A statement that all wrecker vehicles for which a permit is being sought are properly equipped for the classification for which the permit is sought, and in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(6)  A statement that the operator, when included on the call list, will: 
a.  Provide 24-hour service, including holidays; 
b.  Have a qualified driver on duty at all times; and 
c.  Release a vehicle to its rightful owner at any time of the day or night upon 45 minutes' prior notice. 
(7)  A statement that the operator will accept responsibility for all personal property left in towed or stored vehicles. 
(8)  Attach to the application a certificate of insurance evidencing that the applicant has the minimum amounts of insurance required under state and federal regulations then in effect for motor carriers operating freight equipment, which certificate of insurance must contain an endorsement providing for a minimum of ten days' notice to the sheriff prior to the effective date of any cancellation of the policy evidenced by such certificate. 
(9)  Attach to the permit application a copy of the applicant's current county business license for the wrecker towing business, and a statement from the county zoning administration that the real property in the county used by the applicant for the wrecker towing business is properly zoned for such use. 
(b)  The wrecker inspector shall, upon determining that a permit application is complete, inspect the applicant's place of business and the towing vehicles for which a towing permit is sought, to verify that the applicant has the required vehicles, equipment and facilities to authorize the issuance of the towing permit being sought, and to confirm that the applicant is operating in compliance with all applicable state and federal safety regulations pertaining to the operation of a wrecker towing business. No towing permit shall be issued until the operator has demonstrated, to the satisfaction of the wrecker inspector, that the operator meets all of the requirements for the towing permit applied for as set forth in subsection (a) of this section and in the regulations. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-28; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-181. - Equipment required; facilities of operator. 
(a)  In addition to the equipment required under the applicable wrecker vehicle classifications as set forth in section 82-177, all wrecker vehicles for which a towing permit is issued shall have and maintain the following equipment, as a condition to issuance of the permit: 
(1)  At least one heavy-duty push broom. 
(2)  One shovel. 
(3)  A fire extinguisher having an Underwriters' Laboratories rating of 5B:C or more, or two fire extinguishers, each of which has an Underwriters' Laboratories rating of 4B:C, or more. 
(4)  At least one spare fuse or other overload protective device if the devices used are not of a reset type for each kind and size used. 
(5)  Three bidirectional emergency reflective triangles. 
(6)  Tow lights. 
(7)  One set of bolt cutters. 
(b)  In addition, the operator shall maintain in the county a fenced-in storage area for the parking and storage of towed vehicles, and an enclosed building containing a storage area for vehicles that need to be stored indoors. Fencing around the storage area must be at least six feet high with three strands of barbed wire on top, and must be of chainlink or a more secure material. The fenced storage area must be large enough to park not less than 30 full-size passenger cars. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-29; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-182. - Driver qualifications. 
The operator shall not employ or authorize anyone, including the operator, to drive a wrecker vehicle who does not meet the qualifications for drivers established by the United States Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration, and Safety Regulations Parts 383 and 391. Medical examinations must be performed at least once every two years on the drivers of wrecker vehicles operating under towing permits issued pursuant to this article, in accordance with the procedures for testing as set forth in FMCSR Sections 391.41, 391.43 and 391.45. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-30; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-183. - Issuance of towing permit. 
If the wrecker inspector approves an application for issuance of a towing permit, he shall forward written evidence of such approval to the office of the county designated by the board of commissioners to issue towing permits, which office shall promptly issue the approved towing permit. The towing permit shall be kept on board the wrecker vehicle for which it was issued. A towing permit shall be in effect until December 31 of the year in which it was issued, at which time it shall expire and a new towing permit will have to be applied for. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-31; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-184. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The wrecker inspector or the sheriff may suspend or revoke the towing permit for any wrecker vehicle on any of the following grounds: 
(1)  If the towing permit was procured by fraudulent, false or misleading statements, conduct or representations. 
(2)  Failure of the operator to comply with state and federal safety regulations applicable to the operation of a wrecker towing business. 
(3)  Failure of the operator to comply with the provisions of this article or the regulations. 
(4)  Failure of the operator to maintain the insurance coverages as set forth in section 82-180(a)(8). 
(5)  Failure of the operator to maintain and operate such wrecker vehicle in accordance with the requirements of state and federal regulations pertaining to the maintenance and operation of the vehicle. 
(6)  An unsatisfactory or conditional rating by the United States Department of Transportation. 
(b)  A suspension of a towing permit may be for a period of not less than 30 days, nor more than 180 days. If an operator's towing permit is suspended, the operator shall be removed from the call list during such period of suspension, but shall be returned to the call list when the suspension is lifted, provided that the call list does not have at that time 12 operators on it. If there are 12 operators on the call list upon the lifting of the suspension, the affected operator will be placed at the top of the waiting list. 
(c)  A revocation of a towing permit shall automatically cause the operator to be removed from the call list. Once removed from the call list because of a revocation of the towing permit, the operator shall be treated as a new applicant for inclusion on the call list if he subsequently acquires a permit and again becomes eligible to be placed on the call list. Any operator who has a towing permit revoked shall not be eligible to apply for a towing permit for a period of one year following such revocation. 
(d)  The suspension or revocation of one or more towing permits held by an operator shall automatically operate as a suspension or revocation, as the case may be, of all permits held by such operator. 
(Code 1979, § 2-15-32; Ord. of 11-2-1993) 
Sec. 82-185. - Hearing prior to revocation of permit. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in this article, or unless waived by the holder of a towing permit, no towing permit shall be suspended or revoked without the opportunity for a hearing as provided in this section. The wrecker inspector shall provide written notice to the operator of the initiation of an action to suspend or revoke a towing permit. Such written notification shall set forth, in reasonable detail, the reasons for such action, and shall notify the operator of the right to a hearing under the provisions of this section.
